rule.message: Did you mean ?

rule.message: Did you mean ?

rule.name: true to her words (word)
rule.message: Did you mean the idiom 'true to one's word' (=keep one's promise)?
rule.example: She was true to her words.

rule.name: 360 (180) degree change
rule.message: Did you mean ? (360 degrees leads to the starting point)
rule.example: She made a 360 degree change in her life.

rule.name: tow (toe) the line
rule.message: Did you mean toe?

rule.name: wrack (rack) one's brain about
rule.message: Did you mean ?

rule.name: Halo (Hallo)
rule.message: Did you mean Hallo, the greeting? A halo is an optical phenomenon.

rule.message: Did you mean \1\2re?
rule.example: We'Re looking forward to our meeting.
We'RE looking forward to our meeting.

rule.message: Did you mean \1\2t?

rule.name: 'as follow' (as follows)
rule.message: Did you mean as follows?
rule.example: We can elaborate this distinction as follow.

rule.name: 'by' + passive participle (be)
rule.message: Did you mean be?
rule.example: This can by consistent with usability constraints.

rule.message: Possible spelling error: Did you mean mis\2

rule.message: Possible spelling error: Did you mean World War

rule.name: wont (won't)
rule.message: Please make sure you mean 'wont' (a habit), not won't/won’t (short for 'will not')?
rule.example: No, I wont do that.
We were wont to meet at that pleasant spot.
As is his wont, Tourneur shows us only parts of the set, in logical sequence, each at the moment when, and not before, we need to see it.

rule.name: re cent (recent)
rule.message: Did you mean recent?

rule.name: if which
rule.message: which should not follow if. Choose either one. Or did you forget a comma?

rule.name: ah ha (aha)

rule.message: Did you mean standalone?
rule.example: I wrote a stand alone application.

rule.name: past time (pastime)
rule.message: Did you mean pastime?
rule.example: This was America's favorite past time.

rule.name: any where (anywhere)
rule.message: Did you mean anywhere?
rule.example: Put your stuff down any where.

rule.name: some where (somewhere)
rule.message: Did you mean somewhere?
rule.example: There's a place for us, some where.

rule.name: a bail out (bailout)
rule.message: Did you mean bailout?
rule.example: The bail out was too expensive.

rule.name: out come (outcome)
rule.message: Did you mean outcome?
rule.example: What was the out come?

rule.name: album comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean composed of?
rule.example: This is an album comprised of of great songs.
This is an album composed of great songs.

rule.name: area comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean area consisting of?
rule.example: The Tenderloin is an area comprised of the seedy sort.

rule.name: band comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean band composed of or band comprising?
rule.example: The Beatles were a band comprised of great musicians.

rule.name: comprised principally of
rule.message: Did you mean composed of?
rule.example: The lawsuit was comprised primarily of false accusations.

rule.name: entirely comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean composed of?
rule.example: It was entirely comprised of people.

rule.name: comprised chiefly of
rule.message: Did you mean composed \2 \3 or comprised \2 or consisted \2 \3?

example.correction: composed chiefly of|comprised chiefly|consisted chiefly of

rule.example: The song was comprised chiefly of B chords.

rule.name: comprises of
rule.message: Did you mean comprises or consists of?
rule.example: The part comprises of the whole.

rule.name: comprising of
rule.message: Did you mean comprising or consisting of?
rule.example: This is a country comprising of independent people.

rule.name: comprise of
rule.message: Did you mean comprise or consist of?
rule.example: It's tough to think you comprise of mostly water.

rule.name: was comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean comprised or consisted of or was composed of?
rule.example: The proposal was comprised of faulty assumptions.

rule.name: were comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean comprised or were composed of?
rule.example: The missiles were comprised of nuclear warheads.

rule.name: which comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean which comprised or which consisted of or which was composed of?

example.correction: which comprised|which consisted of|which was composed of

rule.example: The ants, which comprised of the colony, were asleep.

rule.name: will be comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean will be composed of or will comprise or will consist of?

example.correction: will be composed of|will comprise|will consist of

rule.example: The album will be comprised of synthetic sounds.

rule.name: will comprise of
rule.message: Did you mean will be composed of or will comprise or will consist of?

example.correction: will be composed of|will comprise|will consist of

rule.example: The ants will comprise of the colony.

rule.name: would comprise of
rule.message: Did you mean would comprise or would consist of?
rule.example: The ants would comprise of the colony.

rule.name: government comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean government composed of or government consisting of?
rule.example: Theirs was a government comprised of warring factions.

rule.name: is comprised mostly of
rule.message: Did you mean comprises mostly or consists mostly of or is composed mostly of?

example.correction: comprises mostly|consists mostly of|is composed mostly of

rule.example: The government is comprised mostly of idiots.

rule.name: is comprised of
rule.message: Did you mean comprises or consists of or is composed of?
rule.example: The government is comprised of idiots.
The government consists of great guys.

rule.name: political gaffs (gaffes)
rule.message: Did you mean gaffes?
rule.example: There were some serious political gaffs committed that day.

rule.name: political gaff (gaffe)
rule.message: Did you mean gaffe?
rule.example: His novel was a huge cultural gaff.

rule.name: were MD
rule.message: Did you mean where ?
rule.example: Were could we sleep tonight?

rule.name: other then (other than)
rule.message: Did you mean other than?
rule.example: There was no one other then us at the campsite.

rule.name: was aloud (allowed)
rule.message: Did you mean \1 allowed?
rule.example: No dancing was aloud.

rule.name: eluded to (alluded to)
rule.message: Did you mean allude to?
rule.example: He eluded to engagement at the party.

rule.name: allude (elude)
rule.message: Did you mean elude?
rule.example: Her failure to allude the school bullies is evident.

rule.name: complaint (compliant) with
rule.message: Did you mean compliant (= in agreement with rules, standards, or requirements)?
rule.example: If the rules are not fully complaint with the specification, post them here.
Any law that is enacted today must be complaint with the fundamental rights chapter of the Constitution.

rule.name: baited (bated) breath
rule.message: Did you mean bated breath?
rule.example: We are waiting with baited breath.

rule.name: bare (bear) in mind
rule.message: Did you mean bear in mind?
rule.example: Bare in mind that we're alone.

rule.name: playoff birth (berth)
rule.message: Did you mean playoff berth?
rule.example: The Patriots failed to earn a playoff birth.

rule.name: disc break (brakes)
rule.message: Did you mean disc brake?
rule.example: The rear wheels are disc break.

rule.name: hit the breaks (brakes)
rule.message: Did you mean hit the brakes?
rule.example: Charlie forgot to hit the breaks.

rule.name: spinal chord (cord)
rule.message: Did you mean \1 ?
rule.example: There was permanent injury to the spinal chord.

rule.name: full compliment (complement) of
rule.message: Did you mean full complement of?
rule.example: He had the full compliment of good qualities.

rule.name: in edition (addition) to
rule.message: Did you mean in addition to?
rule.example: In edition to failing, he embarrassed himself.
And in addition to the belt, he had a chartreuse cap.

rule.name: faired (fared) as well
rule.message: Did you mean fared as well?
rule.example: He faired as well as could be expected.

rule.name: faired (fared) badly
rule.message: Did you mean fared ?
rule.example: It was a pity that the Jets faired badly.
It was a pity that the Mets fared rather well.

rule.name: and so fourth (forth)
rule.message: Did you mean and so forth?
rule.example: And so on and so fourth.

rule.name: put fourth (forth) the
rule.message: Did you mean put forth ?
rule.example: He put fourth the proposal.

rule.name: forth (fourth) place
rule.message: Did you mean fourth place?
rule.example: The runner finished in forth place.

rule.name: door jam (jamb)
rule.message: Did you mean door jamb?
rule.example: There were scratches all along the door jam.

rule.name: less (fewer) dollars
rule.message: Did you mean fewer ?
rule.example: There were less hours to devote to work that day.
There were fewer dollars in the coffer that weekend.

rule.message: Did you mean less ?
rule.example: He gave his enemies fewer information than he gave his friends.
He gave his enemies fewer advice than he gave his friends.
They made less progress towards their goal.

rule.message: Did you mean less ?
rule.example: He gave his enemies fewer information than he gave his friends.
He gave his enemies fewer advice than he gave his friends.
They made less progress towards their goal.

rule.name: am loathe (loath) to
rule.message: Did you mean loath to?
rule.example: I am loathe to continue this conversation.

rule.name: loosing (losing) effort
rule.message: Did you mean losing ?
rule.example: The Yankees never had a loosing season.
It was a terrible losing record.

rule.name: mute (moot) point
rule.message: Did you mean moot point?
rule.example: It was a mute point, so we ignored it.
I believe that statement is largely a moot point.

rule.name: peak (pique) his interest
rule.message: Did you mean pique \2 \3?
rule.example: The mere mention of Luxembourg was enough to peak his interest.
The dance music failed to pique his interest.

rule.name: most populace (populous)
rule.message: Did you mean populous?
rule.example: Chicago was the most populace city.
California is the most populous state.

rule.name: at the reigns (reins)
rule.message: Did you mean the reins?
rule.example: The coachman held the reigns with expertise.
The CEO holds the reins with authority.

rule.name: managerial reigns (reins)
rule.message: Did you mean managerial reins?
rule.example: He handed over the managerial reigns of the project to the junior member.
He held the managerial reins throughout the project's lifespan.

rule.name: reigns (reins) of power
rule.message: Did you mean reins of power?
rule.example: Idi Amin held the reigns of power for far too long.
Napoleon had such a firm grasp on the reins of power.

rule.name: take the reigns (reins)
rule.message: Did you mean take the reins?
rule.example: Take the reigns cried the bandit.
Take the reins! cried the bandit.

rule.name: free reign (rein)
rule.message: Did you mean free rein?
rule.example: The famous actor was given free reign over the city.
The famous actor was given free rein over the city.
Free Reign Entertainment (www.freereign.net) supplies video games.

rule.name: lead roll (role)
rule.message: Did you mean \1 role?
rule.example: She accepted the lead roll in the prestigious play.

rule.name: roll player (role player)
rule.message: Did you mean role player?
rule.example: Eddie House was mainly a roll player in the Celtics' championship run.
Darko would be relegated to a mere role player during his last seasons.

rule.name: role (roll) call
rule.message: Did you mean roll call?
rule.example: The colonel always forgot to take role call.
The opponents' names were messed up during roll call.

rule.name: construction sight (site)
rule.message: Did you mean construction site?
rule.example: We didn't visit the construction sight until Wednesday.
We didn't visit the construction site until it was almost finished.

rule.name: out of sink (sync)
rule.message: Did you mean out of sync?
rule.example: The teammates were so badly out of sink.

rule.name: different tact (tack)
rule.message: Did you mean different tack?
rule.example: We'll have to try a different tact.

rule.name: IN PRP then (than) IN PRP
rule.message: Did you mean than ?
rule.example: I'd rather be between him then between she.
I'd rather be between him than between her.

rule.name: comparisons then (than)
rule.message: Did you mean than?
rule.example: It was hotter then it'd ever been.

rule.name: comparisons NNS then (than)
rule.message: Did you mean than?
rule.example: There were better companies then GE and Google.

rule.name: comparison 'as ... as' (no comparative/superlative)
rule.message: Did you mean ?
rule.example: We must do our job as best as we can.
She’s not singing as loudly as she can.

rule.name: to blank then (than) by
rule.message: Did you mean than ?
rule.example: I'd rather go to play then by the market.

rule.name: waived (waved) off
rule.message: Did you mean waved off?
rule.example: The offsides call was waived off by the referee.
The offsides wall was waved off by the referee.

rule.name: wreck (wreak) havoc
rule.message: Did you mean wreak havoc?
rule.example: The hurricane would go on to wreck havoc up and down the coast.

rule.name: about who (whom) to
rule.message: Did you mean whom to?
rule.example: What do you think about who to promote?

rule.message: Did you mean \3m instead of 'who'.
rule.example: With who did you go?
For who is so tolerant of an unjust city, so ironclad, that they can hold back?

rule.message: Did you mean \2m instead of 'who'.
rule.example: Sarah gave the tickets to who?

rule.message: Did you mean \3m instead of 'who'.
rule.example: The hall was filled with students, many of who were girls.

rule.message: Did you mean instead of 'whom'.
rule.example: Whom paid for the meal?
With whom did you talk?
Whom did you meet?
The hall was filled with students, many of whom were girls.

rule.message: Did you mean \2m instead of 'who'.
rule.example: Depending on who you like more...

rule.name: VBG you're (your)
rule.message: Did you mean your?
rule.example: Stop visualizing you're own demise.

rule.name: that's you're (your)
rule.message: Did you mean your?

rule.name: that's they're (their)
rule.message: Did you mean their?
rule.example: That's they're fault.
Who's their advisor this year?

rule.name: that's its (possessive)
rule.message: Did you mean its?
rule.example: He's it's primary caretaker.

rule.name: your (you)
rule.message: Did you mean you?
rule.example: Have your seen my sister?
Have your ever come across an animal like this?
Can I have your full name?

rule.message: Did you mean excited (=enthusiastic) instead of 'exited' (=gone away)?
rule.example: She is really exited about it.

rule.message: Did you mean You're?
rule.example: Your not a nice man.
Your a great guy!
Your the nicest girl on earth!

rule.message: Did you mean 're?
rule.example: Your beautiful.
Did you know that your beautiful?
Did you do this on your own?
I'm tired of your nagging.

rule.message: Did you mean You're?
rule.example: Your welcome.
Your right, but for the wrong reason.

rule.message: Did you mean Yours? (complimentary close)
rule.example: Your sincerely, Tom

rule.name: you're (your) JJS NN
rule.message: Did you mean your ?
rule.example: I'd like to buy you're greenest banana please.

rule.name: they're (their) JJS NN
rule.message: Did you mean their ?
rule.example: It was they're oddest hypothesis yet.

rule.name: 'wherever there (they are) going'
rule.message: Did you mean they are?
rule.example: Wherever there going, I will follow them.

rule.name: VBZ IN they're (their) NN
rule.message: Did you mean their ?
rule.example: What kind of person disparages of they're company?

rule.name: IN VBZ they're (their) NN
rule.message: Did you mean their ?
rule.example: The only thing we think of is they're happiness.

rule.name: DT VBZ they're (their) NN
rule.message: Did you mean their ?
rule.example: And if another is they're boyfriend, I will be angry.

rule.name: need to VBG (VB)
rule.message: Did you mean ?
rule.example: We're going to hypothesizing about the origins of man.

rule.name: Ill (I'll)
rule.message: Did you mean I'll?
rule.example: Ill explain!
I'll never do this again!
Ill news comes apace.

rule.name: I ill (I will)
rule.message: Did you mean will \3 or is a hyphen missing ill-\3 (e.g., ill-treated, ill-advised)?
rule.example: It seems that I ill have to celebrate at home.
They ill treated me.
Am I ill, Doc?

rule.name: laid (lay) ahead
rule.message: Did you mean lay ahead?
rule.example: We never knew what laid ahead.

rule.name: lay (lie) around
rule.message: Did you mean lie ?
rule.example: All he did Sunday was lay around the house.

rule.name: laying (lying) around
rule.message: Did you mean lying ?
rule.example: He had a special talent for laying low.

rule.name: lays (lies) atop
rule.message: Did you mean lies ?
rule.example: The text explains how important it is that the chicken lays on the noodles artfully.

rule.name: was lain (laid)
rule.message: Did you mean \1 laid?
rule.example: The body was lain beside his wife in the cemetery.
His body was laid beside his wife in the cemetery.

rule.name: Jimmy Buffet (Buffett)
rule.message: Did you mean Jimmy Buffett?
rule.example: Jimmy Buffet sang at the Arco Arena.
Jimmy Buffett sang at Arco Arena.

rule.name: Harison (Harrison) Ford
rule.message: Did you mean the American actor and film producer Harrison Ford?
rule.example: Harison Ford is famous for playing Indiana Jones.

rule.name: Erwin Schroedinger (Schrödinger)
rule.message: Did you refer to the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger (1887–1961)?
rule.example: The Schrodinger equation is a mathematical formulation for studying quantum mechanics.

rule.name: Jimmy (Jimi) Hendrix
rule.message: Did you mean Jimi Hendrix?
rule.example: Some argue that Jimmy Hendrix was the best guitarist who ever lived.
Some argue that Jimi Hendrix was the best ever.

rule.name: Phillips (Philips) Arena
rule.message: Did you mean Philips Arena?

rule.name: jive (jibe) with
rule.message: Did you mean jibe with?

rule.name: mash (mashed) potatoes
rule.message: Did you mean mashed potatoes?

rule.name: brew haha (brouhaha)
rule.message: Did you mean brouhaha?

rule.name: working (work in) progress

rule.name: historic (historical) record
rule.message: Did you mean historical record?
rule.example: The policy was strictly a matter of historic record.

rule.name: guest stared (guest-starred)

rule.name: in titled (entitled)

rule.example: The children felt in titled to their expensive education.

rule.name: is contained of (contains)
rule.message: Did you mean contains?
rule.example: The beer is contained of hops and water.

rule.name: after been (being)
rule.message: Did you mean after being?
rule.example: After been assaulted, the man was often wary.

rule.name: imminent (eminent) domain
rule.message: Did you mean eminent domain?
rule.example: Their house was claimed due to imminent domain.

rule.name: chomping (champing) at the bit
rule.message: Did you mean champing at the bit?
rule.example: The horses were all chomping at the bit.

rule.name: constellation (consolation) prize
rule.message: Did you mean consolation prize?

rule.name: constitutes (consists) of

rule.name: could (couldn't) care less

rule.example: The man on the street said he could care less.

rule.name: couldn't careless (care less)
rule.message: Did you mean care less?
rule.example: I couldn't careless.

rule.name: could (couldn't) give a damn
rule.message: Did you mean couldn't give a damn?
rule.example: Frankly, my dear, I could give a damn.

rule.name: daily regiment (regimen)
rule.message: Did you mean daily regimen?
rule.example: They had a strict daily regiment of calisthenics.

rule.name: de factor (facto)
rule.message: Did you mean de facto?
rule.example: There was a de factor ban on cigarettes.

rule.name: worse-case (worst-case) scenario
rule.message: Did you mean worst-case scenario?
rule.example: They always prepared for the worse-case scenario.

rule.name: worst (worse) comes to worst
rule.message: Did you mean worse comes to worst?
rule.example: If worst comes to worst, we'll just move.

rule.name: to bath (bathe)
rule.message: Did you mean to bathe?
rule.example: It's so relaxing to bath in the evening.

rule.name: treasure trough (trove)
rule.message: Did you mean treasure trove?

rule.name: ad nauseum (nauseam)
rule.message: Did you mean ad nauseam?
rule.example: The song was playing ad nauseum.

rule.name: Noble (Nobel) Prize
rule.message: Did you mean Nobel ?
rule.example: He was awarded the Noble Prize in literature.
He was awarded the Nobel Prize in physics.
He was awarded the Noble prize in literature.

rule.name: land lover (landlubber)
rule.message: Did you mean landlubber?

rule.name: strike a cord (chord)
rule.message: Did you mean strike a chord?

rule.name: safety (safe) deposit box
rule.message: Did you mean safe deposit box?
rule.example: He inherited his grandfather's safety deposit box.

rule.message: Did you mean statute of limitations?

rule.message: Did you mean as far as?

The town was as far as the border.

rule.name: discussions around (about)
rule.message: Did you mean about?

rule.name: as time progressed (passed)

rule.name: as follow (follows)
rule.message: Did you mean as follows?

rule.name: beyond the pail (pale)
rule.message: Did you mean beyond the pale?
rule.example: His behavior was beyond the pail.

rule.name: beckon (beck and) call
rule.message: Did you mean beck and call?
rule.example: Don't expect me to be at your beckon call.

rule.name: begs (beggars) belief
rule.message: Did you mean beggars belief?
rule.example: It begs belief that corporate policies can always pursue the best interests of a company.

rule.name: buttload (boatload)
rule.message: Did you mean boatload?

There was a boatload of sprouts left over.

rule.name: brussel (brussels) sprout
rule.message: Did you mean brussels sprout?

rule.name: bored of (with)

rule.name: build off of (build on)
rule.message: Did you mean build on?
rule.example: Arcade Fire tried to build off of the success of their first album.

rule.name: trite (tried) and true
rule.message: Did you mean tried and true?
rule.example: It was a trite and true solution.

rule.name: between you and I (me)
rule.message: Did you mean between you and me?
rule.example: Between you and I, there's no hope of survival.
Between you and me, there's no hope of cake tomorrow.

rule.name: every (ever) since
rule.message: Did you mean ever since?

rule.name: fowl (fell) swoop
rule.message: Did you mean fell swoop?

rule.name: gardener (garter) snake
rule.message: Did you mean garter snake?

rule.name: hay day (heyday)
rule.message: Did you mean heyday?

rule.name: hardly never (ever)
rule.message: Did you mean hardly ever?

rule.name: hew (hue) and cry
rule.message: Did you mean hue and cry?

rule.name: minus well (might as well)
rule.message: Did you mean might as well?

rule.name: oft chance (off chance)
rule.message: Did you mean off chance?

rule.name: on the same token (by the same token)
rule.message: Did you mean by the same token?
rule.example: On the same token, they believe you've cheated them.

rule.name: one of the only (few)
rule.message: Did you mean one of the few?

rule.message: Did you mean pedal to the metal?

rule.name: pawn off (palm off)

rule.name: plays a factor (plays a role)
rule.message: Did you mean plays a role?

rule.name: realms (realm) of possibility
rule.message: Did you mean realm of possibility?

rule.name: sense of false security (false sense of security)
rule.message: Did you mean false sense of ?
rule.example: The members of the board were holding onto a sense of false security.

rule.name: ring (wring) its neck
rule.message: Did you mean wring its neck?

rule.message: Did you mean rite of passage?

rule.name: souse (sous) chef
rule.message: Did you mean sous chef?

rule.name: stock and trade (stock in trade)
rule.message: Did you mean stock in trade?

rule.name: sound byte (bite)
rule.message: Did you mean sound bite?

rule.name: to the manor (manner) born
rule.message: Did you mean to the manner born?

rule.name: vintage (vantage) point
rule.message: Did you mean vantage point?

rule.name: whim (wing) and a prayer
rule.message: Did you mean wing and a prayer?

rule.name: year end (in) and year out
rule.message: Did you mean year in and year out?

rule.name: hand and hand (hand in hand)
rule.message: Did you mean hand in hand?

The ability to talk about nothing important goes hand in hand with being a Brown student.

rule.name: grasping for straws (grasping at straws)
rule.message: Did you mean grasping at straws?
rule.example: At that point, the desperate gentleman was simply grasping for straws.
At the point it's just grasping at straws.

rule.name: grill (grilled) cheese
rule.message: Did you mean grilled cheese?
rule.example: The kid only wanted to eat grill cheese sandwiches.

rule.name: might has (as) well
rule.message: Did you mean might as well?
rule.example: You might has well take off your shoes.

rule.name: on the contraire (au contraire)
rule.message: Did you mean au contraire or on the contrary?
rule.example: On the contraire, you've been following me home!

rule.name: damp squid (squib)
rule.message: Did you mean damp squib?
rule.example: The last firework of the evening was a disappointing damp squid.

rule.name: cursing (coursing) through veins
rule.message: Did you mean coursing through veins?

rule.name: daring-do (derring-do)
rule.message: Did you mean derring-do?

rule.name: death nail (knell)

rule.name: reap what you sew (sow)

rule.name: spare (spur) of the moment

rule.name: tongue and (in) cheek

rule.name: urine analysis (urinalysis)

rule.name: tattle-tail (tattle-tale)

rule.name: its is (it is)

rule.name: Id would (I would)

rule.name: flashpoint (flash point)

rule.name: can blackout (black out)

rule.name: to comeback (come back)

rule.name: along (a long) time

rule.name: downpayment (down payment)
rule.message: Did you mean down payment?

rule.name: smartphone (smart phone)

rule.name: I am worry (worried)

I'm worry about her.

rule.name: must of the time (most of the time)
rule.message: Did you mean most of the \4?

rule.name: complement / compliment
rule.message: Did you mean the verb 'compliment' (=say something nice)?

rule.name: confusion of hart/heart
rule.message: Did you mean heart (=muscular organ)?

rule.name: confusion of fond/fund
rule.message: Did you mean ?

rule.name: confusion of contract/contact

rule.name: confusion of hart/hard

rule.message: Did you mean into (or 'in two')?
rule.example: It is split in to two sections.
The board split in two.

rule.message: Did you mean rid ('get rid of' = 'discard' or 'get free of')?
rule.example: Let's get ride of that broken chair.

rule.message: Did you mean of ('get rid of' = 'discard' or 'get free of')?
rule.example: Let's get rid if that broken chair.

rule.name: for time to time (from time to time)
rule.message: Non-standard phrase. Did you mean from \2 \3 \4?

rule.name: save (safe) to ignore

Th must not...

rule.name: 'hair' + singular verb

rule.example: She cut her hairs yesterday.

rule.name: too so(o)n
rule.message: Did you mean soon?

rule.name: Let + object
rule.message: Please check whether an object form is required here.
rule.example: Let she do it!

rule.name: ask + object (no preposition)
rule.message: The verb 'to someone' does not require a preposition.

rule.name: please + 3rd person verb
rule.message: Did you mean ?

rule.name: will follows be ('he is would')

rule.name: can able to (can)
rule.message: Please check whether one of these words is redundant.
rule.example: So you can able to download more apps regardless of the storage.

rule.name: rely on
rule.message: The verb 'to rely' requires the preposition '(up)on': \1 on.
rule.example: I rely my family to help me out.

rule.name: Missing preposition: allow (to) do
rule.message: Please check whether 'to' is missing here (to allow to do something).
rule.example: He allowed me do it on my own.

rule.name: Missing preposition: explain (to)
rule.message: The verb 'to explain something to someone' requires a preposition.
rule.example: She explained me the results in detail.
Let me explain you why I like him.

rule.name: depend on
rule.message: The verb 'to depend' requires the preposition '(up)on': \1 on.

rule.message: Did you mean end.

rule.message: The verb 'to graduate' requires the preposition 'from': \2 from.

rule.name: all/most/some (of) + noun
rule.message: Consider using \1 or \1 of the \3.

rule.name: missing verb after 'if there'

rule.name: missing verb (can what / can see what)
rule.message: Please check whether a verb is missing here.

rule.name: objective case after with(out)/at/to/...
rule.message: Did you mean \1 me, \1 her, \1 him, \1 us, or \1 them?

example.correction: to me|to her|to him|to us|to them

rule.example: Give it to I.

example.correction: with me|with her|with him|with us|with them

rule.example: Come with I.
I feel safe with him.
Look at her!

rule.name: possessive case after with(out)/at/in/to/...
rule.message: Did you mean \2 my, \2 her, \2 his, \2 our, or \2 their?

example.correction: at my|at her|at his|at our|at their

rule.example: Look at I eyes!

example.correction: at my|at her|at his|at our|at their

Each of us has to be careful when driving.
Living with him isn't easy.

rule.name: incorrect pronoun as subject ('Her loves me.')
rule.message: Did you mean I, He, She, or They?

rule.name: too ADJECTIVE to

rule.name: base form after I/you/we/they

rule.name: Two modal verbs in a row (will can)

rule.message: The verb '\2' is singular. Did you mean: This or ?

The most common of these is dot 5, which combines with the first letter of words.

rule.message: The verb '\3' is singular. Did you mean: \1 \2 ?

rule.message: Did you mean these?

rule.name: these + singular noun

rule.name: people + 3rd person verb
rule.message: If 'people' is plural here, don't use the third-person singular verb.

rule.name: we + ... + are + base form verb (gerund)

rule.name: personal pronoun + gerund

rule.name: I life (live)
rule.message: Possible agreement error -- use verb form: live.

Troopers are trained to use Type I life jackets on handcuffed subjects.

rule.name: some faculty... (some faculty members...)

rule.name: neither X or Y (neither X nor Y)
rule.message: Use nor with neither.

rule.name: is even worst (worse)
rule.message: Probably incorrect use of superlative '\3'. Consider using the comparative form instead.
rule.example: He was even nicest after a year.
He was even worst.
He was even worse after a year.
He was even best man at my wedding.

rule.message: Unless you have already specified someone or something as the \1 and are comparing the remaining items, 'other' should not be used in combination with a superlative. Please check whether 'other' can be removed.
rule.example: Bill is the tallest of all other boys.
Shakespeare is the greatest writer and of all other writers Hemingway is the greatest.
Bill is taller than any other boy.

rule.message: Unless you have already specified someone or something as the most \3 and are comparing the remaining items, 'other' should not be used in combination with a superlative. Please check whether 'other' can be removed.
rule.example: He is the most important of all other players.
He is more important than any other player.

rule.name: 'some' + sing. noun + verb
rule.message: Did you mean ?

rule.message: Did you mean interested?

rule.message: For negated sentences, use either instead of 'too'.

rule.message: For negated sentences, use either instead of 'too'.

rule.message: For negated sentences, use either instead of 'too'.

rule.message: Did you mean at?

rule.name: essentially

rule.name: to/will before withdrawn

rulegroup.name: 'afford', 'choose', etc. used with base form instead of infinitive

rule.message: This verb is used with the infinitive: to

rule.name: Wrong preposition: 'be fond to' (be fond of)

rule.name: 'will like to' (would like to)

rule.message: Incorrect form of the pronoun 'he'. Use: \1 him.

rule.message: Incorrect form of the pronoun '\2'. Use: \1 her.

rule.name: Articles: 'most/some of' + plural noun

rule.message: In the grammatical structure 'pronoun + be/get + used + to + verb', the verb '\4' is used with the gerund: .

rule.message: “\2” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.
rule.short: Punctuation error, sentence looks like a fragment

After we had dinner.

Even if the dog likes to bark; it's still a nice dog.
That was probably what influenced their decision.

rule.message: “\2 \3” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.
rule.short: Punctuation error, sentence looks like a fragment

rule.message: “\2 \3 \4” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.

rule.message: “\2 \3 \4” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.

rule.message: “\2 \3 \4 \5” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.

rule.message: “\2 \3 \4” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.

rule.message: “\2 \3” at the beginning of a sentence requires a 2nd clause. Maybe a comma, question or exclamation mark is missing, or the sentence is incomplete and should be joined with the following sentence.

Provided that the dog guards my house; I do not mind it barking loudly.

rule.name: wrong preposition: 'exception PREPOSITION the rule' (exception to the rule)

rule.message: Please check whether an article is missing: a \3.

rule.name: wrong preposition: sign into (sign in to)
rule.message: The verb '\1 \2' is not standard English, except in the context of the law ("The bill was signed into law"). Write \1 in to. For websites and computers, other options are log in to or log on to.

rule.name: Articles: unnecessary indefinite article before an uncountable noun
rule.message: The indefinite article might be unnecessary before the uncountable noun: \2.
rule.example: I need a oil for my car.
My car needs an oil.
I need oil for my car.

rule.name: accustomed to

rule.example: He is accustomed of playing football now.
He is accustomed to playing football now.

rule.name: inspired with (by)
rule.message: If '\2 \3' is passive voice, use \2 by.
rule.example: The artist was inspired with the beauty of the mountains.
The artist was (not unsurprisingly, I think) inspired with the beauty of the mountains.
The artist was inspired by the beauty of the mountains.
The book inspired me to write my own novel.
Inspired in class, I decided to write a novel.
This is the book that inspired me to write my own novel.
I was inspired with the desire to write a novel.

rule.name: Missing noun: 'The is the'
rule.message: Please check whether a word is missing between '\1' and '\2' or whether '\1' is the correct determiner.
rule.example: The is the best day of my life.
The are the best.

rule.message: Please check whether an article is missing: \2 a \3 or \2 an \3
rule.example: You are good boy.
It seems to me that Mr Jones is great golfer.
What impresses me the most about China is Chinese food.

rule.name: 'BE I BE GERUND'
rule.message: Possible grammar error. Make sure that '\1 \2 \3 \4' is correct.
rule.example: What was I am doing again?
I don't know was I be going.
... but be I was making my life hard.
What was I doing again?
Was I being stupid?
"Am I being a diva?" she asked.
The thing with me is I am a team player.
The reason I'm in Washington is I was at the Federal Trade Commission earlier today.

rule.name: despite of (despite)
rule.message: Did you mean \1 (or, alternatively, 'in spite of')?
rule.example: He kept running despite of the pain in his chest.
She had difficulty communicating in French despite all her years of study.
She had difficulty communicating in French in spite of all her years of study.

rule.name: Duplicated 'the' surrounding an adverb
rule.message: Duplicated 'the' in the phrase: '\1 \2 \3'. Did you mean \2 \3?
rule.example: That’s the really the point of these songs.
It is the exactly the same thing.
This is the way the music dies.

rule.message: Maybe you need to remove one determiner so that only \1 or \2 is left.
rule.example: The a thing is this.
This is an a flower.
The A Cat Sat On A Mat.

The third letter is the A for Aqua, not Alpha.
In this example, use an A, not a B or a C.

rule.message: Maybe you need to remove the second determiner so that only \1 or \2 is left.
rule.example: I like a this dog.
This is the this idea I was talking about!

rule.message: Maybe you need to remove the second determiner so that only \1 or \2\3 is left.
rule.example: The 'an international movie' is interesting.
The Thames was once a much broader river.

rule.name: The you (you)
rule.message: Possible typo. Did you mean \1 or \2?
rule.example: The cat is on the mat.
Strode past the now frightened man, entered the he house.
It was an impulse when she was here in Me'a She'arim.
