rule.name: an another (an/another)
rule.message: One of these determiners is redundant in this context. Choose only one: or .
rule.example: It's an another lonely night.

rule.name: first come, first serve(d)
rule.message: Did you mean served?
rule.example: First come, first serve.

rule.name: shoe-in (shoo)
rule.message: Did you mean shoo-in.
rule.example: He says some of his supporters thought he was a shoe-in.

rule.name: prostrate (prostate)
rule.message: Did you mean prostate.
rule.example: He was diagnosed with prostrate cancer.

rule.name: worse come to worse (worst)
rule.message: Did you mean worst to indicate that something has degraded from one negative plane to the lowest possible?
rule.example: Worse came to worse.

rule.message: Did you mean worse?
rule.example: The conditions in March were much worst than they imagined to be possible.

rule.name: peak (pique) interest
rule.message: Did you mean .
rule.example: It peaked my interest.

rule.name: knot (not)
rule.message: Did you mean not.
rule.example: She does knot know everything.
Do knot disturb.

rulegroup.name: Repetition of two words ('at the at the')

rule.message: This phrase is duplicated. You should probably leave only \1 \2.
rule.example: Hepatology at the at the turn of centuries.
Again he returned to the study and placed the lamp on the on the table
A handicapped accessible shuttle bus is available from the from the Purdue University parking lot.
All we wanted to do was to stand very quietly and look and look and look.
In an era where bond yields are already as low as low can be, quantitative easing promises to be...
The white spots are saturated -- as white as white can be -- and all the enhancements that everyone is...
What if you're not as good as good should be?
Northern California dispatches from 2015 were as bad as bad could be.
He needed a bell as big as Big Ben.
Very few men were as big as Big Rich.
Entertainment is about to get as real as real life and nothing will ever be the same.
No credit is almost as bad as bad credit.
He accuses the public health lobby of being just as big as big business.

rule.name: according to
rule.message: Did you mean: according to? according to: (as stated/in the opinion of)
rule.example: According about a recent survey, most smokers suffer from cancer.
He was acquitted, because he was innocent according in the Jury.
According to a recent survey, most smokers suffer from cancer.
He was acquitted, because he was innocent according to the Jury.
We breathe life into this prized democratic value by according the Chief Justice due process of law.
'According as' is a conjunction (Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, 10th edition).
'Accord with' is a verb, but it is not usually used in the progressive.
His system had eleven grades, arranged according "to the degree to which they are infected ..."
The manager was according him the greatest of privileges.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: have x years old (be x years old)
rule.message: This phrase is used with 'be': be .
rule.example: I am 25 years old.
He has 25 years old.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'in nowadays' (nowadays)
rule.message: \2 is used without 'in'. Use simply: \2.
rule.example: In nowadays, many organizations are jumping in the social websites bandwagon.
Nowadays, many organizations are jumping in the social websites bandwagon

rule.message: The adjective \1 is normally used with to.
rule.example: He feels inferior than us.

rule.message: The adjective \1 is normally used with to and does not need 'more' (so called implicit comparative). Probably you need to write: \2 to.
rule.example: He feels more inferior than us.
He feels inferior to them.

rule.name: Wrong preposition: 'obvious for' (obvious to)
rule.message: The adjective \1 is normally used with 'to': \1 to \3.
rule.example: It's obvious for me.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'today morning' (this morning)
rule.message: This is a non-standard collocation. Normally, this \2 is used.
rule.example: I'm going home today evening.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'yesterday night' (last night)
rule.message: This is a non-standard collocation. Normally, last night is used.
rule.example: I was there yesterday night.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'today night' (tonight)
rule.message: This is a non-standard collocation. Normally, tonight is used instead.
rule.example: I'm going fishing today night.

rule.name: Wrong collocation: 'worry for' (worry about)
rule.message: The verb 'worry' does not normally take the preposition 'for'. Did you mean \1 about?
rule.example: Don't worry for.
I am worried about her.

rule.name: a sinking (s)hip
rule.message: Did you mean ship?
rule.example: The idiom 'like rats fleeing a sinking hip is used in reference to people abandoning an enterprise once it seems likely to fail.

rule.name: Collocation: apply to/for
rule.message: You can apply to a company or university, but you apply for \4. Revise: \1 for \5.
rule.example: You can apply to welfare.
You can apply to the job online.
You can apply to more assistance.

rule.name: Collocation: apply for/to
rule.message: You can apply for a job or welfare, but you apply to a \4. Revise: \1 to \3 \4.
rule.example: You try and apply for another University!

rule.name: Collocation: Sit in/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for activities with a desk is "at." Try this: \1 \2 at \4 \5.
rule.example: At lunch, I eat with my colleague working or I eat in my desk alone.

rule.name: Collocation: Between ... to/and ...
rule.message: Use "between" + "and" not "to." Try this: \1 \2 and \4.
rule.example: Children between three to five are cute.
...aspen parkland, a biome transitional between prairie to the south and boreal forest to the north.
...causing the electrostatic interactions between them to be strong.

rule.name: Collocation: Well in/on
rule.message: Use "\2 on" with "\4". Try this: \1 \2 on \4.
rule.example: I do badly in tests because I'm lazy.

rule.name: Collocation: Admitted at/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "admit" is "to"," not "at." It is better to say this: \1 to \3 \4.
rule.example: On his way to an interview to be admitted at Princeton College, Quentin and his childhood best friend James arrive on a crime scene where they find the corpse of the man who was supposed to interview the former, along with a very nonchalant paramedic.

rule.name: Collocation: Summon at/to
rule.message: The usual collocation is "summon to" a place, or "summon at" a time/moment. Use "to" instead: \1 to \3 \6.
rule.example: Without him knowing, Quentin was summoned at an examination in order to get his admission to this institution.
Without him knowing, Quentin was summoned at a particular examination in order to get his admission to this institution.

example.correction: summoned to a very particular examination

rule.example: Without him knowing, Quentin was summoned at a very particular examination in order to get his admission to this institution.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the Internet
rule.message: The usual collocation for technology is "on," not "in." It is better to say this: on the \3.
rule.example: Land reclamation is in the internet.

rule.name: Collocation: accompany with/by
rule.message: The usual collocation for "accompany" is "by," not "with." It is better to say this: \1 by.
rule.example: Land reclamation is always accompany with pollution.

rule.name: Collocation: Popular among/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "popular" is "with," not "among." It is better to say this: popular with.
rule.example: John's popular among his friends.

rule.name: Collocation: Play with/for
rule.message: Use "for" with "play." You probably meant this: \1 for.
rule.example: He plays regularly with that team.

rule.name: Collocation: Opposite from/to
rule.message: Use "to" with "opposite." You probably meant this: \1 to \3.
rule.example: Their house is opposite from ours.

rule.name: Collocation: Marry with/to
rule.message: Use "to" with "marry." You probably meant this: \1 to.
rule.example: Angela was married with a rich man.

rule.name: Collocation: Prefer over/to
rule.message: Use "to" with "prefer." You probably meant this: \1 \2 to \4.
rule.example: She much prefers overalls over skirts, because she enjoys playing in the mud

rule.name: Collocation: Talk at/to
rule.message: Talking at someone means they aren't listening. You probably meant this: \1 to \3 or \1 with \3.
rule.example: I was talking at Charles about

rule.name: Collocation: Stress out for/over
rule.message: The usual preposition in this context is "over" or "about." Revise: \1 \2 over \4 or \1 \2 about \4.

example.correction: stressing out over everything|stressing out about everything

rule.example: I have to stop stressing out for everything.

rule.name: Collocation: Tired of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition in this context is "from." Revise: tired from last night.
rule.example: I am always tired of the last night

rule.name: Collocation: Repercussion with/on
rule.message: The usual preposition for "repercussion" is "on" not "with". Revise: \1 on.
rule.example: This action has repercussions with the entire community.

rule.name: Collocation: Look at/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "mirror" is "in" not "at". Revise: \1 in a mirror.
rule.example: I suppose what makes me unusual is the fact that I can put on make up without looking at a mirror.

rule.name: Collocation: Passionate by/about
rule.message: The usual preposition for "passionate" is "about" not "by". Revise: passionate about.
rule.example: I am very passionated by my job.

rule.name: Collocation: passionate by/about (stricter)
rule.message: The usual preposition for "passionate" is "about" not "by". Revise: \1 passionate about or \1 inspired by.
rule.example: I'm really passionate by the chocolate, it's my vocation.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the outside
rule.message: The usual preposition for "outside" is "on" not "in". Revise: on the outside.
rule.example: There are white windows in the outside of the house.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a island
rule.message: The usual preposition for "island" is "on" not "in". Revise: on \2 island.
rule.example: Our house is located in a small island surrounded by ices. There are no other houses around us.

rule.name: Collocation: Crazy on/with
rule.message: The usual preposition for "crazy" is "with" not "on". Revise: crazy with.
rule.example: What makes me crazy on this dwelling is that some time we are higher than the clouds.

rule.name: Collocation: Hide of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "from" not "\2". Revise: \1 from.
rule.example: This is very useful to hide of prying tourists.

rule.name: Collocation: Concentrate with/on
rule.message: The usual preposition for "concentrate" is "on" not "\3". Revise: \2 on \4 \5.
rule.example: I know my life, it's not very interest because I am concentrated with my studies.

rule.name: Collocation: Difference about/between
rule.message: The usual preposition for "difference" is "between" not "about". Revise: difference between.
rule.example: There is not big difference about the week and the weekend to me.

rule.name: Collocation: Important with/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "to" not "with". Revise: \1 to \3.
rule.example: Family who is closest and important with you.

rule.name: Collocation: Consist to/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "of" not "to". Revise: \1 of.
rule.example: There is a program in medicine and this program consists to diagnostic people to know if their body works well.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on birthday
rule.message: The usual preposition for "birthdays" is "on". Revise: on \2 \3.
rule.example: My favorite thing is bag, I love my bag very much because it is a gift from my girl friend in my birthday, it is a red bag, I have kept it for 2 years and forever.

rule.name: Collocation: Participate to/in
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "in" not "to". Revise: \1 in.
rule.example: They participate to many activities, which contains organize laboratory experiments, supervise students research, conducting many lectures and of course, writing textbooks.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in a meeting
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\4 \5" is "in" not "on". Revise: \1 \2 in meeting.
rule.example: I was on a meeting.

rule.name: Collocation: at/in the morning
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3" is "in" not "at". Revise: in the \3.
rule.example: I hardly ever drinks coffee at the morning because this make me crazy.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a team
rule.message: The usual preposition for "team" is "on" not "in". Revise: on \5 \6.
rule.example: I’m the one Frank Catania need in his team.

rule.name: Collocation: addiction to/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for \1 is "to." Did you mean, \1 to \3?
rule.example: I would like to work with people who have an addiction of drugs.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in charge of
rule.message: The usual preposition for \5 is "in." Did you mean, \1 \2 \3 in charge of?

example.correction: is the person in charge of

rule.example: Julie is the person on charge to the security.

rule.name: Collocation: in/at a party
rule.message: Unless you mean "in a political party," the usual preposition for a party is "at." Did you mean, at a party?
rule.example: Later, I started working as a Research Assistant in university projects again, where I met her in a party.

rule.name: Collocation: in (on) university projects
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3...projects" is "on". Did you mean, \3 on \8 projects?

example.correction: working as a Research Assistant on university projects

rule.example: Later, I started working as a Research Assistant in university projects again.

rule.name: Collocation: suffer of/with/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for this expression is "from" or "with." Did you mean \1 from or \1 with?
rule.example: A clinical psychologist deals with people suffering of bipolar disorder.

rule.name: Collocation: talk down about/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for this expression is "to". Did you mean, \1 down to?
rule.example: Don't you ever talk down about my baby boy or Kristy.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the foot
rule.message: The usual preposition for feet is "on". Did you mean, on \5 \6?
rule.example: He is wearing a crocs in my feet.

rule.name: Collocation: at/in the morning
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "in". Revise: in the \3.
rule.example: I like to do soccer on the evening.

rule.name: Collocation: at/over the weekend
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "over" or "during". Revise: over the \3 or during the \3.
rule.example: I like to do soccer on the weekend.

rule.name: Collocation: get a job in/with
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1 \2 \3" is "with" for an organization. Revise: with \5 \6.
rule.example: The text is also a very important things for the people who want to get a job in the SPVM.

rule.name: Collocation: do/play game
rule.message: The usual collocation for an activity that does not end in "-ing" and is something you can win is "play" not "do" or "go." Revise: play \2.
rule.example: I like to do soccer on the weekend.
I like doing soccer on the weekend.

rule.name: Collocation: go/do art
rule.message: The usual collocation for an activity that does not end in "-ing" and is not something you can win is "do" not "go" or "play." Revise: do \2.
rule.example: My sister plays ballet at the community center.

rule.name: Collocation: do/go activity
rule.message: The usual collocation for an activity ending in "-ing" is "go" not "do" or "play." Revise: go \2.
rule.example: Do you do jogging?
He does jogging.
After the squad is done installing the gear.

rule.name: Collocation: damage of/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "damage" is "to" not "of." Revise: \1 to.
rule.example: It may cause damage of wildlife.

rule.name: Collocation: interest about/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "interest" is "in" not "about." Revise: \1 \2 in.
rule.example: They are more interest about the money, like how it's manage.

rule.name: Collocation: vulnerable from/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "vulnerable" is "to" not "from," as in "vulnerable to attack." Revise: vulnerable to.
rule.example: We do want to differ from other solutions where you must redirect all your domain names to a service provider, leaving your server vulnerable from direct attacks and having you hassle with domain records all the time.

rule.name: Collocation: imitation from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for word "imitate" is "of" not "from," as in "imitate the style of someone." Revise: \1 \2 of \5 \6.

example.correction: imitate every habit and behavior of their parents

rule.example: Children imitate every habit and behavior from their parents.

rule.name: Collocation: offered in/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "offered" and "\3" is "at" not "in." Revise: offered at \3.
rule.example: In addition, if people are in favor of women practicing combat sports, it would be beneficial to have combat sport sessions in schools as well as optional courses offered in universities.

rule.name: Collocation: perspectives about/on
rule.message: The usual preposition for "perspectives" is "on" not "about." Revise: perspectives on.
rule.example: They have different perspectives about the topic.

rule.name: Collocation: varieties in/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for "varieties" is "of" not "in." Revise: varieties of.
rule.example: They should increase varieties in food.

rule.name: Collocation: cover by/in
rule.message: The usual preposition for "cover" is "in" not "by." Revise: covered in \3 or covered with \3.
rule.example: The Mountains are covered by snow.

rule.name: Collocation: leave to/for
rule.message: The usual preposition for "leave" is "for" not "to". Revise: leaving for \3 \4.
rule.example: They are leaving to England soon.

rule.name: Collocation: do/have a meeting
rule.message: The usual verb for "a meeting" is "have" not "do." Revise: have a meeting.
rule.example: We decided to do a meeting the next day.
Tom does a meeting the next day.
We decided to did a meeting the next day.

rule.name: Collocation: growled to/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1" is "at." Revise: \1 at \3.
rule.example: Dr. Dre growled to him about the snow.

rule.name: Collocation: to/on a trip
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" and "a trip" is "\2 on a trip". Did you mean \1 on a trip?
rule.example: Yes, I went to a trip.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a trip
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2 \3" is on \2 \3 or during \2 \3.
rule.example: It was is in his trip, that he met her.

rule.name: Collocation: think on/about
rule.message: The usual collocations for "\1" are \1 about or \1 of.
rule.example: I'm thinking in finish this text.

rule.name: Collocation: responsible of/for
rule.message: The usual collocations for "\1" is "\1 for". Did you mean \1 for or in charge of?
rule.example: I am responsable of marketing.

rule.name: Collocation: waiting after (for) someone
rule.message: The usual collocations for "\1" is "\1 on," meaning act as an attendant to someone, or "\1 for" meaning to remain patiently inactive. Did you mean \1 for \3.
rule.example: I am waiting after her.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in a hospital bed
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\5" is "in". Did you mean in a hospital bed.
rule.example: The patient is on a hospital bed waiting for surgery.

rule.name: Collocation: live from/off
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\1" and "\7" is "off". Did you mean \1 off.
rule.example: He lives from his brother’s money.

rule.name: Collocation: anxious of/about
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\1" is "about". Did you mean anxious about.
rule.example: They are anxious for his health.
Parents are anxious for their children’s success.

rule.name: Collocation: be on/in shock
rule.message: The usual preposition with "\3" is "in". Did you mean \1 in shock.
rule.example: We were on shock when it happen..

rule.name: Collocation: far of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "far" is "from." Revise: far from.
rule.example: It is not very far of my job.

rule.name: Collocation: near from/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "near" is "to." Revise: near to.
rule.example: It is not very near from my job.

rule.name: Collocation: blind for/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "blind" is "from" when followed by the cause of the blindness. Revise: \1 from \3 \4.
rule.example: blind for the fury.

rule.name: Collocation: yell on/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "yell" is "at." Revise: \1 at \3.
rule.example: Lily yelled on him.

rule.name: Collocation: takes into consideration (of)
rule.message: You have fused two expressions into one, "in consideration of" and "taking into consideration." Remove the word "of" from the end: \1 \2 \3.
rule.example: Tom takes into consideration of all the perspectives.

rule.name: Collocation: in/from the perspective
rule.message: The usual preposition for "perspective" is "from" not "in." from \2 \3 \4.
rule.example: In the psychological perspective.

rule.name: Collocation: sit on the court/bench
rule.message: The usual way to express a judge's association with a courtroom is with the phrase \1 on the bench.
rule.example: He is 67 year old and he sits on the court since 1998..

rule.name: Collocation: follow/take a course
rule.message: The usual verb for "courses" in a school is "take" or "attend" not "follow." Try it like this: take \2 courses.
rule.example: There is classes were students can follow their courses.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in the afternoon
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3" is 'in' not "on". Try it like this: in \2 \3.
rule.example: The meeting is on the afternoon.

rule.name: Collocation: accuse for/of
rule.message: The usual preposition for accusations is "of" not "for." Try it like this: \1 the \3 of.
rule.example: She accused the man for stealing.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on a secret mission
rule.message: The usual preposition for "a secret mission" is "on" not "in". Try it like this: \1 on \3 \4 \5.
rule.example: Bond is in a secret mission.

rule.name: Collocation: laugh of/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for "laugh" is "at". Did you mean \1 at \3?
rule.example: I laughed of him.

rule.name: Collocation: bring at/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "bring" is "to". Did you mean \1 \2 to?
rule.example: Bring Suzanne at the party.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in fact
rule.message: The usual preposition for "fact" is "in". Did you mean In fact?
rule.example: On fact, the people are fed up of so many elections.

rule.name: Collocation: bring to/put on the agenda
rule.message: The usual verb + preposition for "agenda" is "put on". Did you mean put on the agenda?
rule.example: We must bring to the agenda the people that are fed up of so many elections.

rule.name: Collocation: in front of
rule.message: The usual preposition for "in front" is "of". Did you mean in front of?
rule.example: In front to so many decisions, the people are fed up.

rule.name: Collocation: departure of/from
rule.message: The usual preposition for "departure" with a destination name is "from". Did you mean departure from?
rule.example: The stay is finally ended and they prepared their departure of New York.

rule.name: Collocation: live in/on planet
rule.message: The usual preposition for \4 is "on". Did you mean \1 on \4?
rule.example: Not all creatures that live in the planet Earth use oxygen.

rule.name: Collocation: countless of
rule.message: Do not use "of" after "\1". Did you mean \1 \3?
rule.example: There are countless of occurrences.

rule.name: Collocation: fed up of/with
rule.message: The usual preposition for "\1 \2" is "with". Did you mean \1 \2 with?
rule.example: The people are fed up of so many pointless elections.

rule.name: Collocation: enter in
rule.message: There isn't usually a preposition after "\1". Did you mean \1 \3 \4.
rule.example: While he was entering in the room, he felt an uncomfortable feeling on his spine.
The record is entered in a book.

rule.name: Collocation: go to home (go home)
rule.message: There isn't usually a preposition before "\3". Did you mean \1 \3.
rule.example: Suzie went to home.
Carry went to home base.

rule.name: Collocation: came in/into
rule.message: The usual proposition after "\2" is "into" not "\3". The sentence "\1 \2 \3 \4 \5" is a colloquial expression for "\1 had an orgasm in the \5". Did you mean \1 \2 into \4 \5, meaning "\1 arrived"?
rule.example: Judy came in the house after greeting her elders.

rule.name: Collocation: arrive on/at the beach
rule.message: The usual proposition after "\1" is "at" not "\2". Did you mean \1 at.
rule.example: When John arrived on the beach, he went for a swim.

rule.name: Collocation: return at home
rule.message: You do not need a preposition between "\1" and "\3". Did you mean \1 \3.
rule.example: Return at home before midnight.

rule.name: Collocation: be in/under pressure
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "under" not "\2". Did you mean under pressure.
rule.example: Kelly is in pressure.

rule.name: Collocation: absorb at/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Did you mean \1 in.
rule.example: I am absorbed at this book.

rule.name: Collocation: accuse for/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: He is accused for fraud.

rule.name: Collocation: ashamed from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: After flunking in the exam, she felt ashamed from it.

rule.name: Collocation: arrive at/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Use "in" for geographical regions and "at" for a specific point. For a town, province, state, country or continent, use "in". For a restaurant, business, park or car, use "at". Did you mean \1 in or '\1 at'.
rule.example: They will arrive at the city at 9:00 am.

rule.name: Collocation: angry with/about
rule.message: Use "angry with" for people. Use "angry about" for situations or weather. Did you mean \1 about the \4.
rule.example: Barbie is angry with the situation.

rule.name: Collocation: accustom with/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "\2". Did you mean \1 to.
rule.example: The mechanic is accustomed with handling those situations.

rule.name: Collocation: afraid from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Rats are afraid from cats.

rule.name: Collocation: angry against/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "with" or "at" not "\2". Did you mean \1 with or \1 at.
rule.example: Birds fly when they are angry against pigs.

rule.name: Collocation: aim on/at
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "at" not "\2". Did you mean \1 at.
rule.example: This tool is aimed on regular users.

rule.name: Collocation: believe to/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Did you mean \1 in.
rule.example: 'cause I believe to fitness.

rule.name: Collocation: boast for/about/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" or "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of or \1 about.
rule.example: He boasted for his skills.

rule.name: Collocation: careful for/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "with" not "\2". Did you mean \1 with.
rule.example: Be careful for the camera.

rule.name: Collocation: travel with/by
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "by" not "\2". Did you mean \1 by \4.
rule.example: We are going to travel with a bus.

rule.name: Collocation: complain for/about
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 about.
rule.example: The client complained for the service.

rule.name: Collocation: compose from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: It is composed from carbohydrates and proteins.

rule.name: Collocation: cure from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: This medicine will cure you from the disease.

rule.name: Collocation: deprive from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: This soil is deprived from nutrients.

rule.name: Collocation: die from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: The ferns are dying from too much watering.

rule.name: Collocation: disappoint from/with
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "with" or "in" or "by" or "at" or "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 with or \1 in or \1 by or \1 at or \1 about.

example.correction: disappointed with|disappointed in|disappointed by|disappointed at|disappointed about

rule.example: She was disappointed from the surprise.

rule.name: Collocation: divide in/into
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "into" not "\4". Did you mean \1 \2 \3 into.
rule.example: Divide the pizza in four.

rule.name: Collocation: doubt for/in/about
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" or "about" not "\3". Did you mean \1 in or \1 about.
rule.example: I doubt for that.

rule.name: Collocation: dress with/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "in" not "\3". Did you mean \1 \2 in.
rule.example: Jane dresses with a coverall.

rule.name: Collocation: full with/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: The washing machine is full with dishes.

rule.name: Collocation: rid from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: He got rid from the clutter.

rule.name: Collocation: glad with/about
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "about" not "\2". Did you mean \1 about.
rule.example: He's glad with it.

rule.name: Collocation: guard from/against
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "against" not "\2". Did you mean \1 against.
rule.example: The dog guards from the thieves.

rule.name: Collocation: guilty for/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Mark is guilty for laziness.
...the court enters a plea of not guilty for a defendant who refuses to enter a plea.

rule.name: Collocation: independently from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Independently from our relationship, you are not the best, nor most the brightest.

rule.name: Collocation: insist on + gerund
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "on" not "\2". Did you mean \1 on ?
rule.example: She insisted to attend the conference.

rule.name: Collocation: interest for/in
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "in" not "\2". Did you mean \1 in.
rule.example: I have an interest for the sea.

rule.name: Collocation: jealous from/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of.
rule.example: Jane might be jealous from my car.

rule.name: Collocation: photo with/of + POSSESSIVE PRONOUN + NOUN
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "of" not "\3". Did you mean \2 of \4 \5.
rule.example: This is a photo with his cat.

rule.name: Collocation: in/at this moment
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2 \3" is "at" not "\1". Did you mean At \2 \3.
rule.example: In this moment she woke up.

rule.name: Collocation: tired about/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "of" or "from" not "\2". Did you mean tired of or tired from.
rule.example: tired about.

rule.name: Collocation: advertisement of/for
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "for" not "\2". Did you mean advertisement for.
rule.example: Nice advertisement of your company.

rule.name: Collocation: stop him of/from
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1 \2" is "from" not "of". Did you mean stop \2 from \4.
rule.example: This stops us of achieving victory.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on an album
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "on" not "in" when album refers to a collection of recorded music. If by "album" you mean a collection of photos, "in an album" is correct. Did you mean on \2 \3.
rule.example: Listen to that in the album.

rule.name: Collocation: cure against/for
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "for" not "against". Did you mean \1 for.
rule.example: Researcher have found the cure against that type of cancer.

rule.name: Collocation: to found/find a cure
rule.message: The verb "to found" means "to establish," but "to find" means "to discover." Did you mean to find \3 \4.
rule.example: It took a while to found a cure for malaria.

rule.name: Collocation: desire on/for
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "for" not "\4". Did you mean \3 for \5 \6?
rule.example: Even though some businessmen prefer unusual approaches to boost up their business identification, they get interested to identify the best approach to realize their desires on the business development.

rule.name: bring SOMEBODY in/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "\3" with. Did you mean \1 \2 to \4 \5.
rule.example: Friday came fast and the couple quitted their sweet house for took the bus who will brought them in the airport.

rule.name: curator on/of
rule.message: The usual collocation for "curator" is "of" not "\2". Did you mean \1 of \3 \4.
rule.example: The man to whom you were speaking to was the curator on the exposition.

rule.name: closer from/to
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "from". Did you mean simply \1 to or further from.
rule.example: I moved in July to be closer from school.

rule.name: article + possessive form
rule.message: A determiner cannot combine with a possessive pronoun. Did you mean simply \2 \3 or \1 \3.
rule.example: The my car is on the maintenance services.

rule.name: I enrolled international school
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "in" (a school) or "for" (a course). Did you mean \1 \2 in or \1 \2 for.
rule.example: He enrolled at the college.

rule.name: steps to do/take
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "take". Did you mean \1 \2 take.
rule.example: There are some steps to do.

rule.name: going on vacation
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" is "on." Did you mean \1 on \3.
rule.example: She is going to vacation.

rule.name: I came by plane
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "on". Did you mean on \2.
rule.example: Check it in Wikipedia.

rule.name: Write on my page
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "on". Did you mean \1 on .
rule.example: That is written in page 21.
That is written in my own page.

example.correction: Write that on my own page

rule.example: Write that in my own page.

example.correction: Write that piece on my own page

rule.example: Write that piece in my own page.

rule.name: came to/by
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "by." Did you mean \1 \2 by \4.
rule.example: I came to plane.

rule.name: work (for) is
rule.message: You are missing the word 'for' between "\5" and '\6'. Did you mean \1 \2 that \4 \5 for \6.

example.correction: The company that I work for is

rule.example: The company that I work is Cosme Inc...

rule.name: waiting (for) a patient
rule.message: You are missing the word 'for' between "\1" and "\1 \2". Did you mean \1 for \2 \3.
rule.example: Anne is waiting her patient.

rule.name: travel (for) X days
rule.message: You are missing the word "for" between "\2" and "\3". Did you mean \1 traveled for \3 \4.
rule.example: I traveled four days.

rule.name: Respectful against/toward
rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is 'toward' but never 'toward'. Did you mean \1 toward.
rule.example: Respectful against.

rule.name: Disappointed with, at, or by
rule.message: The usual collocation for 'disappointed' is 'with', 'at', of 'by, but never "of". Did you mean \1 with.
rule.example: We could be disappointed of this announcement.

rule.name: account (for)
rule.message: You seem to be missing a word. Usually the verb "account" is followed by "for". Did you mean \1 \2 for.
rule.example: That accounts a rise in price.
The use of symbolism is an important writing technique that accounts a crucial contribution on the novel.

rule.name: contribution on/to
rule.message: The usual preposition for "contribution" is "to". Did you mean \1 to.
rule.example: The use of symbolism is an important writing technique that accounts a crucial contribution on the novel.
Make a code contribution on LanguageTool.

rule.name: Collocation: arrived (in the) dowtown
rule.message: Did you mean simply \1 \4? You do not need the word 'in' here.
rule.example: Arrive in the downtown.

rule.name: Collocation: consider (about)
rule.message: Did you mean simply \1 \3? You do not need the word "about" here.
rule.example: Please, consider about this.

rule.name: Collocation: associates to/with
rule.message: Did you mean \1 \2 \3 with? The usual preposition for the word 'associate' is 'with' not 'to'.
rule.example: She associates her layoff to your arrival.

rule.name: named it (as)
rule.message: Did you mean simply named \2 \4? You do not need the word 'as' here.
rule.example: They named it as Gilead.

rule.name: Collocation: lot (of)
rule.message: If you mean a great quantity, use \1 \2 of \3?
rule.example: A lot people were late.
...my credit card and ran up a lot of charges." It's a lot harder to get them to buy into "Someone stole my magic s...
We walked a lot.

rule.name: Collocation: interested by/in
rule.message: In English, people don't say "\1 by'. They say, "\1 in'. Did you mean \1 in?
rule.example: I am not interested by this job.

rule.name: Collocation: at/on the job
rule.message: In English, people don't say "\1 \2 \3". They say, 'on \2 \3' or 'at work'. Did you mean on the job or at work?
rule.example: He does personal stuff at the job.

rule.name: Collocation: analysis about/of
rule.message: In English, people don't say 'analysis about'. They say, 'analysis of'. Did you mean analysis of?
rule.example: Read the analysis about the results.

rule.name: Collocation: it is sure/certain
rule.message: In English, people don't say 'it is sure'. They say, 'it is certain that'. Did you mean it is certain?
rule.example: It is sure that my English will improve.

rule.name: Collocation: spend it for/on
rule.message: The usual prepositions that follow 'spend it' are either "on" or 'in'. Did you mean spend it on?
rule.example: I spend it for my essence.

rule.name: Translation errors: by/for example
rule.message: The best translation for the introductory phrase "\1 \2" is 'for example'. Did you mean For example?
rule.example: By example, poor spelling makes pattern matching more difficult.

rule.name: Translation error: a gesture of greeting
rule.message: This is awkward. Did you mean waved at me?
rule.example: She made me a gesture of greeting.

rule.name: Collocation: we call/you would call
rule.message: This is awkward. Did you mean \2 \3 you would call?
rule.example: I'm not what we call perfectly bilingual.

rule.name: Collocation: consequences on/for/of
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use after "\2" is "of" or 'for' not "\3". Did you mean \2 of or \2 for?
rule.example: The new labour laws will have consequences on employees.
Think about the consequence 'of' inflation 'for' the economy.
Mayr claimed that there was "nothing of any real consequence in biology after Lucretius and Galen until the Renaissance.

rule.name: Collocation: ask (to)
rule.message: This is a collocation error. You do not need a preposition after "\1'. Remove it: \1.
rule.example: Ask to all the employees.
I was asked to put away all the papers we used at the meeting.
The reason I'm here is because I was asked to come.

rule.name: Collocation: at/in the room
rule.message: This is a collocation error. Use "in" for rooms. Revise: in \3 \4.
rule.example: The plant is at the kitchen.

rule.name: Collocation: invoice of/for
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use after "\1 \2" is "for" not "of". Did you mean \1 \2 for?
rule.example: We booked for 8 tickets but we only received an invoice of 7 tickets.
The supplier has not yet issued invoices of Ms Tuyen to us.

rule.name: Collocation: in charge of/for
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use after "\1 \2" is "for" not "of". Did you mean \1 \2 for?
rule.example: Wood in exchange of metal.

rule.name: Collocation: fill of/with
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use after "\1" is 'with' not "\2" Did you mean \1 \2 \3 with?
rule.example: Fill the page of numbers.

rule.name: Collocation: located on (at) Main street
rule.message: The usual preposition for an exact address is "at" not "on". Did you mean located at \3 ?
rule.example: The company's name is Denver Inc. and it's located on 11056 Main street.
The company's name is Denver Inc. and it's located in 11056 Great Suffolk St.
The company's name is Denver Inc. and it's located on 11056 Henri-Bourassa street.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in the middle
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use when surrounded is "in" not "on". Did you mean in \2 \3?
rule.example: The button is on the middle of the screen.

rule.name: Collocation: on/in the corner
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use with a corner "in" not "on". Did you mean in \2 \3 \4 corner?
rule.example: The button is on the top left corner of the screen.

rule.name: Collocation: similar/like as/to
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use with "similar" is "to" not "as". Did you mean \1 to \3 \4?

example.correction: similar to a church|like a church

rule.example: the roof will be similar as a church.

rule.name: Collocation: kind with/to
rule.message: The usual preposition to use with "\1" is "to." Did you mean \1 to?
rule.example: All the people he met were very kind with him.

rule.name: Collocation: come in/into
rule.message: The words "come in" and "come to" have different meanings. "Come in \3 office" means "have an orgasm in \3 office." "Come to" or "Come into" means "enter." Did you mean come to or come into?
rule.example: Finally, the boss called us all to come in her giant office for a meeting.

rule.name: Collocation: motivation in/to
rule.message: Do not use "motivation in \3." Use a "to" + infinitive form instead. Did you mean motivation to \3?
rule.example: It is very important for them because motivation in study is the best ways for them to get good mark and high spirit in study process.

rule.name: Collocation: in/on the right hand side
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use when in contact with the side is "on" not "in". Did you mean on \2 \5?
rule.example: The button is in the left hand side of the screen.

rule.name: Collocation: in/at the top
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use with bottom or top is "at" not "in". Did you mean at \2 \3?
rule.example: The button is in the top of the screen.

rule.name: Collocation: lunch to/for
rule.message: The usual prepositions to use when you do something for the benefit of another person is "for". Did you mean \1 \2 for \4 \5?
rule.example: The lunch to the guests is ready.

rule.name: Collocation: difficult to/for
rule.message: The usual preposition to follow "difficult" is 'for" when followed by a pronoun. "Difficult" and "to" only appear together when "to" forms part of an infinitive structure. Did you mean \1 for \3?
rule.example: Studying grammar is difficult to me.

rule.name: Collocation: a diversity of colours OR diverse colours
rule.message: You are missing the word "of" between "\2" and "\3". Did you mean \2 of \3 or diverse \3.
rule.example: The diversity nature of this work is appealing to many.

rule.name: Collocation: waiting (to) finish
rule.message: You are missing the word "to" before the infinitive form "\4". Did you mean \1 \2 \3 to \4.
rule.example: I am waiting my patient finish the sample collection.

rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "\2" with. Did you mean \1 to?
rule.example: While we were returning in the office, I have been arrested for speeding.

rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" is "to" not "\2" with. Did you mean \1 to.
rule.example: While we were returning in Montreal, I have been arrested for speeding.

rule.message: In English, the normal collocation for "party" is "have" or "throw". Revise your sentence: to throw a party or to have a party.

example.correction: to throw a party|to have a party

rule.example: A new roommate has moved in, so we decided to do a party with all of us..

rule.message: In English, the normal collocation for "party" is "have" or "throw". Revise your sentence: \1 throwing a party or \1 partying.
rule.example: I like making a party.

rule.message: The usual collocation for "in charge" is "of" not "for". Did you mean in charge of.
rule.example: Who is in charge for this shop?

rule.message: The usual collocation for "\2" is "with" not "\3". Did you mean \2 with.
rule.example: charge for.
Brevity is essential because you will be charged for every word.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "the weekend" is "on." Revise: on the weekend for American English, or at the weekend for British English.
rule.example: During the week, I go to school and I work in a pet shop during the weekend.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "the weekend" is "on." Revise: on the weekend for American English, or at the weekend for British English.
rule.example: During the week, I go to school and I work in a pet shop during the week end.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "weekends" is "on." Revise: on weekends for American English, or at the weekend for British English.
rule.example: I only speak English on weekends because during weekends I work and some clients that only speak in English.
During the week, I go to school and I work in a pet shop during the weekends.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "a \2" with a named destination is "to". Did you mean a trip to?
rule.example: John and Jenny week decided to go on a trip in New York.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "a \2" with a named destination is "to". Did you mean a trip to?
rule.example: John and Jenny week decided to go on a trip in York.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "a \2" with a named destination is "to". Did you mean a trip to?
rule.example: John and Jenny week decided to go on a trip in New-York.

rule.message: The usual verb for "\3" is "watch". Did you mean watch \3?
rule.example: During my free time, I like listen to movies in cinema with my boyfriend and my friends.

rule.message: The usual verb for "\3" is "watch". Did you mean watch a \4?
rule.example: During my free time, I like listen to movie with my boyfriend and my friends.
During my free time, I like listen to a movie in cinema with my boyfriend and my friends.
During the week, I listen series or action movie in English because I want to improve myself with my sister.

rule.message: The usual verb for "\3" is "watch". Did you mean watch an \4 \5?
rule.example: During the week, I listen to action movie in English because I want to improve myself with my sister.

rule.message: The usual preposition for team membership is "on" not "in". Try it like this: on \2 \3's \6.
rule.example: in the men's team.

rule.message: The usual preposition for team membership is "on" not "in". Try it like this: on \2 \3's \6 \7.
rule.example: in the men's basketball team.

rule.message: The usual preposition for team membership is "on" not "in". Try it like this: on \2 \3's \6 \7 \8.

example.correction: on the men's basket ball team

rule.example: in the men's basket ball team.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3 \4" is "in" not "to." Try it like this: \1 in the \4.
rule.example: Their arrival to the city will be at one o'clock.

rule.message: The usual preposition for "\3 \4" is "at" not "to." Try it like this: \1 at the \4.
rule.example: At that time, their arrival to the house was a surprise.

rule.message: The usual preposition for mode of transportation is "by" not "in". Try it like this: \1 by \3.
rule.example: She comes in car.

rule.message: The usual preposition for mode of transportation is "by" not "in". Try it like this: \1 \2 \3 by \5.
rule.example: She comes to work in car.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in world geography.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in social studies.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in physical education.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in language arts.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in home economics.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3 \4.
rule.example: I'm good in computer science.

rule.message: Use "good at" to mean "skilled" with school subjects. Try this: \1 at \3.
rule.example: I'm good in math. I was good in running errands.

rule.name: Collocation: good in/at
rule.message: The usual preposition for this expression is "at". Did you mean, \1 at \3?
rule.example: He is good in swimming.

rule.message: The usual collocation for "\1" in this context is "to" not "\2". Did you mean \1 to.
rule.example: This is an exception of the guidelines.

rule.message: The usual collocation for "\3" in this context is "for" not "\4". Did you mean \1 \2 \3 for.
rule.example: I'll make an exception to you.

rule.message: When a person is directly addressed, a comma should set off the name: \2, \3?
rule.example: Please Tom, let us go.

rule.message: When a person is directly addressed, a comma should set off the name: \1 \2, \3?
rule.example: Thank you Tom, for helping us.

rule.message: When a person is directly addressed, a comma should set off the name: \2, \3?
rule.example: Tom thank you!

rule.message: The comma is probably missing here: , .
rule.example: For years I have been travelling.
At least they believed me.
To see you is always a great pleasure.

rule.message: Interjections are usually punctuated.
rule.example: Oh horrid examples...

rule.message: Interjections are usually punctuated.
rule.example: Oh John what a horrid example...
Oh! Horrid examples...

rule.name: Comma after a month
rule.message: When specifying a month and year, the comma is unnecessary: .
rule.example: The store closed its doors for good in October, 1958.

rule.name: Missing comma between day of month and year
rule.message: Commas set off the year in a month-day-year date: \1 \2,.
rule.example: My birthday is October 18 1983.
He died on April 1, 1888.

rule.message: The comma is probably incorrect:
rule.example: My aunt, and I like skiing.
The dog, and the cat hate each other.

rule.name: Missing comma after weekday
rule.message: Commas set off the month in a weekday-month-day date: \1,.
rule.example: We will meet Friday July 15.
He was born on Friday, August 12, 2016.

rule.name: Loose punctuation mark
rule.message: Loose punctuation mark.
rule.example: ; How's it goin'?

rule.name: for heaven's sake
rule.message: Did you mean \1 ’s sake or \1 \2’ sake?
rule.example: For heavens sake!
For goodness sake!
For Christ’s sake!
For pity’s sake!

rule.message: A comma should precede the tag question (i.e., the yes/no-question at the end).
rule.example: She isn't coming is she?
He didn't know you did he?
She was reading a book wasn't she?
Ann and Tim will come won't they?
She has already left hasn't she?
You can drive can't you?
Do you know how to do it?
What floor is it?
How would I do it?
Did she tell you why she did it?
Can anybody do it?
Are you sure Tom didn't do it?
Do you know where Tom is or don't you?
Why can't they do it?
If you could do it, would you do it?
Excuse me, how much is it?
So this will do it?

rule.message: Use a comma before '\2' if it connects two independent clauses (unless they are closely connected and short).
rule.example: She really purchased the car but she declined the extended warranty.
I love Tim and he loves me.
No one is obliged to do more than what he or she can.
Either you or he is wrong.
I thought you and he were happy.
Tom couldn't find anybody to go with him, and so he went by himself.
Just so we're clear, that was Tom's idea, not mine.
Either they are not happy together or there is another problem.

rule.message: Use a comma before '\2' if it connects two independent clauses (unless they are closely connected and short).
rule.example: Bill didn't work hard enough and so he failed.

rule.message: Use a comma before '\2' if it connects two independent clauses (unless they are closely connected and short).
rule.example: I need to borrow some money so I can buy some medicine for Tom.
I want a wife and children, and so I need a house.

rule.message: Use a comma before '\2' if it connects two independent clauses (unless they are closely connected and short).
rule.example: My friends are in Washington but I am in Seattle.

rule.name: extraneous apostrophes before 'are'
rule.message: Did you mean the plural instead of the possessive?
rule.example: The car's are cheap.

rule.name: state of the art (state-of-the-art)
rule.message: Did you mean state-of-the-art?
rule.example: We present our state of the art solution.
We compare our results to the state of the art.

rule.name: out of place (out-of-place) etc.
rule.message: Did you mean out-of-\3?
rule.example: This word is out of place.
This is an out of place word.

rule.name: out of the way (out-of-the-way) etc.
rule.message: Did you mean out-of-the-way?
rule.example: They seem to be having five hindrances out of the way.
An out of the way place.

rule.message: The comma is missing here:e.g.,.
rule.example: There are several grammar checkers for English, e.g., LanguageTool.
There are several grammar checkers for English, e.g. LanguageTool.

rule.message: A comma and a dot are missing here: e.g.,.

rule.message: A comma and a dot are missing here: e.g.,.

rule.message: The comma is missing here: i.e.,.

rule.message: The comma and dots are missing here: i.e.,.

rule.message: When a number forms part of an adjectival compound, use hyphens: \2-\3-\4
rule.example: Rudolph is a two year old reindeer.
Rudolph is two years old.

rule.message: When a number forms part of an adjectival compound, use a hyphen: \2-\3
rule.example: Rudolph is a two-year old reindeer.
Rudolph is two years old.

rule.message: When a number forms part of an adjectival compound, use a hyphen: \3-\4
rule.example: France has a 35 hour working week.
He won the 100 metre sprint.
Lara handed me a 15 foot pole.
An eighteen inch monitor is too big for my desk.

rule.message: Did you mean the adjective \1-hand?

His left hand felt numb.
You'll see the bank on the left hand side of the hospital.

rule.message: Did you mean the adjective \1-speaking?
rule.example: This is all about English speaking people.
This is all about English-speaking people.

There is an old joke about the English speaking loudly to foreigners.
When I hear an Italian speaking, I remember the wonderful holidays in Italy.

We're lost again! Aren't they english speaking people from our hotel? Ask them for directions.

rule.name: Missing hyphen: face first (face-first)
rule.message: Did you mean the adverb \1-\2?

rule.message: Consider using an m-dash in dialogues and enumerations.
rule.example: - What is that, mother?
« - What is that, mother?
— It's your birthday present, my daughter.

rule.message: Consider using an m-dash if you do not want to join two words.
rule.example: In these educational establishments there were enrollments - mostly from elementary school — and a total of teachers.
Institute Ricci de Macau - Association of cultural promotion of the Company of Jesus in Macau
In the Midwest and Northwest portion are higher elevations, reaching 500 meters above sea level, highlighting Serra do Tumucumaque and Sierra Lombarda.

rule.message: Consider using an n-dash (half dash), if you want to indicate numerical ranges or time ranges.
rule.example: Vitorino Nemésio (1901 - 1978) — writer and university teacher.

rule.message: If this is a parenthetical clause, finish it with an m-dash.
rule.example: …— as aforementioned -,…
A better or more prestigious quality or status: A-, A or A+
Sometimes the syndrome is divided into low-, medium- or high-functioning autism
--------, Schopenhauer, The Human Character.

rule.name: Enumerations with dashes: 1.2.-
rule.message: Dashes are unnecessary in enumerations.

rule.name: no comma before indirect question
rule.message: If \4 starts an indirect question, you do not need to put a comma before it.
