rule.name: stripped (striped)
rule.message: Did you mean striped (= having stripes)?
rule.example: Did you see her stripped dress?

rule.name: striped (stripped)
rule.message: Did you mean stripped (= without clothes / deprived of)?
rule.example: He striped naked for a swim.
He was striped of all his powers.

rule.name: calender (calendar)
rule.message: Did you mean calendar, a system of organizing days? A 'calender' is a machine.
rule.example: A calender is a system of organizing days for social, religious, commercial or administrative purposes.

rule.name: on behave (on behalf)
rule.message: Did you mean on behalf (in the name of, as a representative of)?
rule.example: They act on behave of a user.

rule.name: witch (which) is wrong
rule.message: Did you mean which?
rule.example: Which position is right and witch is wrong?

rule.name: where (were)
rule.message: Did you mean were, the simple past of "to be"?
rule.example: It seems unlikely that they where going to achieve it.
There where major delays because of weather.
And it was from there where I drove back to camp.
Yet, are we there where our founding fathers wanted us to be?
There were public showers there where homeless people could get cleaned up.
Montreal is just happy to be there where losing is no option.
Take me there where the sky is shimmering of a flourishing shuffling.
Tell me why, I can't be there where you are...
And how many other businesses are there where the retailer has no control over price?
There was a long time there where my feelings for him was hella twisted.
Additionally, there was a couple there where a woman had her entire arm adorned with a huge elaborate tattoo.

rule.message: Did you mean altar?
rule.example: He was an alter boy.

rule.message: Did you mean altar (= table used as a center of worship) instead of the verb 'alter' (= modify)?
rule.example: He was at the alter.
He danced around the alter.
O Come to the alter

rule.message: Did you mean alter (=change)?
rule.example: Forty-seven percent of executives said they were concerned that retiring Boomers will significantly altar the workforce in the next decade.
He will radically alter his work.

rule.message: Did you mean averse (=unwilling) instead of 'adverse' (=hostile)?
rule.example: Are you adverse to eating horse meat?

rule.message: Did you mean descent?
rule.example: He is of Asian decent.
He is of Asian descent

rule.message: Did you mean decent?
rule.example: Looking for a hotel with descent rooms.

rule.name: diffuse (defuse) tensions
rule.message: Did you mean defuse, as in removing the fuse from a bomb? "Diffuse" as a verb means to spread out.
rule.example: They gathered at her police precinct to thank officers for their work and to diffuse tensions.

rule.name: diffuse (defuse) bomb
rule.message: Did you mean defuse (=removing the fuse from a bomb)? "Diffuse" as a verb means to spread out.
rule.example: How long did it take you to diffuse the bomb?
He diffused several bombs today.

rule.name: counsel (consul) general
rule.message: Did you mean consul \2?
rule.example: Archer Blood, the counsel general in Dacca.
The Counsel General for Wales is the Welsh Government’s Law Officer.

rule.name: wildly (widely) accepted
rule.message: Did you mean widely?
rule.example: This idea is now wildly accepted.

rule.name: a through(thorough) discussion etc.
rule.message: Did you mean thorough (accurate, exhaustive)?
rule.example: The manual does not have a through discussion of the topic.

rule.name: I was wandering (wondering) if
rule.message: Did you mean wondering?
rule.example: I was wandering if someone could help me.

rule.name: knew (new)
rule.message: Did you mean new?
rule.example: The artistic community knew his name.
If I only knew how.
This is very knew to me.

rule.message: Did you mean (reward)?
rule.example: She won a price.

rule.message: Did you mean (reward)?
rule.example: That is the consolation price.
These are the consolation prices.

rule.message: Did you mean Nobel Prize (reward)?
rule.example: That is the Nobel Price.

rule.message: Did you mean price (cost)?
rule.example: This is called prize spiral.

rule.message: Did you mean watching?
rule.example: I am looking TV.

rule.message: Did you mean watches?
rule.example: She looks TV every morning.

rule.message: Did you mean watch?
rule.example: I look TV every morning.

rule.message: Did you mean watched?
rule.example: I looked TV in the morning.
She looked poker on television.

rule.message: Did you mean side?
rule.example: On the positive site, there are some improvements.

rule.message: Did you mean site?
rule.example: There is a construction side.

rule.name: believe (belief)
rule.message: Did you mean (noun) instead of (verb)?
rule.example: We believe that this is wrong.
an atheist believe
It is my strong believe that something has to be changed.
Mr. Kennedy, Mr. White believes, had mastered politics on so many different levels that no other American could match him.
It is the believe of the people.
Are there different believes?
Some believe the public should have the freedom.
We all believe that it's true.
My sister believes that I'll end up with someone really generic.

rule.name: belief (believe)
rule.message: Did you mean (verb) instead of (noun)?
rule.example: But Baptist beliefs can vary.
We belief that this is wrong.
He beliefs that this is wrong.
Joan of Arc refused to renounce her belief that the voice she heard was from God.

rule.message: Did you mean course?
rule.example: A coarse after action
To coarse after hares

rule.message: Did you mean course?
rule.example: In the syllabus for an Applied Mathematics coarse, students are told to write their problem sets individually.

rule.message: Did you mean proof of concept?
rule.example: It's just a prove of concept.

rule.message: Did you mean (noun) instead of (verb)?
rule.example: Their prove is wrong.

rule.message: Did you mean it?
rule.example: Being vegan easier than it's seems, experts say.

rule.message: Did you mean seems?
rule.example: Being vegan easier than it seams, experts say.

rule.name: ease off (of) use
rule.message: Did you mean of?
rule.example: Increase ease off use.

rule.name: ease (easy)
rule.message: Did you mean easy?
rule.example: This looks pretty ease to me.

rule.name: admin (admit)
rule.message: Did you mean admit (=confess)?
rule.example: I must admin that my code is not perfect.

rule.message: Did you mean at?
rule.example: No, not ad all.

rule.message: Did you mean at?
rule.example: This is not true ad all.

rule.name: take case (care) of it
rule.message: Did you mean care?
rule.example: We're taking care of it.
We need to take case of it.
We took case of it.

rule.name: I wander (wonder) if
rule.message: Did you mean wonder?
rule.example: I wander if I'm studying enough?

rule.name: worth (worse) than
rule.message: Did you mean worse, the comparative of 'bad'?
rule.example: Zynga estimated to be more worth than EA.
Is cloud hosting worth than hostgator?

rule.name: not jet (yet)
rule.message: Did you mean yet?
rule.example: That is not jet decided.

rule.name: your (you're)
rule.message: Did you mean your?
rule.example: You're still working on it?
You're right!
Let me know what you're up to.
If you're drunk don't take the wheel of a car.
You're old enough to know better.
You're forever making mistakes.
You're in perky form, aren't you?
You're man enough to let her play, she's experimental and confident enough to do it.
You're optimization is a good example.
You're Arthur Willis.
You're kind of amazed.
You're in better shape than I am.

rule.name: you're (your)
rule.message: Did you mean your?
rule.example: There are a number of things you can do to reduce the risk to you’re pet.
You should read a lot of books while you're young.

rule.message: Are you writing a letter? Did you mean Dear?
rule.example: Deer Anne,...
Deer Dr. Snyder:

rule.message: Did you mean accept?
rule.example: Please except my apologies.

rule.message: Did you mean except?
rule.example: Police found the culprits (accept one).

rule.message: Did you mean except?
rule.example: This is done accept for that fact that we still have JBossws 2.0.0 binaries.
This is done except for the fact that we still have JBossws 2.0.0 binaries.

rule.message: Did you mean effect?
rule.example: The primary affect on property values.
The primary effect on property values.

rule.message: Did you mean effect?
rule.example: We tried appeasing the rain gods, but to no affect.

rule.message: Did you mean effect (=influence)?
rule.example: Regional factors have an affect on hotel guest satisfaction.

rule.message: Did you mean in effect (in substance, virtually)?
rule.example: Parking Fees are in affect in this park.
Parking Fees are in effect in this park

rule.message: Did you mean effect?
rule.example: The ban took affect at midnight.

rule.message: Did you mean effect?
rule.example: It had the same affect on me.

rule.message: Did you mean affect?
rule.example: That might effect the bottom line.

rule.message: Did you mean affect?
rule.example: That might adversely effect the bottom line.
That might affect the bottom line.

rule.message: Did you mean affect?
rule.example: The medicine shouldn't effect the baby.

rule.message: Did you mean affected?
rule.example: The medicine would've effected the baby.

rule.message: Did you mean effect?
rule.example: The laws had an immediate affect.

rule.message: Did you mean effects?
rule.example: There was a law with immediate affects.

rule.message: Did you mean side effect (=adverse effect, unintended consequence)?
rule.example: A side affect of global warming

rule.message: Did you mean side effects (=adverse effect, unintended consequence)?
rule.example: The side affects of global warming

rule.message: Did you mean (=adverse effect, unintended consequence)? Open compounds are not hyphenated.
rule.example: A side-affect of global warming
Conventional treatments are subjected to testing for undesired side-effects.

rule.message: Did you mean cause and effect?
rule.example: The experiment didn't obey the laws of cause and affect.

rule.message: Did you mean \1 affected?
rule.example: She was badly effected.

rule.name: 'economical (economic) growth' etc.
rule.message: Did you mean economic (=connected with economy)?
rule.example: This article deals with economical development of the Third World.

rule.name: 'economic (economical) car' etc.
rule.message: Did you mean economical (=affordable, cheap)?
rule.example: This is a very economic car.

rule.name: 'written in verses (verse)'
rule.message: Did you mean verse?
rule.example: The tale was written in verses.

rule.message: Did you mean \1 principle (=as a rule)?
rule.example: In principal I don't think it will be too difficult.
In principle, I don't think it will be too difficult.
Each award of more than $1,000 in principal amount

rule.message: Did you mean \1 principle (=rule)?
rule.example: In principle, I don't think it will be too difficult.
In this discussion we have endeavored to do this: to point out basic principals of liberty in which all people can believe.
Ptolemy sets out the general principals of astrology.

rule.message: Did you mean principal (=main)?
rule.example: The principle activity of the Foundation is centred on humanitarian aid and charity, especially with regards to children.
The principal activity of the Foundation is focused on humanitarian aid and charity.
Dr. Doe was listed as the grant's principle investigator.
Laundering money was the mob's principle activity.

rule.message: Did you mean school principal (=head of school)?
rule.example: Mr Brown is our new school principle.

rule.message: Did you mean principle (=rule)?
rule.example: He told me it's against his principals to drink alcohol.
This violates all principals of the Constitution.

rule.message: Did you mean principle (=rule)?
rule.example: Always stick to your principals.

rule.message: 'Say' cannot be followed by a direct personal object. Did you mean tell?
rule.example: Say me the truth.

rule.message: 'Say' cannot be followed by a direct personal object. Did you mean told?
rule.example: He said me the truth.
She said her daughter continues to see a psychologist.

rule.message: 'Say' cannot be followed by a direct personal object. Did you mean tells?
rule.example: He says me the truth.
She says her youngest daughter continues to see a psychologist.

rule.message: Did you mean ?
rule.example: try using raw cacao nubs.

rule.message: Did you mean nub?
rule.example: This is the nib of the problem.

rule.message: 'Everyday' is an adjective, and the comma is missing. Did you mean every day, \3?
rule.example: Everyday he gets up early.

rule.message: 'Everyday' is an adjective. Did you mean every day?
rule.example: Everyday, he gets up early.

rule.message: 'Everyday' is an adjective. Did you mean every day?
rule.example: He gets up early everyday.

rule.name: everyone (every one)
rule.message: Did you mean every one?
rule.example: The space in which each and everyone of us lives has taken on a new shape.

rule.name: niece (nice) day etc.
rule.message: Did you mean nice (=pleasant)?
rule.example: I wish you a niece holiday.

rule.name: slight (sleight) of hand
rule.message: Did you mean sleight?
rule.example: This is where the slight of hand comes in.
At the show, we saw many marvellous slights of hand.
Slights of hand are a clever trick.
Sleight of hand is also known as prestidigitation.

rule.name: route (root) of the problem
rule.message: Did you mean root (=source, cause)?
rule.example: The route of the problems is unknown.
The routes of the problem are not yet known.
'The Route of the Problem' on page 26 gives more information.
Routes of the Problem on page 31 gives more information.
The root of the problem is the unnecessary complexity of the rules.
'The Route of the Problem' is a music track (http://runescape.wikia.com/wiki/The_Route_of_the_Problem).

rule.message: Did you mean complaints?
rule.example: I do not understand why there are complains from our community.
They received a number of complains from customers.

rule.message: Did you mean complaint?
rule.example: This is our biggest complain.
Shortness of breath was a common complain among the patients.

rule.name: first aid kid (kit)
rule.message: Did you mean kit (=set of articles, tools, or supplies) instead of 'kid' (=young person)?
rule.example: A first aid kid is a collection of medical supplies and equipment, often portable.

rule.message: Did you mean spelling?
rule.example: This is a spilling error.

rule.message: Did you mean spelling?
rule.example: What is the correct spilling of 'Mississippi'?

rule.message: Did you mean for? ('since' refers to a point in time, whereas 'for' refers to a period)
rule.example: I've lived in Barcelona since six years.
I've lived in Barcelona since 2015.

rule.message: Did you mean the noun extent?
rule.example: It is not known to what extend the subjects were being truthful.

rule.message: Did you mean the noun extent?
rule.example: To a great extend, psychological explanations prove satisfactory.

rule.message: Did you mean the noun extent?
rule.example: Shoplifters will be prosecuted to the fullest extend of the law.

rule.message: Did you mean supper (=evening meal)
rule.example: We went for a walk after super.

rule.message: Did you mean supper (=evening meal)
rule.example: After I had eaten my super, I went straight to bed.

rule.message: Did you mean the noun personnel?
rule.example: She's the director of personal.

rule.message: Did you mean the noun personnel?
rule.example: For authorized personal only.

rule.message: Did you mean the noun personnel?
rule.example: He is the personal director.

rule.message: Did you mean wore (simple past of "to wear")?
rule.example: Last Sunday I whore a beautiful dress.
Tim whore a sweatshirt yesterday.
You are a whore, a liar and a thief.
I whore myself in the streets.

rule.message: Did you mean wore (simple past of "to wear")?
rule.example: This is the skirt that I whore last week.
This is the car that you whore stole from me.

rule.name: overnight instead of 'over night'
rule.message: Did you mean the adjective or adverb \1night (i.e., for or during the entire night)?
rule.example: She stayed over night.
The stock has gone down over night.
Cover and refrigerate overnight.
I prefer day over night.

rule.message: Did you mean overtime (=time someone works beyond normal working hours)?
rule.example: I worked two hours of over time last week.
The gears had worn down over time.
Energy is the capacity to do work over time

rule.message: Did you mean overtime (=time someone works beyond normal working hours)?
rule.example: No child shall be permitted or required to work over time.
Energy is the capacity to do work over time

rule.message: Did you mean overtime (=time someone works beyond normal working hours)?
rule.example: They worked over time to come up with a great idea.
Energy is the capacity to do work over time
Faulty meters stop working over time.

rule.name: bar-b-queue instead of 'bar-b-que'
rule.message: Did you mean ?
rule.example: A casual summer bar-b-queue.

rule.name: redundant determiner: 'in (an) alphabetical order
rule.message: Unless there is more than one '\3 \4', leave out the determiner '\2'.
rule.example: List the names in an alphabetical order.

rule.name: I never have been (I have never been)
rule.message: Although not incorrect, the word order have never is preferred by native speakers.
rule.example: I never have been to London.

rule.name: from X - Y (from X to Y)
rule.message: Nonstandard phrase. Did you mean: to ?
rule.example: From 12 – 17 February 2016
Rates of sea level rise range from 1 . 22 mm per year to 2.14 mm per year.
Ferries commence service from 7:00 am.
He partnered with Stephen T. Logan from 1841 until 1844.
Algiers lost from 30,000 to 50,000 inhabitants to the plague in 1620–21.
The population has grown from 5,000 in 1900.
Starting from 22 May 2016, we will do the new tests.
From 21 Feb 2014 and until further notice, we will do the new tests.
Rates of sea level rise range from 1.22 mm per year to 2.14 mm per year.
The values range from 5,55 mm to approximately 7 mm.
The depth varies from 2'7" approximately to 3 feet exactly.
The depth varies from 2′ 9″ approximately to 3 feet exactly.
The height is from 3 ft 8 in (approx) to 4 feet exactly.
The gradient of the mountain road varies from 3 in 10 to a maximum of 4 in 10.
From 1 .22 bullet, the forensic team solved the crime.

rule.name: February of 2005 (February 2005)
rule.message: When specifying a month and year, 'of' is unnecessary: .

rule.name: the question what (the question of what)
rule.message: This sounds awkward in English. The standard is of .
rule.example: This thesis addresses the question how to analyze concepts.
This thesis addresses the question of how to analyze concepts.

rule.name: in the moment (currently)
rule.message: Did you mean at the moment (=currently)?
rule.example: No, currently not.
No, in the moment not.
But in the moment of truth everyone could see that.

rule.name: make since (sense)
rule.message: Did you mean sense?
rule.example: Something like 90 most likely never makes since.
There have been three made since the launch.
Many changes have been made since my previous visit.

rule.name: all and all (all in all)
rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Did you mean all in all (=after all, nevertheless)?
rule.example: One for all and all for one!
All and all it’s just another brick in the… toilet?

rulegroup.name: all of the sudden (all of a sudden)

rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Did you mean all of a sudden?
rule.example: Why would a man all of the sudden send flowers?
Why would anyone all of a sudden send flowers?

rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Did you mean all of a sudden?
rule.example: Why would a man all the sudden send flowers?
Why would anyone all of a sudden send flowers?

rule.name: along the same vein (along the same line, in the same vein)
rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Use in the same vein or along the same line.

example.correction: in the same vein|along the same line

rule.example: I've been working along the same vein.

rule.name: Misused phrase: 'ever so often (every so often)'
rule.message: This phrase is non-standard in most writing. Did you mean every \2 \3?
rule.example: Ever so often, we put down the books, and go sailing!

rule.name: early adapter (early adopter)
rule.message: Did you mean early adopter (=someone who takes something early on)?
rule.example: DualCore PC is available for purchase for selected companies in the early adapter program.

rule.name: far be it for me (far be it from me)
rule.message: Did you mean far be it from me (=may this possibility be far away from me)?
rule.example: Far be it for me to say that you can’t.

rule.name: money is no option (money is no object)
rule.message: Did you mean money is no object (=money is no obstacle, cost what it may)?
rule.example: Money is no option when are you rich.

rule.name: nip it in the butt (nip it in the bud)
rule.message: Did you mean nip it in the bud (=stop it from flowering completely)?
rule.example: We'd like to nip it in the butt right here.

rule.name: now and days (nowadays)
rule.message: Did you mean nowadays?
rule.example: Money is becoming pretty tight now and days.

rule.name: the proof is in the pudding (the proof of the pudding is in the eating)
rule.message: If you don't want to look for proofs hidden in your pudding, you probably meant the proof of the pudding is in the eating.

example.correction: The proof of the pudding is in the eating
example.marker: The Proof Is In The Pudding

rule.example: The proof of the pudding is in the eating.

rule.name: qui bono (cui bono)
rule.message: Non standard Latin. Did you mean cui bono (=to whose benefit).
rule.example: Let me ask: qui bono?

rule.name: whip cream (whipped cream)
rule.message: Did you mean whipped cream?
rule.example: Whip cream until it becomes whip cream.

rule.name: in/with regards to/of (regarding, with regard to)
rule.message: Use in regard to, with regard to, or more simply regarding.
rule.example: Please be aware of the following changes in regards to this program.
But, they would assist in some way with regards to the criminal prosecution.
With regards to America, we must not forget that the…
The hotel is satisfactory in regards of quality and price.
Please be aware of the following changes in this program.
But, they would assist in some way with regard to the criminal prosecution.
But, they would assist in some way in regard to the criminal prosecution.
But, they would assist in some way regarding the criminal prosecution.
I hope this letter finds you well. Love Mike. P.S. With regards to Susan.

rule.name: very known (very well-known, well-known)
rule.message: Incorrect phrase. Use very well-known or well-known instead.
rule.example: He is a very known actor.

rule.message: This is a non-standard contraction. Use \1 have \4 or \1've got \4 to express possession.
rule.example: I've got a new car.
I've a new car.

rule.message: This is a non-standard contraction. Use have \3 or 've got to express possession.
rule.example: I've got three new cars.
I've three new cars.

rule.message: Wrong phrase. Use \1\2\3 or \1 \4\5\6.
rule.example: It's 7:00 o'clock.

rule.message: Wrong phrase; 'o'clock is used only at the full hour. Use simply \1\2\3 instead.
rule.example: It's 7 o'clock.
It's 7:45 o'clock.

rule.name: 5-farads/5-farad
rule.message: The word '' is an adjective (SI unit of measurement), but the spelling is not correct. Do not use a plural adjective. Refer to section 5.3.3 in 'The International System of Units (SI)'.
rule.example: Use a 6-microfarads capacitor.
Use a 6-microfarad capacitor.
A 10-milliohms resistor is necessary.
Use a 10-metres rope.
The 4.6-centigrammes difference is not a problem.
Also find typographic errors: a 5.7.8-femtogrammes difference is not important.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing an .
rule.example: As the wife of a former alumnus of UCLA, I am appalled at recent events that have occurred and seemingly encouraged by the administration.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: The former alumnus adviser of Alpha Lambda Chapter was elected as congressman-at- large in Ohio.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using an
rule.example: A sworn affidavit is a written statement made by someone under oath to tell the truth about something.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using
rule.example: His sworn affidavit was deposited in the post office mailbox.

rule.name: directly antithetical (antithetical)
rule.message: This phrase verges on redundancy. Consider writing .
rule.example: The two events this week were directly antithetical to the University's values for these reasons.
The two events this week were antithetical to the University's values for these reasons.

rule.name: approximately about
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using .
rule.example: Americans feel full of energy and healthy approximately about 19 days per month.
Americans feel full of energy and healthy approximately 19 days per month.
In reasoning about a complex system, humans reason approximately about its behavior.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: Hippos associate together in groups.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: Poets and choregi having been associated together in pairs, there still remained the selection and appointment of the actors.

rule.name: sufficient enough -> sufficient
rule.message: 'Sufficient enough' is redundant. Consider using only sufficient.
rule.example: The money is sufficient enough to buy the pullover.

rule.name: of any of -> of
rule.message: Consider simply using of instead.
rule.example: He was the worst of any of the dancers

rule.name: Possibly needless 'that'
rule.message: "\2" may be unnecessary here.
rule.example: I am pretty sure that this is right.
I am pretty sure this is right.
It has grown way beyond that.

rule.name: send an email to (email)
rule.message: Consider using email.
rule.example: He was going to email her.
He was going to send an email to her.

rule.name: sent an email to (email)
rule.message: Consider using emailed.
rule.example: He sent an email to her.
He emailed her.

rule.name: the world around it (the world)
rule.message: Consider using the world.
rule.example: He didn't like the world around him.
He didn't like the world.

rule.name: because of the fact that (because)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using because.
rule.example: Its crystals are usually hexagonal in shape, with flakiness and plating, usually because of the fact that it replaced a mineral.

rule.name: Wordiness: in a ... manner
rule.message: Consider replacing "\1 \2 \3 \4" with adverb for "\3"; e.g., "in a hasty manner" with "hastily".
rule.example: He came in a hasty manner.
He came hastily.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant ('M' stands for 'machine'). Use simply \1.
rule.example: ATM Machine Comparison Guide
In the Netherlands, criminals are stealing money from ATM machines by blowing them up.
ATMs are quite common in the Netherlands,

rule.message: This phrase is redundant ('V' stands for 'virus'). Use simply \1.
rule.example: The HIV virus continues to spread.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant ('N' stands for 'number'). Consider using \1.
rule.example: Please input your PIN number to access.
You can create multiple PIN numbers to enhance the security.
Could you let me know the ISBN number of the book?
ISBN numbers are assigned to text-based monographic publications.

rule.message: This phrase is redundant ('D' stands for 'display'). Consider using \1.
rule.example: The result is printed on this LCD display.
LCD displays have sources of light behind the screens.

rule.name: absolutely essential/necessary (essential/necessary)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: This is absolutely essential.
This was essential.

rule.name: actual experience/facts (experience/facts)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: This talk is based on actual experience gained during recovery operations following a fire at the Washington National Records.
This play is based on facts.

rule.name: advance planning/preview/reservations/warning (planning/preview/reservations/warning)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \2.
rule.example: Advance planning is one strategy couples can use to establish legal rights.

rule.name: add an additional (add)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using .
rule.example: How to Add an Additional Page to a Full Flash Site

rule.message: Redundant phrase. Consider using \1 \2\3\4 or \1 \5\6\7.
rule.example: It's 7 o'clock a.m.

rule.message: Redundant phrase. Consider using \1 \2\3\4 or \1 \5.
rule.example: It's 7 o'clock AM.

rule.message: Did you mean \1:\3?
rule.example: It's 7,30 p.m.
The asteroid will arrive first-class at 10.45 a.m.

rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: It's 5 AM in the morning.
He doesn't know where I am in the morning.

rule.message: Consider using A.M.
rule.example: It's 5 A.M. in the morning.
It's 5 A.M.

rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: It's 5 PM in the evening.

rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: It's 1 PM at night.
It's 5 PM.

rule.message: Consider using P.M.
rule.example: It's 5 P.M. in the afternoon.
It's 5 P.M.

rule.message: Consider using P.M.
rule.example: It's 1 P.M. at night.
It's 5 P.M.

rule.name: and also (and/also)
rule.message: Consider using and or also.
rule.example: Typical English Food and also Welsh and Scottish too
Typical English Food, and Welsh and Scottish too

rule.name: and etc. (etc.)
rule.message: Consider using \2\3.
rule.example: E-Commerce and etc.

rule.name: annual anniversary (anniversary)
rule.message: Consider using \2 instead.
rule.example: First Annual Anniversary Contest

rule.name: added bonus (bonus)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \2.
rule.example: Added bonus: booting from cdrom.
Bonus: booting from CD-ROM.

rule.name: adequate enough (adequate)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \1.
rule.example: The Allen test is not adequate enough for the screening of hand circulation.

rule.name: are able to (can)
rule.message: This expression is wordy. Consider using can.
rule.example: Yes, there are some species of frogs that can throw up their entire stomach and wipe it off with their legs.
Yes, there are some species of frogs that are able to throw up their entire stomach and wipe it off with their legs.

rule.name: ask the question (ask)
rule.message: Consider using \1 instead.
rule.example: He asked the question.
He asked the question whether it's OK to add some rules to LanguageTool.

rule.name: as of yet (yet)
rule.message: Consider using yet or as yet.
rule.example: The report remains unfinished as of yet.

rule.name: armed gunman (gunman)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \2.
rule.example: Armed gunmen entered the room to kill Bill.
Gunmen are very dangerous in this city.

rule.name: autobiography of a life (autobiography)
rule.message: Consider using \1 or story \2 \3 \4 instead.
rule.example: In this autobiography of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles.
In this story of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles

rule.name: basic fundamentals/necessities (fundamentals/necessities)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Visual Basic Fundamentals
Let’s get back to the basic fundamentals!

rule.name: bald-headed (bald)
rule.message: Consider using bald.
rule.example: He is bald-headed.
Kojak was bald.

rule.name: balsa wood (balsa)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: It's made of balsa wood.
This table is made of balsa.

rule.name: bare naked (naked)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: The old man ran bare naked through the streets.

rule.name: best ever (best)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \1.
rule.example: Top ten best ever beer names.
Top ten best beer names.

rule.name: temporary bivouac (bivouac)
rule.message: This phrase may be redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: In temporary bivouac areas (1 to 3 days), the straddle trench latrine is used unless more permanent facilities are provided for the unit.

rule.name: bivouac camp (bivouac)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing .
rule.example: A rock climber leaves a hanging bivouac camp on an Arctic cliff
A rock climber leaves a hanging bivouac on an Arctic cliff

rule.name: Big in size, yellow in color, etc.
rule.message: A more concise phrase may lose no meaning and sound more powerful.
rule.example: He's absorbed in thought.
The man is big in size.
His speech was briefest in duration.
My car is redder in color.
Her friends were few in number.
I really need to get back in shape.

rule.name: bitter in taste (bitter)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: This beer is bitter in taste.

rule.name: blend together (blend)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \1.
rule.example: Their voices blend together in lovely harmony.
Their voices blend in lovely harmony.

rule.name: boat marina (marina)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Taupo Boat Marina

rule.name: brief in duration (brief)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: However, most wilderness programs are brief in duration.

rule.name: brief moment/summary (moment/summary)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: A Brief Moment of Compassion
A Moment of Compassion

rule.name: biography of her life (biography)
rule.message: Consider using \1 or story \2 \3 \4 instead.
rule.example: In this biography of her life, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles.
In this story of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles

rule.name: bouquet of flowers (bouquet)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \1.
rule.example: What a beautiful bouquet of flowers!

rule.name: but nevertheless/however (but)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: I should not have, but nevertheless I did.

rule.name: CD disc (CD)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: I ordered a CD disk with their software.
I ordered a CD with their software.
I ordered a DVD with their software.

rule.name: CDROM (CD-ROM)
rule.message: Consider using CD-ROM.
rule.example: I ordered a Cdrom with their software.
I ordered a CD-ROM with their software.

rule.message: Did you mean three?
rule.example: I've lived in Barcelona for tree years.

rule.name: accused of a charge (charged with)
rule.message: This phrase may be redundant. Consider writing: charged with instead.
rule.example: The Magistrate's Court in Kuala Lumpur today decided that a former model accused of a charge of public indecency is fit to stand trial.

rule.name: circumstances surrounding (circumstances of)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider writing of.
rule.example: Based upon this discussion, the OIG expanded the scope of its investigation to analyze the circumstances surrounding the settlement rejected by Judge Rakoff.

rule.message: This is verbose. Consider writing: close to.
rule.example: The majority of Jannali's enterprises are located within close proximity to the suburb's railway station.

rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Their manifesto yesterday received the same close scrutiny as the other two big parties — and it was an uncomfortable experience.

rule.name: combine together (combine)
rule.message: ' ' is redundant. Use
rule.example: Two things are combined together in this application.
Each layer combines together for an absolute orchestra of flavors.
Two things are combined in this application.

rule.name: comfortable with doing (comfortable doing)
rule.message: Consider using \1 \3.
rule.example: I am not comfortable with dancing with strangers.

rule.name: common bond (bond)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: They formed a common bond against the British

rule.name: commute back and forth (commute)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: She will commute back and forth between New Haven and her home in Southern California before relocating to the Elm City this summer.
She will commute between New Haven and her home in Southern California before relocating to the Elm City this summer

rule.name: consensus of opinion (consensus)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: Wim Duisenberg, the ECB's Dutch president, is seen as a leader who seeks to fashion a consensus of opinion on the council rather than imposing his own views, as some chairmen of the US Federal Reserve have done.

rule.name: continue to remain (remain)
rule.message: Consider using remain.
rule.example: We continued to remain optimistic.
We remain optimistic.

rule.name: descend down (descend)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Consider using \1.
rule.example: The Pentagon aides and journalists descend down the back stairs of the plane as is customary while Rumsfeld comes down the main stairs to meet his welcome party.

rule.name: during the course of (during)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: He never smiled during the course of the trial.

rule.name: each and every one (each one)
rule.message: Consider using \1 \4.
rule.example: God bless each and every one of you!

rulegroup.name: Suggest shorter ways to negate words (not common vs uncommon)

rule.message: Consider using in\3.
rule.example: The list is not complete.
The list is incomplete.

rule.message: Consider using un\3.
rule.example: The rock is not steady.
The rock is unsteady.

rule.message: Consider using im\3.
rule.example: The paragraph is not perfect.
The paragraph is imperfect.

rule.message: Consider using ir\3.
rule.example: The student was not rational.
The student was irrational.

rule.message: Consider using too slow.
rule.example: The car was not fast enough to win the race.
The car was too slow to win the race.

rule.message: Consider using too small.
rule.example: The car was not large enough for the tall man.
The car was too small for the large man.

rule.message: Consider using too large.
rule.example: The car was not small enough to fit through the tunnel.
The car was too large to fit through the tunnel.

rule.name: all of the (all the)
rule.message: Consider using all the.
rule.example: She is going to all of the parks.
She is going some or all of the parks.

rule.name: self-admitted (admitted)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using admitted.
rule.example: Springfield police arrest 'very dangerous, self-admitted gang member.'

rule.name: some of the (some)
rule.message: Consider using some.
rule.example: Some of the parks are in the area.
She is going to buy some parks.
She is going all or some of the parks.
He is putting out some of the most inspired music of his life.
They want to answer some of the universe’s deepest questions.

rule.name: try and (try to)
rule.message: "Try and" is common in colloquial speech, but "try to" is recommended for writing.
rule.example: She is going to try and go to the store.

rule.name: so as to (to)
rule.message: Consider using to
rule.example: The band practiced so as to increase their chances of success.

rule.name: on a few occasions (occasionally)
rule.message: Consider using occasionally
rule.example: The man drank on a few occasions.

rule.name: there are also other (also)
rule.message: Consider using there are other or there are also
rule.example: However, there are also other marbles in the jar.
There are other marbles in the jar.

rule.name: a large number of (many)
rule.message: Specify a number, remove phrase, or simply use many or numerous
rule.example: A large number of people were in the parade.

rule.name: a small number of (a few)
rule.message: Specify a number, remove phrase, use a few, or use some
rule.example: A small number of people were in the store.
Few people were in the store.

rule.name: subsequent to (after)
rule.message: Consider using after
rule.example: The roads needed repairs subsequent to the storm.

rule.name: hollow tube (tube)
rule.message: Consider using tube
rule.example: We fixed the hollow tube.

rule.name: exact replica (replica)
rule.message: Consider using replica
rule.example: We created an exact replica of the building.
We created a replica of the building.

rule.name: with the exception of (except)
rule.message: Consider using except or except for
rule.example: With the exception of Bob, all of the children went running.

rule.name: every now and then (now and then)
rule.message: Consider using \2 \3 \4.
rule.example: Every now and then the faucet drips.

rule.name: established fact (fact)
rule.message: Consider using .
rule.example: This is an established fact.

rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: This is the exact same situation.
This is the same situation.

rule.message: Consider using \2 \3.
rule.example: This shoe is exactly the same.
This shoe is the same.

rule.message: Consider using summer.
rule.example: It is warm during the summertime.

rule.message: Consider using summer.
rule.example: It is warm during the summer time.
It is warm during the summer.
For information about British Summer Time (BST), refer to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Summer_Time.
For information about Western European Summer Time, refer to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_European_Summer_Time.

rule.name: fall season (fall)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: The leaves turn red and gold in the fall season.

rule.name: famous celebrity (celebrity)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: I'm told that he's a famous celebrity now.

rule.name: salsa sauce (salsa)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: I enjoy eating salsa sauce.

rule.name: general public (public)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: We should show this to the general public.

rule.name: new innovation (innovation)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: He was a new recruit.

rule.name: originally discovered (discovered)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: He originally discovered gold.

rule.name: former graduate (graduate)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: I am a former graduate of the school.

rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: I enjoy over exaggerating.

rule.message: Consider using .
rule.example: I enjoy over-exaggerating.

rule.name: originally born in (born in)
rule.message: Consider using \2 \3.
rule.example: I was originally born in Texas.

rule.name: return back (return)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: We returned back home.

rule.name: repeat again (repeat)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: We made the song repeat again.

rule.name: might perhaps (might)
rule.message: Consider using \1, \2.
rule.example: We might possibly go fishing.

rulegroup.name: disagree with the fact that (disagree that)

rule.message: Consider using \1 that.
rule.example: I agree with the fact that the sky is blue.

rule.message: Consider using \1 disagree that or \1 agree that.
rule.example: We did not disagree with the fact that the sky is blue.

rule.name: will in the future (will)
rule.message: Consider using will.
rule.example: I will in the future work hard.

rule.name: work colleague (colleague)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: I will talk to a work colleague.

rule.name: numerous different (numerous)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: I will read many different books
I will read many books.

rule.name: whole lot (lot)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: I will read a whole lot of books
I will read a lot of books.

rule.name: fellow classmates/co-workers/comrades (classmates/co-workers/comrades)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: I would enjoy a reunion with my fellow classmates.

rule.name: few in number (few)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: They were few in number, but mighty.

rule.name: first time ever (first time)
rule.message: Consider using \1 \2.
rule.example: We have a pig in space for the first time ever.

rule.name: foreign import (import)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Use simply \2.
rule.example: The rise in foreign imports, the argument goes, is forcing some Americans to accept lower pay to remain competitive with, say, Mexican and Chinese workers.

rule.name: forever and ever (forever)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: It is you and me, forever and ever.

rule.name: from whence (whence)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Go back from whence you came.
Go back whence you came!

rule.name: honest truth (truth)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: That is the honest truth of the matter.
That is the truth of the matter.

rule.name: in order to (to)
rule.message: This phrase might be considered redundant. Consider using \3.
rule.example: We opened the door in order to enter.
We opened the door to enter.

rule.name: introduce for the first time (introduce)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: We were introduced for the first time a week ago.

rule.name: main focus (focus)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Redundancies are the main focus of my essay.

rule.name: major breakthrough (breakthrough)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: It was a major breakthrough in genetic research.

rule.name: can/could/may/might possibly (can/could/may/might)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: That may possibly be the greatest blunder of all.

rule.name: mental telepathy (telepathy)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Do cats really use mental telepathy?

rule.name: mutually dependent on each other (mutually dependent)
rule.message: Consider using \1 \2.
rule.example: Well, they're mutually dependent on each other.

rule.name: never at any time (never)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: I was never at any time with that woman.

rule.name: the noun around it (surrounding noun)
rule.message: Consider using the surrounding \2.
rule.example: He didn't like the protesters around him.

rule.name: now currently (now)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: She is now currently the ambassador.

rule.name: one and the same (the same)
rule.message: Consider using \3 \4.
rule.example: Santa Claus and Saint Nick are one and the same person.

rule.name: or alternatively (or)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: We can either do this now or alternatively leave it for tomorrow.

rule.name: passing fad (fad)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Computers are just a passing fad.

rule.name: past experience/memory (experience/memory)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: We know from past experience that weakness breeds contempt.

rule.name: period of time (period)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: Horses were absent throughout that period of time.

rule.name: personal charm/belongings/opinion/friendship (charm/belongings/opinion/belongings)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: In my personal opinion, canaries are quite tasty.

rule.name: point being is that (point is that/point being that)
rule.message: Consider using \1 \3 \4 or \1 \2 \4.
rule.example: The point being is that Russia and Japan weren't even at war.
The point is that Russia and Japan weren't even at war

rule.name: reason why (reason)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: The reason why I did that is simple.
The reason I did that is simple.

rule.name: so therefore (therefore)
rule.message: Consider using \1 or \2.
rule.example: I am me, the only me, so therefore I am unique, which in turn makes me special :)

rule.name: therapeutic treatment (treatment)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: My swelled knee required special therapeutic treatment.

rule.name: rustic country (rustic)
rule.message: Consider using \1.
rule.example: She loved her rustic country kitchen.

rule.name: safe haven (haven)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: They ran for the forest, searching for a safe haven.

rule.name: usual custom (custom)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Eggnog on Christmas is our usual custom.

rule.name: very unique (unique)
rule.message: Consider using \2.
rule.example: Walk until you see the very unique building on your right.
Walk until you see a unique building on your right.

rule.message: Wordiness: Consider shortening this phrase.

example.correction: Whether|Whether or not|As to whether|The question whether|As to whether or not

rule.example: The question as to whether or not it is difficult is not our concern.

rule.message: Wordiness: Consider shortening this phrase.
rule.example: The question as to whether it is difficult is not our concern.

rule.message: Wordiness: Consider shortening this phrase.
rule.example: The question of whether it is difficult is not our concern.

rule.message: Wordiness: Consider shortening this phrase.
rule.example: We are not concern as to whether or not it is difficult.

rule.message: Consider shortening this phrase to just \3, or rephrase the sentence to avoid "\1 \2".
rule.example: The question whether it is difficult is not our concern.

rule.message: Consider shortening this phrase to just \3, or rephrase the sentence to avoid "\1 \2".
rule.example: As to whether it is difficult, we are not concern.
Whether it is difficult is not our concern.
We are not concern whether it is difficult.

rule.message: Consider shortening this phrase to just \1. It is correct though if you mean 'regardless of whether'.
rule.example: What the government decides to do depends on whether or not the bill passes.

rule.name: female actor (actress)
rule.message: Consider using actress.
rule.example: She was the first female actor.

rule.name: female waiter (waitress)
rule.message: Consider using waitress.
rule.example: She was the first female waiter.

rule.name: first woman president (female president)
rule.message: Use female.
rule.example: She was the first woman president.

rule.name: first man president (male president)
rule.message: Use male.
rule.example: He was the first man employee of the company.
He was the first man Sarah ever kissed.

rule.name: little bit
rule.message: Reduce redundancy by using little or bit.
rule.example: He was a little bit late.

rule.name: free gift
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Consider using .
rule.example: Receive a free gift with every purchase.
Compare the best phone deals with free gifts, from tablets and TVs to …
Free gifts for you to keep!
Receive a gift with every purchase.

rule.name: be bigger than me (I)
rule.message: In formal / written English, it is recommended that you use a subject pronoun.
rule.example: She is wiser than me!
She is prettier than her younger sister.

rule.name: most (almost) every
rule.message: The phrase '\1 \2' is colloquial. In formal/ written English you should avoid it. Use almost \2 instead!
rule.example: Most everyone saw him.
They are most everywhere.

rule.name: where/when
rule.message: It is better to use '\1' with the time-relative pronoun 'when': \1 when. (Alternatively, use 'in/on which')
rule.example: There are times where you need to measure high current devices.
Do you remember the happy days where we were together

rule.name: Profanity
rule.message: This word is considered offensive.
rule.example: Piss off!
Go away!
Carleton S. Coon was an American anthropologist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carleton_S._Coon).

rule.name: 'Needs fixed' type construction
rule.message: "\1 \2" is only accepted in certain dialects. For something more widely acceptable, try or to be \2.
rule.example: My car needs fixed.
A set of needs described as essential

rule.name: an invite (invitation)
rule.message: Use only in informal register. In other registers, invitation should be used.
rule.example: Is that an invite...?

rule.name: irregardless (regardless)
rule.message: 'Irregardless' is acceptable in casual and nonstandard writing at best. In formal style you should use regardless.
rule.example: Irregardless of what he says, do it!

rule.name: Sentence starting with 'And' or 'But'
rule.message: While it is not exactly wrong, stylistically '\2' should only be used to start a sentence for dramatic effect and even then rarely.
rule.example: And yes, it shows a lack of style to start a sentence with 'and'.
Yes, it shows a lack of style to start a sentence with 'and'.
But it is not a great writing style to start a sentence with 'but'.
It is not a great writing style to start a sentence with 'but'.

rule.name: Number starting a sentence
rule.message: Numbers at the start of the sentence should be written as words.
rule.example: 12 soldiers were killed!
Twelve soldiers were killed!

rule.name: Word order: 'Hopefully' starting a sentence
rule.message: Many style books advice that a sentence should not start with 'hopefully'.
rule.example: Hopefully, this will be a great grammar checker.
The prisoner thought hopefully about the prospect for escape.

rule.name: Readability: Three nouns in a row
rule.message: You used three nouns after one another, and this might decrease readability. You might consider rewording the sentence.
rule.example: The security protection software we offer is the state-of-the art achievement.
The security software we offer is the state-of-the art achievement.

rule.name: Style: 'possible' after 'possibility'
rule.message: Bad style. Before '\2', use a word such as chance or opportunity. Alternatively, keep '\1' and remove '\2'.
rule.example: I did not have a possibility to check for possible errors.
A possibility for possible errors exist.
You should remove all possibilities for these possible errors.
I did not have a chance to check for possible errors.
I did not have a possibility to check for errors.
Einstein published an article in 'Physikalische Zeitschrift' that proposed the possibility of stimulated emission, the physical process that makes possible the maser and the laser.
There is a possible possibility that errors exist.

rulegroup.name: capitalize proper names, geographic terms, historic episodes...

rule.message: Capitalize specific, well-defined geographical regions:
rule.example: She lived several years in south America.
With the reunification of West and east Germany, the Federal Republic of Germany became known simply as 'Germany'.
The term NATO stands for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Go south three blocks and then turn left.
The west coast of Scotland is rainy this time of year.
Albania is a country in Southeastern Europe.
The British Isles and North-Western Europe.

rule.message: Capitalize holidays.
rule.example: What did you do on Valentine's day last year?
What are your plans for President's Day?

rule.message: Capitalize holidays.
rule.example: What did you do on Veterans day last year?

rule.message: Capitalize specific historic events, episodes, and eras.
rule.example: How many people died in world war II?

rule.message: Capitalize specific historic events, episodes, and eras.
rule.example: The middle ages is one of the three major periods in the most enduring scheme for analysing European history.

rule.message: Capitalize specific, well-defined geographical places.
rule.example: The cape of good hope is a rocky headland on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula, South Africa.

rule.message: Capitalize specific, well-defined geographical places.
rule.example: Since 1914, cape cod has been separated from the mainland by the Cape Cod Canal.

rule.message: Capitalize The, if it refers to 'The Hague' (city on the western coast of the Netherlands)
rule.example: Some of the most prosperous neighbourhoods of the Netherlands can be found in the Hague.
When did the Hague Congress take place?

rule.name: 'also' at the end of the sentence
rule.message: 'Also' is not used at the end of the sentence. Use as well instead.
rule.example: You will also buy some eggs.
You will buy some eggs also.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "It is possible that the sky is blue." can be changed to "The sky might be blue".
rule.example: It is possible that the sky is blue.
It is also possible that the sky is blue.
The sky might be blue.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "He is said to have been happy." can be changed to "The people said that he was happy." if you can define who/what performed the action.
rule.example: He is said to have been happy.
He is said to have not been happy.
The people said that he was happy.
He is not thought to have been happy.
He was not thought to have been happy.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "He is said to be happy." could be changed to "The people said that he was happy." if you can define who/what performed the action.
rule.example: He is said to be happy.
People say that he is happy.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "He insisted that red should be used." can be changed to "He insisted on using red."
rule.example: He insisted that red should be used.
He insisted that red be used.
He insisted on using red.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "Her work will have been finished by tonight." can be changed to "She will have her work finished by tonight."
rule.example: Her work will have been finished by tonight.
Her work will not have been finished by tonight.
She will have her work finished by tonight.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "A cake is being baked by him." can be changed to "He is baking a cake."
rule.example: A cake is being baked by him by tonight.
He is baking a cake.
A cake is also being baked by him by tonight.
A cake was also being baked by him by tonight.
A dozen cookies were also being baked by him by tonight.

rule.message: Change from passive to active voice? Example: "Instruments are played by her." can be changed to "She plays instruments."
rule.example: Instruments are played by her.
Instruments were played by her.
Instruments are not played by her.
John was given a book by her.
She plays instruments.

rule.name: May 20001 (May 2001)
rule.message: Did you really mean year \2? Or maybe ?
rule.example: I will go to Holland in May 20014.

rule.name: 'to both ...' with more than two items
rule.message: 'both' is usually followed by two items
rule.example: It allows us to both grow, focus, and flourish.
It allows us to both grow a lot, focus, and flourish.
It allows us to both grow a lot, focus some, and flourish.
It allows us to both grow and focus, and later flourish.

rulegroup.name: Future date, but verb in past tense

rule.message: The given date is in the future, but the verb is in past tense.
rule.example: We have visited the client on 7 October 2020.
I had already informed the customer on 7 October 2025.
We have visited the client on 7 October 2010.
I had already informed the customer on 7 October 2010.
We will inform the client on 7 October 2010.

rule.message: The given date is in the future, but the verb is in past tense.
rule.example: On 7 October 2020, we have visited the client.
On 7 October 2025, I had already informed the customer.
On 7 October 2010, we have visited the client.
On 7 October 2010, I had already informed the customer.
On 7 October 2010, we will inform the client.

rule.message: The given date is in the future, but the verb is in past tense.
rule.example: We visited the client on 7 October 2020.
I already informed the customer on 7 October 2025.
We visited the client on 7 October 2010.
I already informed the customer on 7 October 2010.
We will inform the client on 7 October 2010.

On 7 October 2025, I already informed the customer.
On 7 October 2010, we visited the client.

I had already informed the customer on October 7, 2020.
We have visited the client on October 7, 2010.

rule.message: A new year has begun. Did you mean \1 \2 {realYear}?
rule.example: IGD Convention - 7 October 2013
IGD Convention - 7 Oct 2013
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 Oct 2014

rule.message: A new year has begun. Did you mean \1 \2, {realYear}?
rule.example: IGD Convention - October 7, 2013
IGD Convention - Oct 7, 2013
IGD Convention - Tuesday, Oct 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, Oct 7, 2018
IGD Convention - Tuesday, October 7, 2012

rule.message: A new year has begun. Did you mean \1/\3/{realYear}?
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - 31/10/2013
IGD Convention 2014 - 31/10/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - 31/10/2018
IGD Convention 2014 - 31/10/2012
IGD Convention 2014 - 10/09/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - 9/10/2014

rule.message: A new year has begun. Did you mean \1/\3/{realYear}?
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - 10/31/2013
IGD Convention 2014 - 10/31/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - 10/31/2018
IGD Convention 2014 - 10/31/2012
IGD Convention 2014 - 10/09/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - 9/10/2014

rule.message: A new year has begun. Did you mean {realDate}?
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - 2013-10-31
IGD Convention 2014 - 2014-10-31
IGD Convention 2014 - 2018-10-31
IGD Convention 2014 - 2012-10-31

rule.message: The date \3 \4 \5 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention - Monday, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Mon, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Mo, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Monday, 7 Oct 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 October 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 Oct 2014

rule.message: The date \3 \4, \6 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention - Monday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Mon, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Mo, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Wednesday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Thursday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Friday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Saturday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Sunday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Sunday, Oct 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, October 7, 2014
IGD Convention - Tuesday, Oct 7, 2014

rule.message: The date \3/\5/\7 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 31/10/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 31/10/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/09/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 9/10/2014

rule.message: The date \3/\5/\7 is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/31/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 10/31/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/09/2014
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 9/10/2014

rule.message: The date \3 (YYYY-MM-DD) is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 2014-10-31
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 2014-10-31

rulegroup.name: Weekday doesn't match date for the current year

rule.message: Did you mean to refer to the current year? \3 \4 {currentYear} is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention - Monday, 7 October
IGD Convention - Mon, 7 October
IGD Convention - Mo, 7 October
IGD Convention - Monday, 7 Oct
IGD Convention - Monday, 7th Oct
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 October
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7 Oct
IGD Convention - Tuesday, 7th Oct

rule.message: Did you mean to refer to the current year? \3 \4, {currentYear} is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention - Monday, October 7
IGD Convention - Monday, October 7
IGD Convention - Mon, October 7
IGD Convention - Mo, October 7
IGD Convention - Wednesday, October 7
IGD Convention - Thursday, October 7
IGD Convention - Friday, October 7
IGD Convention - Saturday, October 7
IGD Convention - Sunday, October 7
IGD Convention - Sunday, Oct 7
IGD Convention - Sunday, October 3rd
IGD Convention - Sunday, Oct 2rd
IGD Convention - Sunday, Oct 1st
IGD Convention - Tuesday, October 7
IGD Convention - Tuesday, October 7th
IGD Convention - Tuesday, Oct 7
IGD Convention - Friday, Oct 3rd
IGD Convention - Thursday, Oct 2rd
IGD Convention - Wednesday, Oct 1st

rule.message: Did you mean to refer to the current year? \3/\5/{currentYear} is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 31/10
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 31/10
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/09
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 9/10

rule.message: Did you mean to refer to the current year? \3/\5/{currentYear} is not a {day}, but a {realDay}.
rule.example: IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/31
IGD Convention 2014 - Friday, 10/31
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 10/09
IGD Convention 2014 - Monday, 9/10

rule.message: The month of \1 only has 30 days.
rule.example: It happened on November 31, 2014.
It happened on November 30, 2014.

rule.message: February only has 28 days, or 29 days in leap years.
rule.example: It happened on Feb 30, 2014.
It happened on Feb 28, 2014.

rule.message: The starting day (\2) happens later than the final day (\4).
rule.example: January 10 – 17, 2016
January 10 – 1, 2016.

rule.message: The starting day (\3) happens later than the final day (\5).
rule.example: January 10 – 17, 2016

rule.message: Please check the suffix, if this is an ordinal number.
rule.example: This was my 1nd try.
This was my 92rd try.

rulegroup.name: Light-year as a unit of time

rule.message: A light-year is a unit of length (not of time) used to express astronomical distances.
rule.example: It all seems light-years ago now.
It all seems light years ago now.
It all seems lightyears ago now.
A light-year is how astronomers measure distance in space.

rule.message: Every positive number a has two square roots.
rule.example: The square root of 9 is 3.

rulegroup.name: Interval scale: doubling values ('twice as hot')

rule.message: Unless this expression refers to the Kelvin scale, it is not defined and probably makes no sense.
rule.example: It's half as warm as it was yesterday.
If it's zero degrees outside and it becomes twice as cold it was before, what is the temperature?

rule.name: Possible wordiness: be a X one
rule.message: Might \1 \3 convey the same?
rule.example: This test is an easy one.

rule.name: abundance
rule.message: Use enough or plenty, or give specific amount.
rule.example: There is an abundance of flowers in the meadow.
The meadow of full of flowers.

rule.name: accede to (give in)
rule.message: Unless it is a throne that is acceded to, change into allow, agree to or give in to.

example.correction: allow, agree to or give in to

rule.example: He acceded to our demands.
He gave in to our demands.

rule.name: accelerate
rule.message: Technical. Elsewhere replace with speed up.
rule.example: The car accelerated from traffic lights
The car sped up from traffic lights

rule.name: accentuate
rule.message: Replace with stress or emphasize.
rule.example: The harsh light accentuated the ruggedness of the landscape.
The harsh light emphasized the ruggedness of the landscape.

rule.name: accommodation
rule.message: room.
rule.example: Accommodation available.
Room available.

rule.name: accompany
rule.message: If not in musical context, use go with or with.
rule.example: You need to accompany him.
You need to go with him.

rule.name: verb accomplish (do, archive, finish)
rule.message: Try one of: do or achieve or finish.
rule.example: Accomplish your work!
He is an accomplished musician.

rule.name: verb accrue
rule.message: Use add or gain.
rule.example: The deposit accrued interest.
The deposit gained interest.

rule.name: accurate
rule.message: If it is not about aiming, use right; also detailed or correct.
rule.example: We need accurate information.
We need right and detailed information.

rule.name: verb acquire (get, develop)
rule.message: A simple get is enough most of the time, sometimes develop.
rule.example: He acquired all the tools he needed.
He got all the tools he needed.

rule.name: all things considered (omit)
rule.message: Remove as unnecessary.
rule.example: All things considered, Connecticut's woodlands are in better shape now than ever before.
Connecticut's woodlands are in better shape now than ever before.

rule.name: along the lines of (like)
rule.message: Did you mean like?
rule.example: I think my point is very much along the lines of his.
I think my point is very much like his.

rule.name: as a matter of fact (in fact, actually, omit)
rule.message: Replace with less wordy in fact or actually, or remove completely.
rule.example: As a matter of fact, dry-bulb temperature indicates the amount of heat in the air.
Actually, dry-bulb temperature indicates the amount of heat in the air.

rule.name: as per (as, in accordance with)
rule.message: Business jargon meaning in accordance with. Replace with as or modify the sentence.
rule.example: As per usual, he came late to work.
As usual, he came late to work.

rule.name: assist, assistance (help)
rule.message: Did you mean simpler help?
rule.example: Do you need any assistance?
Do you need any help?
May I assist you?
May I help you?

rule.name: at all times (always)
rule.message: Simply, always. Pay attention to place in the sentence.
rule.example: Kingfisher can be found near water at all times
Kingfisher can always be found near water.

rulegroup.name: at the present time, at this time, at this point in time, at the moment (now, currently)

rule.message: Use now, for now, or if you really must, currently
rule.example: At the present time, this Wiki is experimental.
For now, this Wiki is experimental.

rule.message: Use "now", or if you really must "currently". Sometimes a specific time is meant and "then" is better.
rule.example: At this time, Churchill was serving as Chancellor of the Exchequer
Churchill was then serving as Chancellor of the Exchequer

rule.message: Use now, or if you really must currently
rule.example: This document has no formal standing at this point in time.
This document has no formal standing now.

rule.message: Use now, or if you really must currently
rule.example: At the moment, I am taking a leave of absence from my work.
Now, I am taking a leave of absence from my work.

rule.name: at your earliest convenience (as soon as you can)
rule.message: Overly formal. Did you mean as soon as you can?
rule.example: Please come at your earliest convenience.
Please come as soon as you can.

rule.name: on a x basis
rule.message: Replace with the proper adverbial form of \3ly.
rule.example: We have been coming here on a regular basis for years.
We have been coming here regularly for years.

rule.name: be advised
rule.message: Remove wordy "\1 \2"
rule.example: You are advised look after your belongings.
Look after your belongings.

rule.name: wordy phrase: due to the fact
rule.message: Remove wordy "\1 \2 \3 \4 \5"
rule.example: The experiment was halted due to the fact that funding was withdrawn.

rulegroup.name: Some phrases that can be simplified

rule.message: Did you mean because of?
rule.example: His lack of conversation is attributable to his shyness.
His lack of conversation is because of his shyness.

rule.message: Did you mean because or since?
rule.example: Nader had to cancel his planned invasion in light of the fact that the Abdali Afghans had rebelled and invaded Khorasan.
Nader had to cancel his planned invasion because the Abdali Afghans had rebelled and invaded Khorasan.

rule.message: Legal term "by reason of insanity" is influencing the use. Did you mean because of?
rule.example: A national emergency exists by reason of the terrorist attacks.
A national emergency exists because of the terrorist attacks.

rule.message: Did you mean because?
rule.example: These two syndromes are usually referred to under one name, Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome, due to the fact that they are part of the same etiology.
These two syndromes are usually referred to under one name, Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome, because they are part of the same etiology.

rule.message: Did you mean because?
rule.example: The Stoors also had their own dialect of Hobbitish, owing to the fact that they spent some time in Dunland.
The Stoors also had their own dialect of Hobbitish, because they spent some time in Dunland.

rule.name: belated (late)
rule.message: Outdated. Did you mean late?
rule.example: They are on a belated honeymoon.
They are on a late honeymoon.

rule.name: by means of (by, with, through)
rule.message: Did you mean by, with or through?
rule.example: Major forest areas are coming back by means of natural processes.
Major forest areas are coming back through natural processes.
I opened the bottle by means of a bottle opener.
I opened the bottle with a bottle opener.

rule.name: clearly, obviously
rule.message: Something that is clear to you is not always clear to the reader. Remove "\1" unless it is necessary.
rule.example: Obviously, this is important.
This is important.
We have clearly arrived.
We have arrived.

rule.name: currently
rule.message: Omit or replace with now
rule.example: I am currently employed.
I am now employed.

rule.name: each and every (every)
rule.message: Replace with \3 \4
rule.example: You better check each and every door.
You better check every door.

rule.name: end result or product
rule.message: Remove repetitive "\1" with \2
rule.example: The end result is clear.
The result is clear.

rule.name: for all intents and purposes (omit)
rule.message: See if you could remove this phrase.
rule.example: The era in which we must aggressively defend our woodlands has, for all intents and purposes, passed.
The era in which we must aggressively defend our woodlands has passed.

rule.name: for the most part (omit)
rule.message: See if you could remove this phrase.
rule.example: For the most part people's suspicions are based on a misunderstanding of the facts.
People's suspicions are based on a misunderstanding of the facts.

rule.name: for the purpose of (to, for)
rule.message: Did you mean to or for?
rule.example: Commercial shows are one-off projects put on for the purpose of making money.
Commercial shows are one-off projects put on to make money.
She created an account for the purpose of asking questions at the forum.
She created an account for asking questions at the forum.

rule.name: have the ability to (be able to, can)
rule.message: Did you mean can?
rule.example: The toddle has the ability to walk.
The toddle can walk.

rule.name: have a tendency (tends)
rule.message: Did you mean tends?
rule.example: This policy has a tendency to isolate some communities.
This policy tends to isolate some communities.

rule.name: in a manner of speaking (omit)
rule.message: See if you could remove this phrase.
rule.example: The policy has, in a manner of speaking, begun to Balkanize the more rural parts of our state.
The policy has begun to Balkanize the more rural parts of our state.

rule.name: in a very real sense (omit)
rule.message: See if you could remove this phrase.
rule.example: In a very real sense, this policy works to the detriment of those it is supposed to help.
This policy works to the detriment of those it is supposed to help.

rule.name: in excess of (more than, over, exceeding)
rule.message: Better with more than, over, or exceeding
rule.example: Her three albums have sold in excess of 17 million copies worldwide
Her three albums have sold more than 17 million copies worldwide

rule.name: in my opinion (omit)
rule.message: See if you could remove this phrase.
rule.example: In my opinion, this wasteful policy ought to be revoked.
This wasteful policy ought to be revoked.

rule.name: in term of (in terms of)
rule.message: The phrase is always written in terms of.
rule.example: Femininity is still defined in term of beauty.
Femininity is still defined in terms of beauty.

rule.name: in terms of (in, for)
rule.message: Change to in or for.
rule.example: Disclaimers vary in terms of their uniformity.
Disclaimers vary in their uniformity.

rulegroup.name: despite the fact that, in spite of the fact that (although, though)

rule.message: Did you mean although, even though or though?
rule.example: He still loves her despite the fact that she cheated on him.
He still loves her even though she cheated on him.

rule.message: Did you mean although, even though or though?
rule.example: He still loves her in spite of the fact that she cheated on him.
He still loves her even though she cheated on him.

rule.name: in the affirmative (yes, affirmatively)
rule.message: Change to yes or affirmatively.
rule.example: The poll asked average Israelis if they support such a program, and 82 percent responded in the affirmative.
The poll asked average Israelis if they support such a program, and 82 percent responded yes.

rule.name: in the case of (about, to)
rule.message: Change to about or to and change the word order of the sentence.
rule.example: In the case of this particular policy, citizens of northeast Connecticut became very upset.
Citizens of northeast Connecticut became very upset about this particular policy.
In the case of this woman, we'll not grant permission.
We'll not grant permission to this woman.

rule.name: in the event of, in the event that (if, in case)
rule.message: Did you mean if or in case of?
rule.example: In the event that I can't come back by seven, you can eat without me.
If I can't come back by seven, you can eat without me.
In the event of rain, the race will be cancelled.
In the event that it rains, the race will be canceled.
If it rains, the race will be canceled.

rule.name: in the final or last or ultimate analysis (finally, in conclusion)
rule.message: Did you mean finally or in conclusion? You could remove the phase, too.
rule.example: In the final analysis, it is their war.
Finally, it is their war.
In the ultimate analysis, only the jury can strip a man of his liberty or his life.
In conclusion, only the jury can strip a man of his liberty or his life.

rule.name: in the nature of (like)
rule.message: Did you mean like"?
rule.example: Something in the nature of a repeal may soon take place.
Something like a repeal may soon take place.

rule.name: in the neighborhood of (about)
rule.message: Can be used as almost, approximately, more or less, around. Often about.
rule.example: They searched for the keys in the neighborhood of the playground.
They searched for the keys around the playground.
Residents planted 1200 trees in one day in the neighborhood of Ballard.
Residents planted 1200 trees in one day around Ballard.

rule.name: in the process of
rule.message: Possibly empty phrase "\1 \2 \3 \4" when it means "currently".
rule.example: The work is in the process of getting done.
The work is getting done.

rule.name: it seems that (omit)
rule.message: Possibly empty phrase "\1 \2 \3"
rule.example: It seems that they can't wait to get rid of this one.
They can't wait to get rid of this one.

rule.name: majority (most, usually) when not voting
rule.message: Majority in the sense of "more than half" is used with countable nouns only (esp. when voting); for uncountable nouns, use most or usually.
rule.example: Majority of the world is covered with water.
Most of the world is covered with water.

rule.name: make decisions about (decide on)
rule.message: Did you mean decide on?
rule.example: The school board will make decision about the first day of school.
The school board will decide on the first day of school.

rule.name: make an attempt/effort/try (try)
rule.message: Can you write try and still be correct?
rule.example: We should make an effort to win.
We should try to win.
He's making an attempt to win the gold medal.
He's trying to win the gold medal.
.. and others at least made a try to get into a good job.
Evan Browne needed to make a try saving tackle just short of the try line.

rule.name: not able (unable)
