rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean unable?
rule.example: He was not able to join the meeting.
He was unable to join the meeting.

rule.name: not accept (reject)
rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean reject?
rule.example: He does not accept the proposal.
He rejects the proposal.

rule.name: not certain (uncertain)
rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean uncertain?
rule.example: Future is not certain.
Future is uncertain.

rule.name: not unlike (similar, alike)
rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean similar or alike?
rule.example: Sisters were not unlike.
Sisters were alike.

rule.name: not many (few)
rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean few?
rule.example: Not many people know this.
Few people know this.

rule.name: not often, not very often (seldom. rare, rarely)
rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean seldom, rare or rarely?
rule.example: It is not very often that a hotel exceeds your expectations.
It is rare that a hotel exceeds your expectations.

rule.name: not the same (different)
rule.message: Avoid using "not". Did you mean different?
rule.example: The taste is not the same.
The taste is different.

rule.name: obtain (get)
rule.message: Did you mean simpler get?
rule.example: We need to obtain visas.
We need to get visas.

rule.name: on the occasion of (on, when, because of)
rule.message: Did you mean on? Try also when and because of.
rule.example: I was congratulated on the occasion of my son's birthday.
I was congratulated on my son's birthday.

rule.name: on the other hand (omit, but, yet)
rule.message: Avoid completely or try but, yet
rule.example: It was quite a good bargain. On the other hand, do we really need one?
It was quite a good bargain, but do we really need one?

rule.name: on two separate occasions (twice)
rule.message: Did you mean twice?
rule.example: I stayed here on two separate occasions.
I stayed here twice.

rulegroup.name: question as to whether, question of whether (question whether)

rule.message: Verbose. Use whether.
rule.example: The question as to whether it will do any good hasn’t been determined.
Whether it will do any good hasn’t been determined.

rule.message: Verbose. Use question whether.
rule.example: There is a question of whether we need to be there or not.
There is question whether we need to be there or not.

rule.name: regard as being (regard as)
rule.message: Word "being" is redundant. Use \1 \2.
rule.example: What industries do you regard as being highly competitive?
What industries do you regard as highly competitive?

rule.name: solicit for
rule.message: Avoid. Use asking for.
rule.example: We are soliciting for suggestions.
We are asking for suggestions.

rule.name: sooner rather than later (soon, now)
rule.message: Try soon or now meaning sooner than expected.
rule.example: I believe that spring will be here sooner rather than later.
I believe that spring will be here soon.

rule.message: Use latest.
rule.example: Many covet for a state-of-the-art cell phone.
Many covet for a latest cell phone.

rule.message: Use latest.
rule.example: Many covet for a state of the art cell phone.
Many covet for a latest cell phone.

rule.name: sufficient (enough)
rule.message: Use enough.
rule.example: That is sufficient reason.
That is reason enough.
He was adding more until it was sufficient.
He was adding more until it was enough.

rule.name: take action to (omit)
rule.message: Remove as verbose.
rule.example: Take action to fight climate change.
Fight climate change.

rule.name: that exists (omit)
rule.message: Try removing the phrase.
rule.example: The fear that exists among many people that we are losing our woodlands is uncalled for.
The fear among many people that we are losing our woodlands is uncalled for.

rule.name: the undersigned (I, me, we)
rule.message: Legalese. Did you mean I, me or we?
rule.example: Please contact the undersigned.
Please call me on this number.

rule.name: type of (omit)
rule.message: Try removing the phrase "\1 \2".
rule.example: Legislators need to be more careful of the type of policy they propose.
Legislators need to be more careful of the policy they propose.

rule.name: until such time as (until)
rule.message: Use until.
rule.example: He may keep the key until such time as he resigns.
He may keep the key until he resigns.

rule.name: what I mean to say is that (omit)
rule.message: Try removing the phrase.
rule.example: What I mean to say is that well intentioned lawmakers sometimes make fools of themselves.
Well intentioned lawmakers sometimes make fools of themselves.

rule.name: with/in reference to, with/in regard to (about, of, on, for, concerning, regarding)
rule.message: Replace with shorter about, of, on, for, concerning, or regarding.
rule.example: Statement in reference to the book.
Statement on the book.
What shall we do in regard to the dinner?
What shall we do with regard to the dinner?
What shall we do about the dinner?
What shall we do regarding the dinner?
This reply is in regard to your message earlier this week.
This reply concerns your message earlier this week.
This reply is about your message earlier this week.
With regard to your letter last week, …
Regarding your letter last week, …
Misunderstanding can arise in reference to how a person becomes certified or credentialed.
Misunderstanding can arise about how a person becomes certified or credentialed.
Misunderstanding can arise regarding how a person becomes certified or credentialed.
The veterinary clinic gets many calls from children with regard to lost pets.
The veterinary clinic gets many calls from children concerning lost pets.
The veterinary clinic gets many calls from children regarding lost pets.
The veterinary clinic gets many calls from children about lost pets.
This test is important with regard to the new rules.
This test is important for the new rules.
Before you do a test with regard to a rule, always include a correct example and an incorrect example.
Before you do a test of a rule, always include a correct example and an incorrect example.

rule.name: worthwhile is weak
rule.message: Weak word. Use something stronger like valuable.
rule.example: It was a worthwhile endeavor.
It was a valuable endeavor.

rule.name: you are requested (please)
rule.message: Replace with please
rule.example: you are requested to sit down.
Please sit down.

rulegroup.name: your attention is drawn, draw to your attention (please see, please note, point out)

rule.message: Replace with please see or please note
rule.example: Your attention is drawn to the last page.
Please see the last page.

rule.message: Replace with point out.
rule.example: We'd like to draw your attention to the last picture.
We'd like to point out the last picture.

rule.name: Legal jargon referring to previous text
rule.message: Legalese. Bad style in any normal text. Remove and explain. Use this or these.
rule.example: The above-mentioned fact is important.
The abovementioned fact is important.
The above-listed points must not be forgotten.
The abovelisted points must not be forgotten.
The before-mentioned fact is important.
The beforementioned fact is important.
The afore-mentioned fact is important.
The aforementioned fact is important.
Like I mentioned before, it is important not to follow rules blindly
This fact is important.

rule.name: Starting sentence with 'The truth/fact is'.
rule.message: Remove. Just say what the truth or fact is.
rule.example: The truth is, this is annoying.
This is annoying.
The fact is, they are not here.
They are not here.

rule.name: really, very, quite, extremely, severely (use sparingly)
rule.message: Usually, the word "\1" is not necessary. Remove it unless it is necessary.
rule.example: The band is very irritating.
The band is irritating.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: There are no biscuits. I myself ate the last one.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: I cannot do it for you. Only you yourself can do it.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: I cannot do it for you. Only you yourselves can do it.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: They cannot do it for us. We ourselves must do it.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: You cannot do it for him. Only he himself can do it.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: You cannot do it for her. Only she herself can do it.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: The software update is not correct. It itself causes more problems than in solves.

rule.message: Although '\1 \2' is correct, it is not always necessary. If possible, use only \1.
rule.example: You cannot do it them. Only they themselves can do it.

rule.name: Replace '#'
rule.message: Wikipedia style. Replace "#" with No. or number when referring to numbers or rankings.
rule.example: The #3
No.
number

rule.name: Replace '12 pm' with 'noon'
rule.message: Wikipedia style. Replace "12 pm" with noon for clarity.
rule.example: At 12 pm
noon

rule.name: Replace '12 am' with 'midnight'
rule.message: Wikipedia style. Replace "12 am" with midnight for clarity.
rule.example: At 12 am
midnight

rule.name: Replace 'currently' with a specific date
rule.message: Wikipedia style. Replace "currently" with a specific date, as "currently" will change over time.
rule.example: date

rule.message: Wikipedia style. Replace "wasn't" with was not.
rule.example: it's

rule.message: Wikipedia style. Replace "it's" with it is
rule.example: it is

rule.name: (TM) instead of ™
rule.message: Did you mean ™?
rule.example: The new product is Executive Choice(TM) Plus.

rule.name: (R) instead of ®
rule.message: Did you mean ®?
rule.example: Windows (R)
These are Richard Burr (D) and Kay Hagan (R).

rule.name: (c) instead of ©
rule.message: This notation is nonstandard, use this symbol instead: ©
rule.example: Copyright (C) Joanna Bator, 2012
Copyright (C) 2010 The Estate of Ezra Pound
This is a list: (a) item, (b) 2 items, (c) 2014 items.

rule.message: The currency mark is usually put at the beginning of the number: \2\1.
rule.example: You owe me 7.25$.
You owe me 100$.
You owe me 100,000€.
You owe me 2,500,000€.

rule.name: Whitespace after currency symbols: '$ 100' ($100)
rule.message: The currency mark is usually written without any whitespace: \1\2.
rule.example: You owe me $ 100.

rule.message: Use a smart opening quote here: “.
rule.example: This is a ("test").
"Test"!
“Test”!
This is another "test".

rule.message: Use a smart closing quote here: ”.
rule.example: This is a ("test")
Use a quote "here" to say something.
This is another "test".
Achilles is mentioned in the song "57821", by Janelle Monáe ft.
“Test”!
Economy class seats have a seat pitch of 31-33"
American baseball player nicknamed "The Animal"

rule.message: Use a smart opening quote here: “.
rule.example: ``Test”.

rule.message: Possibly wrong smart opening quote: “.
rule.example: „Test”.

rule.name: Smart ellipsis (…)
rule.message: Use typographical ellipsis character here instead: ….
rule.example: This is important . . . as far as I know.
This is important – as far as I know.
This is important... as far as I know.

rule.message: You used an accent character instead of an apostrophe. Please use either \1'\3 or \1’\3.
rule.example: You shouldn´t do it!

rule.message: You used an accent character instead of an apostrophe. Please use either \1'\3 or \1’\3.
rule.example: She´ll make a decision tomorrow.

rule.message: You used an accent character instead of an apostrophe. Please use either \1'\3 or \1’\3.
rule.example: I´ll be here.

rule.message: You used an accent character instead of an apostrophe. Please use either \1'\3 or \1’\3.
rule.example: You´ll have to decide.

rule.message: Did you mean \1'\3 or \1’\3?
rule.example: You shouldn;t do it!
I couldn t do it!

rule.name: Apostrophe in dates
rule.message: Apostrophes aren't needed for decades: .
rule.example: Hillary Clinton asked where Bernie Sanders was in the 1990's.
Hillary Clinton asked where Bernie Sanders was in the 90's.
Where were you in the 1990’s?
Disc wheels replaced the Alvis 12/70's wire wheels and are fitted with larger tyres.

rule.name: action
rule.message: In EU texts, the word 'action' is used countably with a meaning akin to 'scheme', 'measure' or 'project'. Where 'action' is used countably with this meaning, use one of those words.
rule.example: Action 1 Measure 1.1 - Town twinning citizens' meetings - EUR 5896000
Measures may include specific actions for the development of e-Government.
Refer to these projects:
When you action these tasks…
If you frequently action these tasks…
When the technician actions these tasks…

rule.name: actor
rule.message: An actor is 'a person who acts in a play, film, broadcast, etc.' or 'a person who puts on a false manner in order to deceive others'. In EU usage, 'actors' are often simply 'the people and/or organisations involved in doing something'. Rework the sentence to avoid the problem. Identify who you are talking about ('international aid organisations', for example) and using the term.
rule.example: … which have been supported by the EU and endorsed by various international actors.
Municipalities represent a major actor of the required change…
… which have been supported by the EU and endorsed by various international organisations.

rule.name: actorness
rule.message: This word is an extraordinary creation… that is both quite impenetrable and slightly childish. Alternatives: participation, involvement.
rule.example: EU Actorness in International Affairs: The Case of EULEX Mission in Kosovo.
EU Participation in International Affairs: The Case of EULEX Mission in Kosovo.
If the actornesses of the EU are…
If the involvement of the EU is…

rule.name: actual
rule.message: 'Actual' is sometimes used to refer to something that is happening now. However, in English it means 'real' or 'existing'. Alternatives: current, present.
rule.example: This appropriation is… based on the actual regulations and on the probable adjustments.
This appropriation is… based on the current regulations and on the probable adjustments.

rule.name: adequate
rule.message: 'Adequate' is frequently used with the meaning of 'appropriate'. However, its actual meaning is closer to 'satisfactory' or sometimes even 'barely satisfactory'. Alternatives: appropriate, suitable, fitting.
rule.example: The collection of the data should be adequate and proportionate to the objectives pursued.
The collection of the data should be suitable and proportionate to the objectives pursued.

rule.message: An agenda is 'a list or programme of things to be done or considered'. It is not a book in which you write your appointments. Alternatives: diary.
rule.example: Write the time of the meeting in your agenda.
Write the time of the meeting in your diary.

rule.message: An agenda is 'a list or programme of things to be done or considered'. It is not a book in which you write your appointments. Alternatives: diaries.
rule.example: Three agendas were found in the meeting room.
Three diaries were found in the meeting room.

rule.name: agent
rule.message: In British English, an 'agent' works for a government intelligence agency (CIA, MOSSAD, MI5, G2), runs or represents a service agency (travel agent, estate agent), or represents a company in its dealings with the public (ticket agent, baggage agent, call-centre agent). Alternatives: staff, employee.
rule.example: The problem of vacancies mainly concerns contract agents.
Agents must not use this car park.
If you are an agent of the EU who has…
The problem of vacancies mainly concerns contract staff.
Employees must not use this car park.

rule.name: aids
rule.message: The word 'aid' is uncountable when it has the meaning of 'assistance'. With an '-s', it refers to a disease (AIDS) or to devices that help you do something (e.g. 'hearing aids' or 'teaching aids'). Alternatives: aid, subsidies.
rule.example: State aids — Decisions to propose appropriate measures pursuant to Article 108(1).
This medication aids the recovery of most patients.

rule.name: aim (with the aim to)
rule.message: There are 634 instances of 'with the aim to (do something) in Eurlex. 'With the aim to' takes 'of' + the gerund. Alternatives: with the aim of (doing something), with a view to (doing something, not do something).
rule.short: EU English: with the aim to

example.correction: with the aim of|with a view to

rule.example: List of specific recommendations from the Commission with the aim to reduce the administrative burden of REACH by SMEs.
List of specific recommendations from the Commission with the aim of reducing the administrative burden…

rule.name: allow (to), permit (to), enable (to)
rule.message: When used to mean 'make it possible to', 'allow to', 'permit to', and 'enable to' cannot be used without a grammatical object. 'Allow' must be followed by a noun or pronoun such as 'us'. Alternatives: make it possible to, allow us to, enable us to, allow (an assessment) of.
rule.example: The statistics available do not allow to take account of all these situations.
… if the function allows to assess whether the subsystem fully complies with…
These persons are not allowed to do the work:
You are permitted to do the work unless you…
The statistics available do not allow us to take account of all these situations.

rule.name: Anglo-Saxon
rule.message: The term 'Anglo-Saxon' is generally used to describe 'a member of any of the West Germanic tribes (Angles, Saxons, and Jutes) that settled in Britain from the 5th century AD'. Also, in America, it is used to denominate white people, usually of the Protestant faith ('WASPS'). Alternatives: English-speaking when referring to the countries or the people, British and American ('Australian' or whatever) when referring to agencies, capitalism etc.
rule.example: The Anglo-Saxon group of agencies are…
… Anglo-Saxon capitalism which was not disrupted by two world wars and the specific operational issues relating to Asian economies.

rule.name: animate
rule.message: Every now and then a job advertisement appears, saying that the Commission is looking for a 'head of sector to animate 12 staff members'. The new employee will find that he/she is expected to lead or head a team.
rule.example: The Commission is looking for a head of sector to animate 12 staff members.
An EU Internal Security Consultative Forum animated by the Commission together with…
The continuation of the process… is expected to be animated by the Director of Budget Execution.

rule.name: anti-
rule.message: The UK has a fraud office, a national crime agency, drug squads and vice squads. In the EU, we have the European Anti Fraud Office, anti-crime policies, anti-drugs trafficking, and anti-cyber crime investigation. You can usually remove 'anti-'. Alternatives: \2
rule.example: These threats are outlined in the framework of the Commission anti-cyber crime policy.
The rapid exchange of information between VAT anti-fraud units in different Member States is important.
Anti-crime policies are a necessary prerequisite to the…
ANTI-CRIME POLICIES:
An anti-drugs trafficking investigation is necessary.
This anti-depressant is good.
These anti-depressants are very good.
If anti-inflammatory drugs cannot be used…

rule.message: The verb 'articulate' normally means 'to put something into words' (e.g. 'he tried to articulate his fears'). Used intransitively, it means 'to speak' or 'to enunciate'. In EU texts, on the other hand, 'articulate' is commonly used to mean coordinate, link together, connect, organise, structure.
rule.example: The European Parliament… urges Turkey to articulate with the Iraqi Government, and other neighbours, …
The European Parliament… urges Turkey to coordinate with the Iraqi Government, and other neighbours, …
The strategy is articulated (= structured?) around four main 'pillars'.
The main challenge is to articulate (=coordinate?) the work of the groups.
This document articulates the work of the research group.
Articulating the problems is the first step to resolving them.

rule.message: 'Articulation' is 'the act or process of speaking or expressing in words'; it is also a synonym for a joint (principally in anatomy, botany and mechanics) and, by extension, the 'state of being jointed together'. Alternatives: coordination, link, structure.
rule.example: This includes an appropriate articulation with the Cohesion policy funds.
Ensure greater consistency between product policies by better coordinating the articulation, revision and implementation of the different policy instruments.
This includes an appropriate coordination with the Cohesion policy funds.
This includes an appropriate link with the Cohesion policy funds.
Articulations in the Cohesion policy funds must…
Coordination in the Cohesion policy funds must…
Links in the Cohesion policy funds must…
Structures in the Cohesion policy funds must…

rule.name: assist at
rule.message: 'Assist at' is archaic in the meaning of 'attend'. Alternatives: attend, be present at.
rule.example: Officials of the Commission assist at the meetings of the Committee and the working groups.
She usually assists at the meetings of the Committee.
He assisted at the meetings of the Committee.
Assisting at the meetings of the Committee is necessary.
Officials of the Commission attend the meetings of the Committee and the working groups.

rule.name: attestation
rule.message: Attestation is not a common word in English and its most frequent meaning is: 'the act of attending the execution of a document and bearing witness to its authenticity'. It is not normally a synonym for certificate.
rule.example: … is a necessary and sufficient condition for an attestation of conformity.
These attestations are not satisfactory.
… is a necessary and sufficient condition for a certificate of conformity.

rule.message: If you attribute something to someone, you are saying that he is thought to have made it/produced it. You can also attribute something to a cause ('The EIB attributes this relative underperformance… to the financial crisis'). You cannot, however, attribute aid, compensation, contracts or licences. Alternatives: allocate, grant, give, award, assign.
rule.example: The contracting authority can attribute a contract to the company if…
When the authority attributes one or more licences, the…
The contracting authority attributed a service contract to the company.
Attributing a service contract without…
The contracting authority can award a contract to the company if…
This unusual attribute of the data is an aid to the…
But, these attributes and conditions are not always a problem with respect to compensation.
The EIB attributes this relative underperformance to the financial crisis.

rule.message: If you attribute something to someone, you are saying that he is thought to have made it/produced it. You can also attribute something to a cause ('The EIB attributes this relative underperformance… to the financial crisis'). You cannot, however, attribute aid, compensation, contracts or licences. Alternatives: allocate, grant, give, award, assign.
rule.example: The contracts were attributed on 21 March.
Contracts: when you attribute these, you must…
Licence -- the authority attributes one or more as necessary.
Compensation: Attributing without…
The contracts were awarded on 21 March.
This licence has an unusual attribute in that the…
But, for compensation, these attributes and conditions are not always a problem.
The EIB attributes this relative underperformance to the financial crisis.

rule.name: axis
rule.message: The use of the word 'axis' that is often found in EU documents ('a coherent group of measures with specific goals') appears to derive from the French (possibly from the meaning 'general direction' cited in the 'Petit Robert'). This usage does not exist in English, where the word is used primarily in geometry, anatomy and politics ('the Axis powers' or the 'axis of evil'). Curiously, in EU texts, 'axes' can also be roads, particularly important ones. Use: depending on the context: priority axis = priority; road axis = road (sometimes trunk road); strategic axis = strategic priority etc. If you have to use the EU term here, you really do need to explain it.
rule.example: … shall be calculated by applying the co-financing rate for each priority axis laid down by the Commission decision.
… reduced the ERDF assistance granted to the Operational Programme "Access and Road axes" for the period 1994-1999.

rule.name: badge (badge, to badge)
rule.message: Although the use of the word 'badge' to mean 'service pass' seems to have gained currency in the English speaking world, it can still not be used to describe a lunch card or the little tag you use to clock in and out at work. Generally speaking it must be something attached to or worn on your outer clothing. There is also no verb 'to badge' in this context. Alternatives: tag for the clocking-in device, and clock in or clock out for the verb. In the school example, the object is actually a lunch card.
rule.example: New topping up system for your children's badges at the European School.
New topping up system for your children's lunch card at the European School.
… there is a flexi-time badge reader in the cafeteria hall.
Until the badging systems have been harmonised (entry and flexi-time), there is a…
Until the tagging systems have been harmonised (entry and flexi-time), there is a…
New topping up system for your children's badge at the European School.
New topping up system for your children's lunch cards at the European School.

rulegroup.name: bovine, ovine, caprine, porcine and asinine animals

rule.message: Bovine animals are 'any of various chiefly domesticated mammals of the genus Bos, including cows, steers, bulls, and oxen, often raised for meat and dairy products'. These animals are normally called 'cattle' in English.
rule.example: … as regards model certificates relating to the importation of bovine animals for slaughter and…
… and bovine fresh meat.

rule.message: Ovine animals are sheep. The term 'ovine' would only be known to specialists.
rule.example: … as regards model certificates relating to the importation of ovine animals for slaughter and…
… and ovine fresh meat.

rule.message: Caprine animals aregoats. The term 'caprine' would only be known to specialists.
rule.example: … and caprine fresh meat.

rule.message: Porcine animals are pigs. The term 'porcine' would only be known to specialists.
rule.example: … and porcine fresh meat.
… and fresh meat from pigs.
… and fresh pig meat.

rule.message: Asinine animals are asses (perhaps 'donkeys' would be a better word these days). The term 'asinine' would only be known to specialists. However, 'asinine' is relatively common, in the meaning 'extremely stupid or foolish.
rule.example: … and asinine animals.
… and donkeys.

rule.name: budget line
rule.message: 'Budget line' is used so often that it has begun to sound right. However, it does not exist in English in the sense in which it is used in the EU institutions. Furthermore, there is no consensus as to what 'budget line' actually refers to (some say 'budget heading' and some 'budget item'). The dictionary definition of 'budget line' is 'the alternative combinations of two different goods that can be purchased with a given income and given prices of the two goods'. Alternatives: budget heading, budget item, budget title.
rule.example: These are DG and Culture (DG EAC) for budget line 15, …
These are DG and Culture (DG EAC) for budget item 15, …
Budget lines:
Use these budget headings:

rule.name: cabinet
rule.message: 'Cabinet' (usually pronounced 'cabinay' by English-speaking EU officials and 'cabinet' by others) is the term used at the Commission (and informally at the Court of Auditors) to refer to the private office of a Commissioner (or Member). Other than denoting a piece of furniture, the term is most commonly used in Britain to refer to 'the senior ministers of the British Government'. The 'British cabinet' is therefore 'the principal executive group of British government' and not the private office of the British member of the Commission or Court or the staff thereof. Alternatives: private office, office.
rule.example: Go to the British cabinet.
Go to the office of the British member of the Commission.
The Cabinet Office is a UK government department (https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/cabinet-office).

rule.name: case (in case /in case of)
rule.message: 'In case of' does not mean 'for' and 'in case' (without of) is not an elegant way of saying 'if, 'when' or 'where'. This may sound a trifle odd to people in 'Brussels', where we often find sentences like 'farmers are subject to possible reductions in case of non-compliance' (= for non-compliance) and 'the fund can be mobilised in case the damage caused by a national disaster exceeds the threshold' (= where it exceeds the threshold)… In regular English 'in case of' is most commonly used in sentences that follow the pattern: 'in case of fire, break glass' (i.e. 'in the event of an (adverse) occurrence, act as follows') and 'in case' (no of) means 'in the event that', or just 'if'.
rule.short: EU English: case (in case /in case of)
rule.example: Farmers are… subject to possible reduction of the grubbing-up premium in case of non-compliance with certain requirements.
In case of pigs and poultry, at least 20 % of the feed shall come from the farm unit itself
The likelihood of continuation of dumping in case the measures would be (sic) allowed to lapse is examined in the following
The fund can be mobilised in case the damages (sic) caused by a national disaster exceed the threshold of three billion euro.

rule.name: citizen
rule.message: 'Citizen' has become something of a buzzword that EU authors like to include in their texts, presumably to emphasize the concept of 'European citizenship', as introduced under the Maastricht treaty. Actually, this word is decidedly less common in English than in some other languages and, in native texts, it is nearly always used to mean 'a legally recognized subject or national of a state or commonwealth'. The emphasis is very much on nationality, so, for example, if we say that 'steps have been taken to help citizens get back to work', we imply that non-citizens are not expected to benefit. Use 'citizen' only if you really mean 'citizen' and particularly if you wish to exclude non-citizens. Otherwise, use the public, people, taxpayer.
rule.example: Tax on citizens travelling from airports within the EU.
The budget should be a responsible use of citizens' money.
… are promoting ways to increase effectiveness for each citizen.
Tax on people travelling from airports within the EU.
… are promoting ways to increase effectiveness for the public and improve value for money.
The budget should be a responsible use of taxpayers' money.

rule.name: coherent/coherence
rule.message: Coherent means 'logical; consistent and orderly' or 'capable of logical and orderly thought'. In the former meaning, it is generally an internal characteristic of an argument or a publication, for example, and in the latter meaning, it is an internal characteristic of a person (e.g. 'he is totally incoherent, he must have been drinking'). In the EU, on the other hand, it is frequently used with the meaning of 'in agreement with' or 'accordant with' (something else). Alternatives: consistent, consistency.
rule.example: The Framework Programme is coherent with the objectives of the SET-Plan.
The Framework Programme is consistent with the objectives of the SET-Plan.

rule.name: college
rule.message: In the English-speaking world, 'college' normally refers to one type of educational establishment or another (university college, Eton College, etc.). It can also be a body of electors ('electoral college'). In the EU, it is used to mean the actual Court or Commission, as opposed to the institution and its staff. The only context where it is traditionally used in a similar meaning is the ecclesiastical Latinism: 'the college of cardinals' (from Collegium Cardinalium). The term 'college of Commissioners' has become enshrined in EU usage, but we should use the word sparingly when referring to other bodies. Especially when it is used in isolation ('the college' tout court), readers outside the institutions may think we are referring to a school of some sort. Alternatives: Court, Commission. If it is necessary to specify beyond doubt that it was the actual Court, we can say 'the Court itself' or 'the Court's members' ('the Members of the Commission') or even just 'the Members' (or the 'Commissioners').
rule.example: … to be adopted by the College before the 2007 summer break.
… to be adopted by the Commission before the 2007 summer break.

rule.name: comitology
rule.message: There are 1,253 instances of the word 'comitology' in EUR Lex. However, not only does the word not exist outside the EU institutions, but it is formed from a misspelt stem (committee has two 'm's and two 't's) and a suffix that means something quite different (ology/logy means 'the science of' or 'the study of') . It is therefore highly unlikely that an outsider would be able to deduce its meaning, even in context. The official term is 'committee procedure'.
rule.example: … in the framework of the now-abolished comitology procedure, to ensure that the new system operates properly.
… in the framework of the committee procedure.

rule.name: competences
rule.message: 'Competence' in its meaning of 'the legal authority of a court or other body to deal with a particular matter' is uncountable in English and therefore does not usually take a plural. We normally speak of the 'powers' of bodies or institutions rather than their 'competences'. Alternatives: powers, jurisdiction.
rule.example: This Directive fully respects the competences of Member States, …
This Directive fully respects the jurisdiction of Member States, …

rule.name: complete
rule.message: To 'complete' means to finish, end or terminate. It therefore implies that whatever is being completed was somehow incomplete. In EU texts, however, this word is often used to mean that something extra has been added to supplement something that, in itself, was actually complete beforehand. Alternatives: supplement, add to.
rule.example: They proposed a Regulation to complete Regulation (EC) No 1347/2000, aimed at facilitating…
They proposed a Regulation to supplement Regulation (EC) No 1347/2000, aimed at facilitating…
They proposed a Regulation to add to Regulation (EC) No 1347/2000, aimed at facilitating…
The new Regulation completes Regulation (EC) No…
The new Regulation supplements Regulation (EC) No…
The new Regulation adds to Regulation (EC) No…
The new Regulation completed Regulation (EC) No…
All the new Regulations that are completing other Regulations…

rule.name: concern (concerning, for what concerns)
rule.message: We often find paragraphs in reports that begin with 'concerning XYZ, the Court found that…', instead of 'with regard to'. This sounds very odd in English. The rather endearing Gallicism 'for what concerns' is also remarkably common, even in published documents (30 hits in EUR Lex, many of which are recent). In English, there is usually no need to start a sentence with a direct reference to the subject matter, as you would in certain other languages, and a different word-order might be better. Furthermore, where this introductory phrase merely repeats the paragraph heading, it should be eliminated altogether. Alternatives: with regard to, in respect of, in terms of.
rule.short: EU English: concern (concerning, for what concerns)

example.correction: With regard to|In respect of|In terms of

rule.example: Concerning the achievement[s] of the six EFA goals, the PEDP report reports that sound progress is being made…

example.correction: with regard to|in respect of|in terms of

rule.example: For what concerns resettlement, Member States will receive financial incentives (lump sums) every two years…

rule.name: concerned
rule.message: A number of adjectives in English have a different meaning when used after the noun. One of these is 'concerned'. Before the noun, it means 'worried', after the noun, it means 'involved in or affected by something'. A concerned official is therefore one that is worried about something, whereas if you want to contact the official responsible for something, you should write to the official concerned. Alternatives: \2 \1
rule.example: This list should not be used in order to target the concerned officials with a marketing campaign or to profile them…
This list should not be used in order to target the officials concerned with a marketing campaign or to profile them…
… and reach out [to] interested and concerned stakeholders at national, regional and local level.
It will allow the objectives of the Year to penetrate more easily and reach out [to] stakeholders at national, regional and local level.

rule.name: conditionality
rule.message: 'Conditionality' is a clumsy word that should be used parsimoniously. Moreover, it is not an erudite synonym of 'condition' but a derivative of 'conditional' and means simply 'the state of being conditional'. Finally, it is an uncountable noun that cannot be used in the plural, despite the 156 plural hits in Eurlex. Alternatives: condition or 'the conditions imposed/set'.
rule.example: … possible for you to influence conditionalities.
… possible for you to influence conditions.
… and this conditionality has a…

rule.name: conference
rule.message: In-house terminology uses 'conference' to refer to a simple talk or lecture, where one speaker comes to impart his knowledge on a given subject. In English, a conference is 'a high-level meeting for consultation or exchange of information or discussion with a number of speakers, often lasting several days', like the Kyoto conference, or in the legal context, a one-to-one meeting between a barrister and his client. Alternatives: talk, lecture, presentation.
rule.example: … the Medical Service is organizing a conference on Tuesday 12 October… A specialist doctor, M. Vic Arendt, will answer any of your questions.
… the Medical Service is organizing a lecture on Tuesday 12 October….
The two conferences are each an hour long.
When you conference with the manager…
The technicians conferenced with the manager.
The you go to the Standards Conference, …

rule.name: consider as
rule.message: The American heritage book of English usage states that, in 'consider as', the 'as' is 'not sufficiently well established to be acceptable in writing'. In any case, it is redundant. Alternatives: consider or consider to be.
rule.example: This increase is considered as adequate and in line with the rules.
This increase is considered adequate and in line with the rules.
The Commission did not issue guidance on what you should consider as a 'new product or new technique'.
The Commission considers as adequate the new proposal.
Considering as the proposal is satisfactory…

rule.name: contractual (agent)
rule.message: 'Contractual' means 'laid down in a contract' (e.g. 'contractual terms'), it does not mean 'under contract'. Although the term is widely used in this latter way in the institutions, it does not appear at all in the current Staff Regulations or in the Conditions of Employment of other Servants. Alternatives: contract staff.
rule.example: … Temporary agents (officials seconded by the Commission and agents recruited by the agency) | Contractual agents | Seconded national experts | Total
… Temporary agents (officials seconded by the Commission and agents recruited by the agency) | Contract staff | Seconded national experts | Total

rule.name: contradictory procedure
rule.message: 'Contradictory procedure' does not exist in English as a fixed expression, although, of course, a procedure can be contradictory. The EU's financial regulation lays down 'adversarial procedure' as the technical term for the Court's hearing of the Commission with regard to its findings. However, 'contradictory procedure' is still used outside this context and we should bear in mind that people beyond our immediate circle will not understand it. In most cases, it is better to drop the legalese and rework the sentence in layman's terms.
rule.example: … to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations, followed by a "contradictory procedure" on the final text of the audit report.
The rights of the operators should be guaranteed through a contradictory procedure with its Flag State…
… to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations, followed by a "adversarial procedure" on the final text of the audit report.
The rights of the operators should be guaranteed through a adversarial procedure with its Flag State…
The paying agency held two contradictory procedures with the farmer.
The paying agency called the farmer in two times to discuss the matter.

rule.message: To control does not usually mean 'to audit' 'check' or 'verify' and 'a control' is not normally 'a check' or 'an inspection'. Its most common meaning is 'to exercise authoritative or dominating influence over; direct'. Thus, if we say that 'the Commission controlled project X in the Member States', we do not mean that the Commission audited it, but that the Commission ran it. Used as a noun, we do not 'carry out' or 'perform' controls. Controls are more likely to be systems that are in place (passport controls, for example). Hence, we can say that the Court checked to see if the key controls were working, but not that it carried out controls. Furthermore, when talking about systems, the best term will often be 'safeguard'. Alternatives: audit, check, verify, inspect, inspection, safeguard.
rule.short: EU English: control (to control, a control)
rule.example: Fraud occurred because the system was not controlled.
Administrative checks must cover all elements that are possible to control by administrative means.
Apart from the annual review of the reference amount, customs authorities are not obliged to carry out controls after authorisation.
When you are controlling the system…
Fraud occurred because the system was not audited.
Administrative checks must cover all elements that are possible to audit by administrative means.

rule.message: To control does not usually mean 'to audit' 'check' or 'verify' and 'a control' is not normally 'a check' or 'an inspection'. Its most common meaning is 'to exercise authoritative or dominating influence over; direct'. Thus, if we say that 'the Commission controlled project X in the Member States', we do not mean that the Commission audited it, but that the Commission ran it. Used as a noun, we do not 'carry out' or 'perform' controls. Controls are more likely to be systems that are in place (passport controls, for example). Hence, we can say that the Court checked to see if the key controls were working, but not that it carried out controls. Furthermore, when talking about systems, the best term will often be 'safeguard'. Alternatives: audit, check, verify, inspect, inspection, safeguard.
rule.short: EU English: control (to control, a control)
rule.example: A number of controls are built into the system.
This control is satisfactory.
A number of safeguards are built into the system.
This check is satisfactory.

rule.message: In British and Irish usage, a 'dean' is either a relatively senior priest or the head of a university faculty. At the Court of Auditors, on the other hand, it is the name given to the doyen or chair of the institution's audit chambers. 'Dean' is now the official title at the Court, but, in our dealings with the outside world, we should not be surprised if people think that we have our own in-house clergy. Alternatives: chair, chairwoman, chairman, chairperson, doyen.
rule.example: Each of the deans must…
Each of the chairpersons must…
Tell Mr. Deans to go to reception.
Elect one Member as a dean.
The Deans must…

rule.message: In British and Irish usage, a 'dean' is either a relatively senior priest or the head of a university faculty. At the Court of Auditors, on the other hand, it is the name given to the doyen or chair of the institution's audit chambers. 'Dean' is now the official title at the Court, but, in our dealings with the outside world, we should not be surprised if people think that we have our own in-house clergy. Alternatives: Chair, Chairwoman, Chairman, Chairperson, Doyen.
rule.example: Each Chamber shall elect one Member as Dean.
Each Chamber shall elect one Member as a Chairperson.
Tell Mr. Dean to go to reception.

rule.name: debriefing
rule.message: To debrief means 'to question (someone, typically a soldier or spy) about a completed mission or undertaking'. In the EU institutions, on the other hand, 'debriefing' is used to indicate 'a meeting for giving information or instructions'. This would be a briefing.
rule.example: Weekly debriefing meetings are necessary.
Weekly briefing meetings are necessary.
We plan to organise other debriefings after the evaluation meeting.
We plan to organise other briefings after the evaluation meeting.
When you are debriefing your colleagues, …
When you are briefing your colleagues, …
Colleagues were debriefed about the situation.
Colleagues were briefed about the situation.

rule.name: decommit/decommitment
rule.message: The Microsoft Word spell checker thinks that 'decommit' does not exist and the Oxford English, Oxford on-line, Merriam Webster and Macmillan dictionaries seem to agree. It follows that there is also no such thing as a 'decommitment'. Use: cancel.
rule.example: The Commission shall decommit a portion of a budget commitment…
This involves the re-entry of commitment appropriations concerning structural funds which have been decommitted.
The Commission shall cancel a portion of a budget commitment…

rule.name: deepen
rule.message: 'Deepen' is a difficult word to use figuratively. In addition to its literal meaning (e.g. deepen a well), it can also be used to mean 'to increase', 'improve' or 'boost'. However, it cannot be used indiscriminately in this way and, in this meaning, can actually only be associated with a few abstract terms like 'knowledge' or 'understanding'. Alternatives: improve, increase, bolster, boost, develop.
rule.example: Portugal shall deepen the use of shared services.
The extension of SJU would enable stakeholders to… deepen strategic partnerships.
This further deepens the internal market for defence and security.
The Commission intends deepening the dialogue with Turkey on visas.
There is clear evidence that the partnership arrangements have deepened and widened.

rule.message: In English, 'define' means 'to state the precise meaning of' (for example 'we have already defined the meaning of control'). It does not mean 'establish', 'set out', 'lay down' or 'illustrate'. Other alternatives: draft, establishment, drafting, design.
rule.example: The main task is to define and carry out the annual implementation plan.
The main tasks is to establish and carry out the annual implementation plan.
The main tasks is to set out and carry out the annual implementation plan.
When the team defines the annual implementation plan…
The team defined the annual implementation plan.
When you are defining the annual implementation plan…

rule.message: In English, 'define' means 'to state the precise meaning of' (for example 'we have already defined the meaning of control'). It does not mean 'establish', 'set out', 'lay down' or 'illustrate'. Alternatives: draft, establishment, drafting, design.
rule.example: The definition and implementation of all Union policies and activities…
The design and implementation of all Union policies and activities…
The definitions all Union policies and activities…
The establishment all Union policies and activities…
During the drafting of these policies…

rule.name: delay
rule.message: 'Delay' is often used in the EU to mean 'deadline' or 'time limit'. In English, on the other hand, 'delay' always refers to something being late or taking longer than is necessary. You cannot, therefore comply with (or 'respect') a delay. Alternatives: time limit, deadline, time allowed.
rule.example: In order to respect the delay for transmission, …
To respect the delays for transmission, …

rule.message: 'Detached' means 'separated', 'disconnected' or standing apart from others (as in 'detached house') or, in the case of a person, 'marked by an absence of (emotional) involvement'. A 'detached official' would therefore be one who worked in an objective manner (no doubt a laudable quality, but not what is usually meant). Alternatives: seconded, secondment.
rule.example: External staff comprise Local Agents, Contract Agents, Detached National Experts and Young Experts.
External staff comprise Local Agents, Contract Agents, Seconded National Experts and Young Experts.

rule.message: 'Detached' means 'separated', 'disconnected' or standing apart from others (as in 'detached house') or, in the case of a person, 'marked by an absence of (emotional) involvement'. A 'detached official' would therefore be one who worked in an objective manner (no doubt a laudable quality, but not what is usually meant). Alternatives: seconded, secondment.
rule.example: The officer responsible for detachment must…
The detachments have a duration of 6 months.
The officer responsible for secondment must…

rule.message: The most common meaning of 'dispose of' is 'to get rid of' or 'to throw away'; it never means 'to have', 'to possess' or 'to have in one's possession'. Alternatives: have, possess, xyz is/are not available to [the Commission].
rule.example: … and may not dispose of independent information sources.
… and may not have independent information sources.

rule.message: The most common meaning of 'dispose of' is 'to get rid of' or 'to throw away'; it never means 'to have', 'to possess' or 'to have in one's possession'. Alternatives: have, possess, xyz is/are not available to [the Commission].
rule.example: … and disposes of independent information sources.
… and disposed of independent information sources.
… and disposing of independent information sources.
… and has independent information sources.

rule.name: do
rule.message: 'To do' is a rather weak word: 'to perform' and 'to carry out' are often better. Using them also avoids the all too common confusion between 'to do' and 'to make'. Alternatives: perform, carry out, undertake.
rule.example: Do the statistical adjustments at national level.
Perform the statistical adjustments at national level.
The statistical adjustments done at national level…
The statistical adjustments performed at national level…
Do not test this rule.
Do you like chocolate?
I don't like chocolate.
They didn't go to Paris in the spring.
The technician did not find the cause of the error.
The does and the other animals are very timid.
How many beds does the hospital have?
Did the test give the expected result?
Anatomy and geometry are fused in one, and each does something to the other.
The wedding 'do' was a great success.

rule.name: dossier
rule.message: A 'dossier' is a file. However, it is not a particularly common word and not one that readers will necessarily fully understand or even know how to pronounce. In EU texts, in addition to being overused, it is also employed metaphorically, where there is no actual file, to mean 'subject', 'issue' or 'question'. If you mean file, use 'file', otherwise question, issue, matter, subject or even procedure.
rule.example: An amendment to the Treaty could give new momentum to this dossier.
Turkey engaged with Iran on the nuclear dossier.
The many dossiers and the complexity of the rules…
An amendment to the Treaty could give new momentum to this subject.
The many files and the complexity of the rules…

rule.name: elaborate
rule.message: To elaborate means 'to work out carefully or minutely' or 'to develop to perfection'. It does not mean to write something up. It is possible to elaborate a strategy, but not a document. Alternatives: draft, draw up, prepare.
rule.example: Refer to the information document elaborated by the Group of Experts.
Refer to the information document drafted by the Group of Experts.

rule.name: ensure (to)
rule.message: 'To ensure' means 'to make sure or certain'. However, it is often used in the EU to mean 'to provide'. 'Ensure' should never be followed by 'to' and an indirect object. Alternatives: provide with, guarantee.
rule.example: In order to ensure to patients with rare diseases…
In order to guarantee patients with rare diseases…

rule.name: enterprise
rule.message: If you look up 'enterprise' on Google images, you get pages and pages of space ships, a few aircraft carriers, a car rental firm and the odd reference to IT architecture. On the other hand, if you look up 'company', you get pages and pages of, well, companies. Alternatives: business, company and, in some cases, firm.
rule.example: Persons starting their own enterprise, including self-employment.
They enhance the entrepreneurial skills of those seeking to set up enterprises.
Persons starting their own business, including self-employment.
They enhance the entrepreneurial skills of those seeking to set up companies.

rule.name: establish
rule.message: 'Establish' is often used in the EU to mean to 'draw up' or 'draft'. In English, it actually means to 'set up', 'found' or 'secure'. You can establish a company or criteria, but not a report. Alternatives: draw up, draft, produce, prepare.
rule.example: The Agency shall establish a final inspection report.
When the Agency establishes a final inspection report…
The company established a final inspection report.
A final inspection report was established.
When the Agency is establishing a final inspection report…
The Agency shall draft a final inspection report.
The established principles of operation are…

rule.name: eventual/eventually
rule.message: Eventual means 'occurring at some unspecified time in the future', eventually means 'in the end'. However, in EU texts, these words are often used with a meaning akin to 'possible' and 'possibly'. Alternatives: possible, any, the possibility of.
rule.example: They both opposed an eventual imposition of anti-dumping measures…
The results thus obtained will be taken into consideration by the Commission with regard to an eventual new request for derogation.

rule.name: evolution
rule.message: The word 'evolution' is both heavily overused and misused in our texts. Above all, it does not sit very well with the adjective 'negative' and a 'negative evolution' is something of an oxymoron. Alternatives: development, trend, change, downturn, upturn.
rule.example: These costs lead to a negative evolution of exports.
Some evolutions can cause…
These costs lead to a downturn of exports.

rule.name: exercise
rule.message: 'Exercise' is often used in EU documents to indicate a procedure or process of some sort or a period in which something is done. Alternatives: procedure.
rule.example: The promotion exercise is different in each institution.
The promotion exercises are different in each institution.
The promotion procedure is different in each institution.

rule.message: Expertise is an uncountable noun meaning 'expert knowledge or skill in a given field' or 'expertness'. In EU documents, on the other hand, it is not only countable, but it is also used to mean 'an appraisal by an expert'. Alternatives: expertise(singular), expert advice or (expert) opinions, assessments, appraisals or evaluations.
rule.example: … in order to optimise local human resources and expertises as greatest potential drivers of growth in the ORs.

rule.message: Expertise is an uncountable noun meaning 'expert knowledge or skill in a given field' or 'expertness'. In EU documents, on the other hand, it is not only countable, but it is also used to mean 'an appraisal by an expert'. Alternatives: expertise(singular), expert advice or (expert) opinion, assessment, appraisal or evaluation.
rule.example: The authority had obtained an expertise on the question…

rule.message: Although 'externalisation' has become something of a buzzword in the UK public administration, it is a recent acquisition and has not yet reached the dictionaries or even Wikipedia, so readers may be unclear as to exactly what it means. Alternatives: outsource, outsourcing, contract out, send out.
rule.example: … the decision to externalise should be taken on a consistent basis across the European Commission…

rule.message: Although 'externalisation' has become something of a buzzword in the UK public administration, it is a recent acquisition and has not yet reached the dictionaries or even Wikipedia, so readers may be unclear as to exactly what it means. Alternatives: outsource, outsourcing, contract out, send out.
rule.example: This externalisation should be consistent across the European Commission.
These externalisations should be consistent across the European Commission.
This outsourcing should be consistent across the European Commission.

rule.name: fiche
rule.message: Fiche is a useful word, but it is French. Its only use in English is to indicate the (somewhat outdated) microfiche. Alternatives: sheet, document, record, entry.
rule.example: Where other information in the product information fiche is also provided, …
The product information fiches must, …
Where other information in the product information sheet is also provided, …

rule.name: financial envelope
rule.message: This curious term is used to mean something like: 'the total budget available for something'. This term is often defended tooth and nail by people who should really know better simply because it is believed to be in one of the sacred texts. Alternatives: budget, financial allocation.
rule.example: The overall financial envelope remains unchanged.
These financial envelopes are not correct.
The overall budget remains unchanged.
The overall financial allocation remains unchanged.
Problems, both political and financial enveloped the nation.

rule.name: fix
rule.message: The main meanings of 'fix' are to repair and to attach. It can also, be used informally to mean 'establish' or 'set' if you are talking about a date, a time or a price. It should be avoided elsewhere in this meaning. Alternatives: establish, set, set out.
rule.example: … under certain conditions fixed in the regulation (Article 145(7)), …
The framework programme shall… fix the relevant priorities.
… under certain conditions established in the regulation (Article 145(7)), …
The framework programme shall… set the relevant priorities.
The set of data was satisfactory.

rule.message: To follow up is a verb. Normally, to follow up means to pursue or investigate something further. Alternatives: monitor.
rule.example: Develop a mechanism to follow up the implementation of the recommendations.
This must be followed up as soon as possible.
Develop a mechanism to monitor the implementation of the recommendations.

rule.name: follow-up (noun)
rule.message: Follow-up (with a hyphen) is a noun. A 'follow-up' is something that is done in order to be certain that an earlier action was effective. Alternatives: monitoring.
rule.example: This allows for an adequate follow-up of the sector.
This allows for follow-ups of the sector.
This allows for an adequate monitoring of the sector.

rule.name: foresee
rule.message: People find it inexplicably difficult to use this word properly, so maybe the safest policy is to avoid it. Its basic meaning in English is 'to see something in advance' and therefore to 'predict' or 'expect'. Alternatives: envisage, plan, lay down in, set out in, provide for, contemplate, expect, predict.

example.correction: envisage|plan|lay down in|set out in|provide for|contemplate|expect|predict

rule.example: The Fleet Adjustment Schemes foresee the scrapping of 367 vessels.

example.correction: envisaged|planned|laid down in|set out in|provided for|contemplated|expected|predicted

rule.example: The Fleet Adjustment Schemes foresaw the scrapping of 367 vessels.
The Fleet Adjustment Schemes provide for the scrapping of 367 vessels.

rule.name: formulate
rule.message: Formulate is heavily over-used in our documents; it means 'to put into or express in systematic terms', 'to express in (or to express as if in) a formula' or 'to devise'. In our work, it is often overused with a meaning akin to 'draw up' or 'prepare'. Alternatives: draft, draw up, produce, prepare.
rule.example: … and one communication manager to formulate urgent safety communications.
When you are formulating the documentation, …
… and one communication manager to draft urgent safety communications.

rule.name: frame (in the frame of)
rule.message: 'In the frame of', meaning 'in connection with', 'in the context of' or 'within the scope of' corresponds literally to an expression found in a number of other languages (Italian 'nel quadro di', German 'im Rahmen von', French 'dans le cadre de'). Unfortunately, this expression does not exist in English.
rule.short: EU English: frame (in the frame of)

example.correction: in connection with|in the context of|within the scope of

rule.example: If the analysis is performed in the frame of a contamination incident, …

example.correction: in connection with|in the context of|within the scope of

rule.example: Food products would be chosen by Member State authorities in the frame of national food distribution programmes.
If the analysis is performed in connection with a contamination incident, …
If the analysis is performed in the context of a contamination incident, …
Food products would be chosen by Member State authorities under national food distribution programmes.

rule.name: global
rule.message: In English, as in other languages, global can mean both 'worldwide' and 'overall', but sometimes it can be a little confusing in this second meaning. This became clear when an internal email was sent 'to everybody' announcing that there would be 'a global power cut'. Alternatives: general or overall
rule.example: Today at 14:30, there will be a global power cut.
Today at 14:30, there will be a general power cut.

rule.name: heavy
rule.message: 'Heavy' has a number of meanings, mostly to do with weight and thickness (heavy load, heavy fog). It cannot, however, be used to render the idea that a procedure or administration is excessively complicated, slow or difficult. As well as using 'heavy' itself, EUR Lex documents try to render this concept in a number of ways (cumbersome, burdensome, and even ponderous), but they rarely sound quite right. Alternatives: complicated, excessively or unnecessarily complex/slow, etc., often unwieldy (organisation, argument), or laborious (process, procedure).
rule.example: The usual reason appears to be overly heavy administration.
The heavier administrations are…
The usual reason appears to be overly complicated administration.

rule.name: hierarchical superior
rule.message: In English, this term is used almost exclusively in the ecclesiastical context, and even 'hierarchy' and 'hierarchical' may be seen as difficult words by many readers. Alternatives: manager, line manager, boss, immediate superior, head of unit, director.
rule.example: The applicant's hierarchical superior is usually…
Some hierarchical superiors have a…
The applicant's immediate superior must always…
Some bosses have a…
The hierarchical superior tests, are as the name suggests, better than the regular tests.

rule.message: Homogenise is a rather unusual word in English (only two hits in the British National Corpus) and is most commonly used with reference to milk. 'Homogeneous' and 'homogeneously' are much more common, but they are more often found in the sciences and social sciences, and are over-used in our texts. Alternatives: , uniform.
rule.example: Member States can work together towards shared goals without seeking to homogenize their inherited policy regimes.
The homogenised texts are satisfactory.
Member States can work together towards shared goals without seeking to standardise their inherited policy regimes.

rule.message: Homogenise is a rather unusual word in English (only two hits in the British National Corpus) and is most commonly used with reference to milk. 'Homogeneous' and 'homogeneously' are much more common, but they are more often found in the sciences and social sciences, and are over-used in our texts. Alternatives: standardise, uniform.
rule.example: Homogeneous policy regimes are not necessary.
Uniform policy regimes are not necessary.

rule.message: Homogenise is a rather unusual word in English (only two hits in the British National Corpus) and is most commonly used with reference to milk. 'Homogeneous' and 'homogeneously' are much more common, but they are more often found in the sciences and social sciences, and are over-used in our texts. Alternatives: standardise, uniformly.
rule.example: Homogeneously developed policy regimes are not necessary.
Uniformly developed policy regimes are not necessary.

rule.name: important
rule.message: 'Important' is often wrongly used to mean 'big' ('the most important power station in France'); it actually means: 'strongly affecting the course of events or the nature of things' or 'having or suggesting a consciousness of high position or authority'. Alternatives: large, significant.
rule.example: … and explain the reasons for which an important amount is still to be implemented.

rule.name: incite
rule.message: To incite means to 'encourage or stir up (violent or unlawful behaviour)' or to 'urge or persuade (someone) to act in a violent or unlawful way'. You cannot therefore incite someone to buy a car, use organic farming techniques or comply with a regulation. Alternatives: encourage.
rule.example: Such activities shall not incite consumers to buy a product.
… the charging infrastructure needs to initially develop with a sufficient density to incite consumers to use such vehicles…
Such activities shall not encourage consumers to buy a product.

rule.message: 'To inform' requires a direct object (inform the public/us/them etc.) and cannot be used without one except in passive sentences ('we were informed of something', for example). In some cases you can add the relevant object ('a number of Member States informed the Commission…'), otherwise, Alternatives: announce, declare, state.
rule.example: If Member States inform that they…
If a Member State informs that they…
If Member States announce that they…

rule.message: 'To inform' requires a direct object (inform the public/us/them etc.) and cannot be used without one except in passive sentences ('we were informed of something', for example). In some cases you can add the relevant object ('a number of Member States informed the Commission…'), otherwise, Alternatives: announced, declared, stated.
rule.example: A number of Member States informed that they…
Member States were informed that they can…

rule.name: informatics/Telematics
rule.message: Although the term exists in English, it is not widely understood. Alternatives: IT, ICT, or sometimes computer, computerised.
rule.example: Professional experience in informatics related to data base management…
Professional experience in informatics systems related to data base management…
Professional experience in IT related to data base management…
Professional experience in computer systems related to data base management…

rule.name: inside
rule.message: 'Inside' is often used in EU documents instead of 'within' or 'in' or even 'at' or 'by'. Alternatives: within, or the appropriate preposition: at, by, in.
rule.example: Evidence-based policy making inside the Commission…

rule.name: instance
rule.message: In EU texts, the word instance is often used to mean a decision-making body or authority. This meaning does not exist in English. Alternatives: authority, body.
rule.example: … for tasks undertaken by another instance on behalf of the said authorities.
… that cannot be given to other instances is probably unavoidable.
… for tasks undertaken by another authority on behalf of the said authorities.
When you instance the problems…

rule.name: intervention
rule.message: In international relations, the normal meaning of 'intervention' is 'interference by a state in another's affairs'. In EU parlance, it is just the term normally used to designate EU-funded operations in the member countries and elsewhere. In normal English usage, 'intervention' is often uncountable, leading to unwanted grammatical problems. Alternatives: activity, project, EU-funded activity.
rule.example: … become a means of making the EU intervention truly complementary.
The North of Kosovo: interventions have been very limited and there has been almost no progress in establishing the rule of law.
… should become a means of making the financial interventions truly complementary.
… become a means of making the EU project truly complementary.

rule.name: introduce
rule.message: Introduce normally means to 'present someone' or 'bring something in', whereas it is often used in our work to mean to 'submit' (as in submit an application or a report). Alternatives: submit, put/ send (an application/request/demand) in.
rule.example: When a State introduces a demand to be granted funding…
The importer can introduce an application for a refund.
… a candidate environmental verifier shall introduce a request with the Accreditation or Licensing Body…
When a State sends a demand to be granted funding…
The importer can apply for a refund.
… a candidate environmental verifier shall submit a request with the Accreditation or Licensing Body…

rule.name: jury
rule.message: A 'jury' is 'a group of, usually twelve, people sworn to deliver a true verdict according to the evidence upon a case presented in a court of law'. The term is also sometimes used in talent shows. In English, it is never used in the context of recruitment. Alternatives: selection board, selection panel.
rule.example: The jury invited the applicants for interview.
The selection panel invited the applicants for interview.

rule.message: In English, to justify means 'to demonstrate or prove to be just, right, or valid' or 'to show to be reasonable'. In EU texts, we often find it used just to mean 'to explain' or 'provide evidence for'. Alternatives: substantiate, provide evidence for, explain.
rule.example: The French Government did not justify the…
When you are justifying the…
The French Government did not explain the…

rule.message: In English, 'justification' is 'the act of justifying' or 'something that justifies'. In EU texts, we often find it used just to mean 'to explain' or 'provide evidence for'. Alternatives: evidence, supporting document, proof, explanation.
rule.example: The Government was unable to provide any justification, and the Commission could find none…
These justifications are not satisfactory.
The Government was unable to provide any explanation, and the Commission could find none…
These supporting documents are not satisfactory.

rule.name: legislator
rule.message: In EU English, a 'legislator' is a body, or, in the case of the EU, two bodies together ('the European legislator' = the Council and the Parliament). In regular English, a legislator is a person. Therefore, the word 'legislator' should be used to refer to a single MEP, not, for example, to the whole Parliament. Alternatives: legislature(= 'a body of persons having the power to legislate'), legislative body, the Council and Parliament.
rule.example: … while respecting the prerogatives of the two branches of legislator.
Members of the two legislators must…
… more time is needed to allow reaching an agreement at the level of the European legislator, …
… while respecting the prerogatives of the two branches of legislature.
Members of the two legislatures must…

rule.name: mission
rule.message: 'Mission' has a number of meanings, none of which corresponds to the way it is most commonly used in EU texts. Generally speaking, missions, in English, are performed by secret agents, astronauts or diplomats. Otherwise they can be the places where priests, nuns, diplomats etc. work abroad (often in developing countries). While it would be difficult to do without the word internally, we should bear in mind that it is likely to be misconstrued by outsiders. Alternatives: audit/ visit (at the Court of Auditors), sometimes official trip, official business or just business or work.
rule.example: Last week I was in Rome on a mission.
Last week I was in Rome for an audit.
I was in Rome on business.
I was in Rome for work.
With regard to the management of travel orders, the missions office… has systematically coordinated the reservation of plane tickets…

rule.name: modality
rule.message: 'Modality' is one of those words which people (a) swear is correct and (b) say they have to use because the Commission does so (the example below is a case in point). The trouble is that it is not English – at least not in the meaning applied in our texts. EUR Lex contains over two thousand cases in which it is used to mean 'procedure', but this does not make it mean 'procedure'. In English, it is a rare and quite specialised word (only 50 or so hits in the British National Corpus), whose main meanings relate to grammar, philosophy, medicine and physiology. Alternatives: procedure, method, mode.
rule.example: Evaluation modalities have changed over recent years.
The evaluation modality has changed over recent years.
Evaluation procedures have changed over recent years.

rule.message: Modify is fine. It is just over-used. So when referring to changes to legislation, prefer amend. In other contexts, the word change is a more common alternative.
rule.example: The Commission… undertook to make proposals to modify the regulation.
When you are modifying a document…
The Commission… undertook to make proposals to amend the regulation.

rule.message: Modification is fine. It is just over-used. So when referring to changes to legislation, prefer amendment. In other contexts, the word change is a more common alternative.
rule.example: The modification to the regulations…
Modifications to the documents must…
The amendment to the regulations…

rule.name: modulation
rule.message: In English, 'modulation' is only normally used in the fields of music and grammar and with regard to wave frequencies. In EU documents, it is used to mean reduction and, in the jargon of the common agricultural policy, refers specifically to a 'system of progressive reduction of direct payments allowing a transfer of funds from Pillar 1… to Pillar 2'. Alternatives: adjustment, reduction, increase. With reference to the common agricultural policy, if you use 'modulation', it must be explained.
rule.example: The voluntary modulations should take the form of…
Regulation (EC) No 73/2009 established a system of compulsory, progressive reduction of direct payments ("modulation").
The voluntary adjustments should take the form of…

rule.name: name
rule.message: In EU texts, the word 'name' is often used to refer exclusively to a person's surname, so we are asked to supply someone's 'name and first name'. In English, a person's 'name' is his/her whole name. The 'first name' should come first and the 'last name' last. Documents and forms in English should unambiguously specify which name is which, e.g. by using the neutral terms given and family . In running text (as opposed to forms or tables), the normal order should be retained.
rule.example: CardHolderName is the name and given name(s) of the holder of the Control Card.
Title, Name and surname, Position in the applicant organisation.
Write the person's first names and surname.
You must name the person who…
When you name the person who must…

rule.name: normally
rule.message: Normally means 'as a rule', 'usually', 'ordinarily' or 'in a normal manner' (e.g. 'act normally!'). In EU usage, it often expresses something that should happen. Use: 'supposed to', 'should', 'expected to'.
rule.example: Normally, she will come at 8 o'clock'.
Are you free this weekend?' 'Yes, normally.' (= 'I should be.').
She should be here at 8 o'clock.

rule.name: note
rule.message: In our administration, the word 'note' (dictionary definition = 'a brief letter, usually of an informal nature') seems to have invaded the semantic fields of both 'memo' ('a written communication, as in a business office') and 'letter' (many of our 'notes' are anything but brief, and none of them are informal). Alternatives: memo, letter.
rule.example: An information note from Vice-President Kallas and the President, … was adopted in 2008.
The notes were posted last week.
An information letter from Vice-President Kallas and the President, … was adopted in 2008.
When you note the time of the test…

rule.name: notify to
rule.message: We normally notify somebody of something, we do not usually notify something to someone. If you notify something to someone, you report it, formally, usually to some sort of authority. If you notify somebody of something, you inform them of it. Alternatives: send, provide… with, inform or notify somebody of something, report something to somebody.
rule.example: Member States shall notify to the Commission the name, the address, ….
Contracting entities notified to the Commission the following information…
Member States shall tell the Commission the name, the address, ….
Contracting entities shall send the Commission the following information…
Barely one third of school absences were notified to social services department'.
Residents were notified of the scheme late last week

rule.name: operator/economic operator
rule.message: EUR Lex has 1,057 hits for 'economic operator'. Although the term is not used in English in this way, I take it that these are simply companies or businesses. Similarly, on its own, the term 'operator' is used to cover a wide range of activities – in customs, it can mean 'importer' or 'exporter' or possibly 'shipping company': in agriculture, it can refer to farmers or people who market or process their produce etc. It would be clearer to call things by their own name – business if you mean business, farmer if you mean farmer, importer if you mean importer etc.
rule.example: … a serious risk caused by an economic operator to the proper and secure functioning of the Single Market.
… a serious risk caused by an importer to the proper and secure functioning of the Single Market.

rule.name: opportunity
rule.message: 'Opportunity' does not mean 'the character of that which is opportune' (I am translating verbatim from a French dictionary). The English dictionary definition of opportunity is 'a favourable or advantageous circumstance or occasion or time' (as in 'I take the opportunity to wish you a merry Christmas.'). Alternatives: advisability, whether it was advisable to, whether it would be opportune to.
rule.example: The Court questioned the opportunity of introducing these measures.
The Court questioned the advisability of introducing these measures.

rule.name: orientations
rule.message: EU 'orientations' are guidelines. Orientation, in English, is uncountable and means 'the act of determining one's bearings or settling one's sense of direction'. Alternatives: guidelines.
rule.example: It will include policy orientations in all these areas.
